Title: Mice in Bion-M 1 space mission: training and selection
Abstract: After a 16-year hiatus, Russia has resumed its program of biomedical research in space, with the successful 30-day flight of the Bion-M 1 biosatellite (April 19–May 19, 2013). The principal species for biomedical research in this project was the mouse. This paper presents an overview of the scientific goals, the experimental design and the mouse training/selection program. The aim of mice experiments in the Bion-M 1 project was to elucidate cellular and molecular mechanisms, underlying the adaptation of key physiological systems to long-term exposure in microgravity. The studies with mice combined in vivo measurements, both in flight and post-flight (including continuous blood pressure measurement), with extensive in vitro studies carried out shortly after return of the mice and in the end of recovery study. Male C57/BL6 mice group housed in space habitats were flown aboard the Bion-M 1 biosatellite, or remained on ground in the control experiment that replicated environmental and housing conditions in the spacecraft. Vivarium control groups were used to account for housing effects and possible seasonal differences. Mice training included the co-adaptation in housing groups and mice adaptation to paste food diet. The measures taken to co-adapt aggressive male mice in housing groups and the peculiarities of “space” paste food are described. The training program for mice designated for in vivo studies was broader and included behavioral/functional test battery and continuous behavioral measurements in the home-cage. The results of the preliminary tests were used for the selection of homogenous groups. After the flight, mice were in good condition for biomedical studies and displayed signs of pronounced disadaptation to Earth's gravity. The outcomes of the training program for the mice welfare are discussed. We conclude that our training program was effective and that male mice can be successfully employed in space biomedical research.
Conclusion: The Bion-M 1 flight was unique in many ways, particularly the unprecedented duration of an automated mission with living animals. The sex of the mice was male, thus imposing greater attention to creation and selection of stable groups of mice for social housing. The overall success was evident: aggressive interactions were noted on single occasions and under conditions of starvation only. The use of male animals is obviously required for research in male reproduction and their larger size compared to females offered clear advantages. Our program of mice training for flight and control experiments of the Bion-M 1 project was aimed to: ensure that mice adapt to stressful conditions of space flight when housed in groups; to collect baseline data from these mice; select homogenous groups; and, more generally, to promote collection of less variable data. The results of our program presented here demonstrate that group housed male mice need not be excluded a priori, but quite on the contrary, can be successfully employed in space biomedical research if clear and simple procedures provided by this study are followed. The failures in this project were connected with hardware malfunction in food distribution system and to microgravity-related changes in mouse behavior. Some of the injuries and deaths encountered in this pioneering effort suggest moving parts within the habitat present potential risks and should be avoided or carefully analyzed in the design of future mouse habitats. In this space experiment we have, for the first time, introduced implantable telemetry in these small laboratory animals. This shift to data collection during the flight became possible with the development of miniature implantable probes, thereby dramatically increasing the scientific output of such experiments. Moreover, the use of an automated data collection system during the post-flight stage of this experiment provided comprehensive data on the course and mechanism of recovery of varied physiological systems following exposure to microgravity. The unprecedented inclusion of daily video recordings proved valuable for scientific purposes, for animal welfare considerations, and for assessing both nominal and aberrant events. The good condition of spaceflight mice was the basis for the positive results of both the recovery and tissue sharing studies; leading us to conclude that our training program was generally effective. We express our hope that the results and considerations presented here will be useful for the planning of future missions and will help to ensure the welfare of rodents in space research.
Overview: This paper is essential reading for researchers in space biosciences as it outlines the successful methodology for preparing male mice for the unprecedented 30-day Bion-M 1 space mission. It details a critical training and selection program that effectively managed aggression in group-housed males, a significant hurdle in animal space research. The study provides a valuable blueprint for experimental design and animal welfare in long-duration spaceflight, addressing practical challenges like diet adaptation and in-flight monitoring, making it invaluable for planning future missions.
Summary:
Background: After a 16-year break, Russia's Bion-M 1 mission aimed to study microgravity's effects on mice over 30 days. A primary challenge was managing the natural aggression of group-housed male mice and adapting them to spaceflight conditions to ensure their suitability for biomedical studies.

Methods: Researchers implemented a thorough training program for male C57/BL6 mice. This involved co-adapting mice into stable groups to minimize aggression, transitioning them to a paste-based diet suitable for space, and selecting homogenous groups based on behavioral tests. For the first time in such a long mission, implantable telemetry devices were used for continuous in-flight physiological monitoring, supplemented by daily video recordings.

Results: The training program proved highly successful. Aggressive behaviors were minimal, and the mice were in good health post-flight, showing clear signs of adaptation to microgravity. This validated them as suitable subjects for subsequent studies. The telemetry and video data provided significant scientific insights and aided in monitoring animal welfare, although hardware malfunctions with the food distribution system were noted.

Conclusions: The study concludes that with appropriate pre-flight training and selection, group-housed male mice are viable subjects for long-duration space biomedical research. The success of the mission's animal preparation program set a new standard for future experiments, while also highlighting the need for improved habitat hardware and the immense value of in-flight data collection technologies.

Title: Microgravity induces pelvic bone loss through osteoclastic activity, osteocytic osteolysis, and osteoblastic cell cycle inhibition by CDKN1a/p21
Abstract: Bone is a dynamically remodeled tissue that requires gravity-mediated mechanical stimulation for maintenance of mineral content and structure. Homeostasis in bone occurs through a balance in the activities and signaling of osteoclasts, osteoblasts, and osteocytes, as well as proliferation and differentiation of their stem cell progenitors. Microgravity and unloading are known to cause osteoclast-mediated bone resorption; however, we hypothesize that osteocytic osteolysis, and cell cycle arrest during osteogenesis may also contribute to bone loss in space. To test this possibility, we exposed 16-week-old female C57BL/6J mice (n = 8) to microgravity for 15-days on the STS-131 space shuttle mission. Analysis of the pelvis by µCT shows decreases in bone volume fraction (BV/TV) of 6.29%, and bone thickness of 11.91%. TRAP-positive osteoclast-covered trabecular bone surfaces also increased in microgravity by 170% (p = 0.004), indicating osteoclastic bone degeneration. High-resolution X-ray nanoCT studies revealed signs of lacunar osteolysis, including increases in cross-sectional area (+17%, p = 0.022), perimeter (+14%, p = 0.008), and canalicular diameter (+6%, p = 0.037). Expression of matrix metalloproteinases (MMP) 1, 3, and 10 in bone, as measured by RT-qPCR, was also up-regulated in microgravity (+12.94, +2.98 and +16.85 fold respectively, p<0.01), with MMP10 localized to osteocytes, and consistent with induction of osteocytic osteolysis. Furthermore, expression of CDKN1a/p21 in bone increased 3.31 fold (p<0.01), and was localized to osteoblasts, possibly inhibiting the cell cycle during tissue regeneration as well as conferring apoptosis resistance to these cells. Finally the apoptosis inducer Trp53 was down-regulated by −1.54 fold (p<0.01), possibly associated with the quiescent survival-promoting function of CDKN1a/p21. In conclusion, our findings identify the pelvic and femoral region of the mouse skeleton as an active site of rapid bone loss in microgravity, and indicate that this loss is not limited to osteoclastic degradation. Therefore, this study offers new evidence for microgravity-induced osteocytic osteolysis, and CDKN1a/p21-mediated osteogenic cell cycle arrest.
Conclusion: In total, our findings demonstrate the pelvic-femoral musculo-skeletal complex as a highly load and gravity sensitive structure that can serve as a valuable model to study muscle and bone degeneration in space. Additionally, we demonstrate that bone responses to spaceflight are complex and involve osteoclastic, osteoblastic, and osteocytic degenerative responses. Finally, our findings on CDKN1a/p21 up-regulation in microgravity have the potential to become a major concern for tissue regenerative health in long-duration spaceflight. Future studies should address the specific molecular regulatory mechanisms of CDKN1a/p21 involvement in tissue degeneration during long-term spaceflight and the possibility of systemic activation of this strong molecular inhibitor of regenerative adult stem cell proliferation.
Overview: This study is crucial for understanding the multi-faceted mechanisms of bone loss in space. It moves beyond the known role of osteoclasts to reveal how microgravity also triggers osteocytic osteolysis (bone degradation by bone cells themselves) and halts the cell cycle of bone-forming osteoblasts. By identifying these additional pathways in mice on the STS-131 mission, the paper provides new, critical targets for developing countermeasures against space-induced osteoporosis and unloading-related bone loss on Earth.
Summary:
Background: Bone homeostasis requires mechanical stimulation from gravity. While microgravity is known to cause bone resorption via osteoclasts, this study hypothesized that other mechanisms, such as osteocytic osteolysis and the arrest of bone-forming cell cycles, also contribute significantly to bone loss in space.

Methods: Sixteen-week-old female C57BL/6J mice were exposed to microgravity for 15 days on the STS-131 space shuttle mission. Post-flight, their pelvic bones were analyzed using high-resolution µCT and nanoCT imaging, TRAP staining for osteoclast activity, and RT-qPCR to measure the expression of genes related to bone degradation and cell cycle regulation.

Results: Microgravity exposure led to a 6.29% decrease in bone volume and a 11.91% decrease in bone thickness, with a 170% increase in osteoclast activity. Crucially, nanoCT revealed signs of osteocytic osteolysis, including enlarged lacunae and canaliculi. Gene expression analysis showed upregulation of matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) consistent with this process, and a 3.31-fold increase in CDKN1a/p21, a cell cycle inhibitor localized to osteoblasts.

Conclusions: The study confirms that the pelvic-femoral region is highly sensitive to microgravity and serves as a valuable model for space-induced degeneration. It provides new evidence that bone loss in space is a complex process involving not only increased osteoclast activity but also osteocytic osteolysis and CDKN1a/p21-mediated inhibition of bone regeneration. The upregulation of CDKN1a/p21 is highlighted as a major potential concern for tissue health in long-duration spaceflight.

Title: Stem Cell Health and Tissue Regeneration in Microgravity
Abstract: Microgravity, defined by minimal gravitational forces, represents a unique environment that profoundly influences biological systems, including human cells. This review examines the effects of microgravity on biological processes and their implications for human health. Microgravity significantly impacts the immune system by disrupting key mechanisms, such as T cell activation, cytokine production, and macrophage differentiation, leading to increased susceptibility to infections. In cancer biology, it promotes the formation of spheroids in cancer stem cells and thyroid cancer cells, which closely mimic in vivo tumor dynamics, providing novel insights for oncology research. Additionally, microgravity enhances tissue regeneration by modulating critical pathways, including Hippo and PI3K-Akt, thereby improving stem cell differentiation into hematopoietic and cardiomyocyte lineages. At the organ level, microgravity induces notable changes in hepatic metabolism, endothelial function, and bone mechanotransduction, contributing to lipid dysregulation, vascular remodeling, and accelerated bone loss. Notably, cardiomyocytes derived from human pluripotent stem cells and cultured under microgravity exhibit enhanced mitochondrial biogenesis, improved calcium handling, and advanced structural maturation, including increased sarcomere length and nuclear eccentricity. These advancements enable the development of functional cardiomyocytes, presenting promising therapeutic opportunities for treating cardiac diseases, such as myocardial infarctions. These findings underscore the dual implications of microgravity for space medicine and terrestrial health. They highlight its potential to drive advances in regenerative therapies, oncology, and immunological interventions. Continued research into the biological effects of microgravity is essential for protecting astronaut health during prolonged space missions and fostering biomedical innovations with transformative applications on Earth.
Overview: This review is a vital read for researchers in space medicine and regenerative therapies, as it synthesizes the profound and often dual-edged effects of microgravity on human biological systems. It explains how microgravity disrupts the immune system and accelerates bone loss, while also creating unique opportunities for cancer research and enhancing tissue regeneration. The paper specifically highlights how microgravity helps mature functional cardiomyocytes from stem cells, presenting promising avenues for treating cardiac diseases on Earth.
Summary:
Background: Microgravity, the environment of space, has a significant impact on biological systems. This review paper examines these effects on human cells and organs, exploring the implications for both astronaut health during long-duration missions and potential biomedical applications on Earth.

Methods: As a review article, the study synthesizes existing research on the effects of microgravity. It covers a range of topics including immune system function (T cell activation, cytokine production), cancer biology (spheroid formation), tissue regeneration (Hippo and PI3K-Akt pathways), organ-level changes (liver, endothelium, bone), and specific cellular advancements (cardiomyocyte maturation).

Results: Microgravity impairs immune functions, increasing susceptibility to infections. In cancer research, it aids the formation of 3D tumor spheroids that better mimic in vivo conditions. It enhances stem cell differentiation into blood and heart cells, and notably, cardiomyocytes cultured in microgravity show advanced structural maturation and improved function (mitochondrial biogenesis, calcium handling). However, it also contributes to lipid dysregulation in the liver and accelerates bone loss.

Conclusions: The abstract indicates the paper's findings underscore the dual implications of microgravity for space medicine and terrestrial health. It highlights microgravity's potential to drive advances in regenerative therapies, oncology, and immunological interventions. Continued research is deemed essential for protecting astronaut health and fostering biomedical innovations with transformative applications on Earth.

Title: Microgravity Reduces the Differentiation and Regenerative Potential of Embryonic Stem Cells
Abstract: Therapeutic effects of adult stem-cell transplantations are limited by poor cell-retention in target organs, and a reduced potential for optimal cell differentiation compared to embryonic stem cells. However, contemporary studies have indicated heterogeneity within adult stem-cell pools, and a novel culturing technique may address these limitations by selecting those for cell proliferation which are highly functional. Here, we report the preservation of stemness in human adipose-derived stem cells (hASCs) by using microgravity conditions combined with microspheres in a stirred suspension. The cells were bound to microspheres (100−300 μm) and cultured using a wave-stirring shaker. One-week cultures using polystyrene and collagen microspheres increased the proportions of SSEA-3(+) hASCs 4.4- and 4.3-fold (2.7- and 2.9-fold increases in their numbers), respectively, compared to normal culture conditions. These cultured hASCs expressed higher levels of pluripotent markers (OCT4, SOX2, NANOG, MYC, and KLF), and had improved abilities for proliferation, colony formation, network formation, and multiple-mesenchymal differentiation. We believe that this novel culturing method may further enhance regenerative therapies using hASCs.
Overview: This paper presents a novel cell culturing technique that could significantly enhance regenerative medicine. Researchers demonstrate that combining simulated microgravity with microspheres preserves the 'stemness' of human adipose-derived stem cells (hASCs), a major challenge in therapeutic applications. This method not only increases the number of highly functional stem cells but also improves their ability to proliferate and differentiate. It offers a promising new strategy for generating more effective adult stem cells for transplantation therapies.
Summary:
Background: The therapeutic use of adult stem cells is often limited because they lose their differentiation potential and are poorly retained in target organs compared to embryonic stem cells. This study aimed to develop a new culturing method to address these limitations by preserving the 'stemness' of human adipose-derived stem cells (hASCs).

Methods: Researchers cultured hASCs on microspheres (100-300 µm) in a stirred suspension under simulated microgravity conditions using a wave-stirring shaker. They compared the proportions of SSEA-3(+) hASCs and the expression of pluripotent markers (OCT4, SOX2, etc.) in cells grown with this method versus those in normal culture conditions. The functional abilities for proliferation, colony formation, and differentiation were also assessed.

Results: The one-week microgravity culture method significantly increased the proportion of desirable SSEA-3(+) hASCs by 4.3 to 4.4-fold. These cultured cells expressed higher levels of key pluripotent markers and demonstrated improved abilities for proliferation, colony formation, and differentiation into multiple mesenchymal lineages compared to conventionally cultured hASCs.

Conclusions: The abstract suggests that this novel culturing method, combining simulated microgravity and microspheres, may significantly enhance the therapeutic potential of hASCs for regenerative therapies. By preserving stemness and improving cell function, this technique offers a new pathway to generate more effective cells for clinical applications.

Title: Microgravity validation of a novel system for RNA isolation and multiplex quantitative real time PCR analysis of gene expression on the International Space Station
Abstract: The International Space Station (ISS) National Laboratory is dedicated to studying the effects of space on life and physical systems, and to developing new science and technologies for space exploration. A key aspect of achieving these goals is to operate the ISS National Lab more like an Earth-based laboratory, conducting complex end-to-end experimentation, not limited to simple microgravity exposure. Towards that end NASA developed a novel suite of molecular biology laboratory tools, reagents, and methods, named WetLab-2, uniquely designed to operate in microgravity, and to process biological samples for real-time gene expression analysis on-orbit. This includes a novel fluidic RNA Sample Preparation Module and fluid transfer devices, all-in-one lyophilized PCR assays, centrifuge, and a real-time PCR thermal cycler. Here we describe the results from the WetLab-2 validation experiments conducted in microgravity during ISS increment 47/SPX-8. Specifically, quantitative PCR was performed on a concentration series of DNA calibration standards, and Reverse Transcriptase-quantitative PCR was conducted on RNA extracted and purified on-orbit from frozen Escherichia coli and mouse liver tissue. Cycle threshold (Ct) values and PCR efficiencies obtained on-orbit from DNA standards were similar to Earth (1 g) controls. Also, on-orbit multiplex analysis of gene expression from bacterial cells and mammalian tissue RNA samples was successfully conducted in about 3 h, with data transmitted within 2 h of experiment completion. Thermal cycling in microgravity resulted in the trapping of gas bubbles inside septa cap assay tubes, causing small but measurable increases in Ct curve noise and variability. Bubble formation was successfully suppressed in a rapid follow-up on-orbit experiment using standard caps to pressurize PCR tubes and reduce gas release during heating cycles. The WetLab-2 facility now provides a novel operational on-orbit research capability for molecular biology and demonstrates the feasibility of more complex wet bench experiments in the ISS National Lab environment.
Overview: This research is a landmark for space biosciences, detailing the successful on-orbit validation of the WetLab-2 system, a molecular biology toolkit for the International Space Station (ISS). It demonstrates for the first time that complex procedures like RNA isolation and real-time gene expression analysis can be performed in microgravity, moving the ISS closer to a fully functional Earth-like laboratory. This capability is critical for understanding the immediate biological effects of spaceflight without the confounding variables of returning samples to Earth.
Summary:
Background: To advance space exploration, the ISS National Laboratory needs to function more like a terrestrial lab, enabling complex end-to-end experiments. NASA developed the WetLab-2 suite of molecular biology tools to allow for on-orbit sample processing and real-time gene expression analysis in microgravity, a significant technological hurdle.

Methods: On the ISS, researchers performed quantitative PCR on DNA standards and conducted Reverse Transcriptase-quantitative PCR (RT-qPCR) on RNA that was extracted and purified on-orbit from frozen Escherichia coli and mouse liver tissue. The experiment utilized novel microgravity-compatible hardware, including an RNA Sample Preparation Module and lyophilized PCR assays.

Results: The on-orbit experiments were highly successful. Data from DNA standards closely matched Earth-based controls. Gene expression analysis from both bacterial and mammalian tissues was completed in about 3 hours, with data transmitted to the ground shortly after. An initial issue with gas bubbles forming in PCR tubes during heating in microgravity was identified and successfully suppressed in a follow-up experiment by using different caps to pressurize the tubes.

Conclusions: The abstract concludes that the WetLab-2 facility provides a novel and operational on-orbit research capability for molecular biology. The success of these validation experiments demonstrates the feasibility of conducting more complex wet bench experiments on the ISS, enabling real-time analysis of biological samples without the need for return to Earth.

Title: Spaceflight Modulates the Expression of Key Oxidative Stress and Cell Cycle Related Genes in Heart
Abstract: Spaceflight causes cardiovascular changes due to microgravity-induced redistribution of body fluids and musculoskeletal unloading. Cardiac deconditioning and atrophy on Earth are associated with altered Trp53 and oxidative stress-related pathways, but the effects of spaceflight on cardiac changes at the molecular level are less understood. We tested the hypothesis that spaceflight alters the expression of key genes related to stress response pathways, which may contribute to cardiovascular deconditioning during extended spaceflight. Mice were exposed to spaceflight for 15 days or maintained on Earth (ground control). Ventricle tissue was harvested starting ~3 h post-landing. We measured expression of select genes implicated in oxidative stress pathways and Trp53 signaling by quantitative PCR. Cardiac expression levels of 37 of 168 genes tested were altered after spaceflight. Spaceflight downregulated transcription factor, Nfe2l2 (Nrf2), upregulated Nox1 and downregulated Ptgs2, suggesting a persistent increase in oxidative stress-related target genes. Spaceflight also substantially upregulated Cdkn1a (p21) and cell cycle/apoptosis-related gene Myc, and downregulated the inflammatory response gene Tnf. There were no changes in apoptosis-related genes such as Trp53. Spaceflight altered the expression of genes regulating redox balance, cell cycle and senescence in cardiac tissue of mice. Thus, spaceflight may contribute to cardiac dysfunction due to oxidative stress.
Overview: This study provides crucial molecular insights into how spaceflight affects the heart, making it essential for understanding cardiovascular deconditioning in astronauts. By analyzing mouse heart tissue after 15 days in space, researchers identified that spaceflight alters key genes related to oxidative stress, cell cycle, and senescence. Specifically, the significant upregulation of Cdkn1a (p21) suggests a mechanism that could contribute to cardiac dysfunction, offering a potential target for countermeasures to protect heart health during long-duration missions.
Summary:
Background: Spaceflight is known to cause cardiovascular changes, but the molecular underpinnings are not well understood. On Earth, similar cardiac deconditioning is linked to altered Trp53 and oxidative stress pathways. This study hypothesized that spaceflight similarly alters the expression of key stress response genes in the heart.

Methods: Ventricle tissue was harvested from mice approximately 3 hours after they returned from a 15-day spaceflight mission. The expression of 168 select genes implicated in oxidative stress pathways and Trp53 signaling was measured using quantitative PCR and compared to ground control mice.

Results: Spaceflight altered the expression of 37 of the 168 genes tested. Key findings include the downregulation of the transcription factor Nfe2l2 (Nrf2), which protects against oxidative stress, and the upregulation of Nox1, which generates oxidative stress. Most notably, spaceflight caused a substantial upregulation of Cdkn1a (p21), a gene linked to cell cycle arrest and senescence, and the cell cycle/apoptosis-related gene Myc. The inflammatory gene Tnf was downregulated.

Conclusions: The study concludes that spaceflight alters the expression of genes that regulate redox balance, cell cycle, and senescence in mouse cardiac tissue. These changes, particularly the persistent increase in oxidative stress-related genes and upregulation of p21, may contribute to cardiac dysfunction and deconditioning during extended space missions.

Title: Dose- and Ion-Dependent Effects in the Oxidative Stress Response to Space-Like Radiation Exposure in the Skeletal System
Abstract: Space radiation may pose a risk to skeletal health during subsequent aging. Irradiation acutely stimulates bone remodeling in mice, although the long-term influence of space radiation on bone-forming potential (osteoblastogenesis) and possible adaptive mechanisms are not well understood. We hypothesized that ionizing radiation impairs osteoblastogenesis in an ion-type specific manner, with low doses capable of modulating expression of redox-related genes. 16-weeks old, male, C57BL6/J mice were exposed to low linear-energy-transfer (LET) protons (150 MeV/n) or high-LET 56Fe ions (600 MeV/n) using either low (5 or 10 cGy) or high (50 or 200 cGy) doses at NASA’s Space Radiation Lab. Five weeks or one year after irradiation, tissues were harvested and analyzed by microcomputed tomography for cancellous microarchitecture and cortical geometry. Marrow-derived, adherent cells were grown under osteoblastogenic culture conditions. Cell lysates were analyzed by RT-PCR during the proliferative or mineralizing phase of growth, and differentiation was analyzed by imaging mineralized nodules. As expected, a high dose (200 cGy), but not lower doses, of either 56Fe or protons caused a loss of cancellous bone volume/total volume. Marrow cells produced mineralized nodules ex vivo regardless of radiation type or dose; 56Fe (200 cGy) inhibited osteoblastogenesis by more than 90% (5 weeks and 1 year post-IR). After 5 weeks, irradiation (protons or 56Fe) caused few changes in gene expression levels during osteoblastogenesis, although a high dose 56Fe (200 cGy) increased Catalase and Gadd45. The addition of exogenous superoxide dismutase (SOD) protected marrow-derived osteoprogenitors from the damaging effects of exposure to low-LET (137Cs γ) when irradiated in vitro, but had limited protective effects on high-LET 56Fe-exposed cells. In sum, either protons or 56Fe at a relatively high dose (200 cGy) caused persistent bone loss, whereas only high-LET 56Fe increased redox-related gene expression, albeit to a limited extent, and inhibited osteoblastogenesis. Doses below 50 cGy did not elicit widespread responses in any parameter measured. We conclude that high-LET irradiation at 200 cGy impaired osteoblastogenesis and regulated steady-state gene expression of select redox-related genes during osteoblastogenesis, which may contribute to persistent bone loss.
Overview: This paper is essential for assessing the long-term skeletal health risks for astronauts on deep-space missions. It investigates how different types of space-like radiation (protons vs. heavy ions) at various doses affect bone in mice. The study uniquely finds that only high-dose, high-LET heavy ions (56Fe) not only cause persistent bone loss but also impair the bone-forming potential of marrow cells. This suggests that the type of radiation is a critical factor in skeletal damage, providing vital information for developing targeted radiation countermeasures.
Summary:
Background: Space radiation may pose a long-term risk to skeletal health. While radiation is known to acutely stimulate bone remodeling, its long-term impact on the potential of marrow cells to form new bone (osteoblastogenesis) and the specific effects of different ion types are not well understood.

Methods: Male C57BL6/J mice were exposed to either low-LET protons or high-LET 56Fe ions at low (5-10 cGy) or high (50-200 cGy) doses. Tissues were harvested 5 weeks or 1 year post-irradiation. Bone microarchitecture was analyzed by microcomputed tomography. Marrow-derived cells were cultured to assess their ability to form mineralized bone nodules ex vivo, and gene expression was analyzed by RT-PCR.

Results: As expected, only high doses (200 cGy) of both protons and 56Fe caused persistent loss of cancellous bone. However, only the high dose of high-LET 56Fe radiation significantly inhibited the ability of marrow cells to form bone (by over 90%), a defect that persisted for up to a year. This was accompanied by a limited increase in redox-related gene expression (Catalase, Gadd45). Doses below 50 cGy had no measurable effect on any parameter.

Conclusions: The study concludes that high-LET 56Fe irradiation at a dose of 200 cGy uniquely impairs osteoblastogenesis and alters the expression of select redox-related genes. This impairment in bone-forming potential may contribute to the persistent bone loss observed after exposure, highlighting that different types of space radiation have distinct long-term biological effects on the skeleton.

Title: From the bench to exploration medicine: NASA life sciences translational research for human exploration and habitation missions.
Abstract: NASA’s Space Biology and Human Research Program entities have recently spearheaded communications both internally and externally to coordinate the agency’s translational research efforts. In this paper, we strongly advocate for translational research at NASA, provide recent examples of NASA sponsored early-stage translational research, and discuss options for a path forward. Our overall objective is to help in stimulating a collaborative research across multiple disciplines and entities that, working together, will more effectively and more rapidly achieve NASA’s goals for human spaceflight.
Overview: This paper serves as a crucial call to action for the space life sciences community, advocating for a stronger emphasis on translational research within NASA. It highlights the gap between basic research and the development of practical medical solutions for astronauts on exploration missions. By providing recent examples of early-stage translational work and discussing a path forward, the authors aim to stimulate the interdisciplinary collaboration needed to more rapidly convert scientific discoveries into tangible health countermeasures for human spaceflight.
Summary:
Background: With human space exploration missions becoming more ambitious, there is a pressing need to translate basic life sciences research into practical medical countermeasures and technologies for astronauts. NASA's Space Biology and Human Research Programs have initiated efforts to coordinate and promote this translational process.

Methods: This paper is an advocacy piece and review. The authors make a strong case for translational research at NASA by discussing its importance. They present recent examples of NASA-sponsored research projects that are in the early stages of translation, aiming to bridge the gap from laboratory findings to clinical application.

Results: The paper highlights several examples of promising early-stage translational research, demonstrating the potential for scientific discoveries to be developed into health solutions for astronauts. It underscores the need for a more structured and collaborative approach across different scientific disciplines and NASA entities to accelerate this process.

Conclusions: The overall objective is to stimulate a more collaborative research environment that spans multiple disciplines. The authors argue that by working together more effectively, the research community can accelerate the achievement of NASA's goals for human spaceflight, ensuring astronaut health and safety on long-duration exploration and habitation missions.

Title: High-precision method for cyclic loading of small-animal vertebrae to assess bone quality.
Abstract: One potentially important bone quality characteristic is the response of bone to cyclic (repetitive) mechanical loading. In small animals, such as in rats and mice, cyclic loading experiments are particularly challenging to perform in a precise manner due to the small size of the bones and difficult-to-eliminate machine compliance. Addressing this issue, we developed a precise method for ex vivo cyclic compressive loading of isolated mouse vertebral bodies. The method has three key characteristics: 3D-printed support jigs for machining plano-parallel surfaces of the tiny vertebrae; pivotable loading platens to ensure uniform contact and loading of specimen surfaces; and specimen-specific micro-CT-based finite element analysis to measure stiffness to prescribe force levels that produce the same specified level of strain for all test specimens. To demonstrate utility, we measured fatigue life for three groups (n = 5–6 per group) of L5 vertebrae of C57BL/6J male mice, comparing our new method against two methods commonly used in the literature. We found reduced scatter of the mechanical behavior for this new method compared to the literature methods. In particular, for a controlled level of strain, the standard deviation of the measured fatigue life was up to 5-fold lower for the new method (F-ratio = 4.9; p < 0.01). The improved precision for this new method for biomechanical testing of small-animal vertebrae may help elucidate aspects of bone quality.
Overview: This study is highly valuable for researchers in bone mechanics and animal modeling, as it introduces a high-precision method for testing the fatigue life of small-animal vertebrae. Traditional methods suffer from imprecision due to the tiny size of mouse bones. This new technique, using 3D-printed jigs and specimen-specific analysis, reduces the variability in fatigue life measurements by up to five-fold. This improved precision is critical for accurately elucidating aspects of bone quality and the effects of diseases or treatments on the spine.
Summary:
Background: Assessing bone quality involves understanding its response to repetitive (cyclic) loading, which can lead to fatigue failure. However, performing precise cyclic loading experiments on small animal bones, like mouse vertebrae, is challenging due to their size and the compliance of testing machines.

Methods: The researchers developed a new method for ex vivo cyclic compressive loading of mouse vertebral bodies. The method incorporates three key innovations: 1) 3D-printed jigs to prepare the tiny vertebrae with perfectly parallel surfaces, 2) pivotable loading platens to ensure uniform force distribution, and 3) micro-CT-based finite element analysis for each specimen to prescribe forces that achieve a consistent level of strain across all samples.

Results: To demonstrate the method's utility, the fatigue life of mouse vertebrae was measured and compared against two commonly used literature methods. The new method significantly reduced the scatter and variability of the results. The standard deviation of the measured fatigue life was up to 5-fold lower with the new technique, indicating much higher precision.

Conclusions: The improved precision of this novel method for biomechanical testing of small-animal vertebrae is a significant advancement. It may help researchers better elucidate important aspects of bone quality, such as fatigue resistance, which is crucial for understanding bone health and disease.

Title: Effects of ex vivo ionizing radiation on collagen structure and whole-bone mechanical properties of mouse vertebrae.
Abstract: Bone can become brittle when exposed to ionizing radiation across a wide range of clinically relevant doses that span from radiotherapy (accumulative 50 Gy) to sterilization (~35,000 Gy). While irradiation-induced embrittlement has been attributed to changes in the collagen molecular structure, the relative role of collagen fragmentation versus non-enzymatic collagen crosslinking remains unclear. To better understand the effects of radiation on the bone material without cellular activity, we conducted an ex vivo x-ray radiation experiment on excised mouse lumbar vertebrae. Spinal tissue from twenty-week old, female, C57BL/6J mice were randomly assigned to a single x-ray radiation dose of either 0 (control), 50, 1,000, 17,000, or 35,000 Gy. Measurements were made for collagen fragmentation, non-enzymatic collagen crosslinking, and both monotonic and cyclic-loading compressive mechanical properties. We found that the group differences for mechanical properties were more consistent with those for collagen fragmentation than for non-enzymatic collagen crosslinking. Monotonic strength at 17,000 and 35,000 Gy was lower than that of the control by 50% and 73% respectively, (p < 0.001) but at 50 and 1,000 Gy was not different than the control. Consistent with those trends, collagen fragmentation only occurred at 17,000 and 35,000 Gy. By contrast, non-enzymatic collagen crosslinking was greater than control for all radiation doses (p < 0.001). All results were consistent both for monotonic and cyclic loading conditions. We conclude that the reductions in bone compressive monotonic strength and fatigue life due to ex vivo ionizing radiation are more likely caused by fragmentation of the collagen backbone than any increases in non-enzymatic collagen crosslinks.
Overview: This research provides a clear and important answer to a long-standing question in radiobiology and orthopedics: what causes bone to become brittle after radiation exposure? By irradiating excised mouse vertebrae, this study separates the material effects from cellular responses. It decisively shows that at high doses, it is the fragmentation of the collagen backbone, not the formation of non-enzymatic crosslinks, that leads to a dramatic loss of bone strength and fatigue life. This finding is critical for understanding radiation damage and improving bone graft sterilization techniques.
Summary:
Background: Ionizing radiation, used in radiotherapy and for sterilizing bone grafts, is known to make bone brittle. This embrittlement has been linked to changes in collagen, but it was unclear whether the primary cause was collagen fragmentation or the formation of non-enzymatic crosslinks.

Methods: Excised mouse lumbar vertebrae were subjected to a range of X-ray radiation doses (0, 50, 1,000, 17,000, or 35,000 Gy) to study the effects on the bone material itself, without cellular activity. Researchers then measured collagen fragmentation, non-enzymatic collagen crosslinking, and the bone's mechanical properties under both monotonic (single-load) and cyclic (fatigue) compression.

Results: Monotonic strength was reduced by 50% and 73% at 17,000 and 35,000 Gy, respectively, but was unaffected at lower doses. This trend was consistent with collagen fragmentation, which only occurred at the two highest doses. In contrast, non-enzymatic collagen crosslinking increased at all radiation doses, even those that did not affect strength. The results were consistent for both monotonic strength and fatigue life.

Conclusions: The study concludes that reductions in bone's compressive strength and fatigue life from high-dose ex vivo ionizing radiation are more likely caused by the fragmentation of the collagen backbone than by an increase in non-enzymatic collagen crosslinks. This clarifies the primary mechanism of material degradation in irradiated bone.

Title: Absence of gamma-sarcoglycan alters the response of p70S6 kinase to mechanical perturbation in murine skeletal muscle
Abstract: BackgroundThe dystrophin glycoprotein complex (DGC) is located at the sarcolemma of muscle fibers, providing structural integrity. Mutations in and loss of DGC proteins cause a spectrum of muscular dystrophies. When only the sarcoglycan subcomplex is absent, muscles display severe myofiber degeneration, but little susceptibility to contractile damage, suggesting that disease occurs not by structural deficits but through aberrant signaling, namely, loss of normal mechanotransduction signaling through the sarcoglycan complex. We extended our previous studies on mechanosensitive, γ-sarcoglycan-dependent ERK1/2 phosphorylation, to determine whether additional pathways are altered with the loss of γ-sarcoglycan. MethodsWe examined mechanotransduction in the presence and absence of γ-sarcoglycan, using C2C12 myotubes, and primary cultures and isolated muscles from C57Bl/6 (C57) and γ-sarcoglycan-null (γ-SG-/-) mice. All were subjected to cyclic passive stretch. Signaling protein phosphorylation was determined by immunoblotting of lysates from stretched and non-stretched samples. Calcium dependence was assessed by maintaining muscles in calcium-free or tetracaine-supplemented Ringer’s solution. Dependence on mTOR was determined by stretching isolated muscles in the presence or absence of rapamycin. ResultsC2C12 myotube stretch caused a robust increase in P-p70S6K, but decreased P-FAK and P-ERK2. Neither Akt nor ERK1 were responsive to passive stretch. Similar but non-significant trends were observed in C57 primary cultures in response to stretch, and γ-SG-/- cultures displayed no p70S6K response. In contrast, in isolated muscles, p70S6K was mechanically responsive. Basal p70S6K activation was elevated in muscles of γ-SG-/- mice, in a calcium-independent manner. p70S6K activation increased with stretch in both C57 and γ-SG-/- isolated muscles, and was sustained in γ-SG-/- muscles, unlike the transient response in C57 muscles. Rapamycin treatment blocked all of p70S6K activation in stretched C57 muscles, and reduced downstream S6RP phosphorylation. However, even though rapamycin treatment decreased p70S6K activation in stretched γ-SG-/- muscles, S6RP phosphorylation remained elevated. Conclusionsp70S6K is an important component of γ-sarcoglycan-dependent mechanotransduction in skeletal muscle. Our results suggest that loss of γ-sarcoglycan uncouples the response of p70S6K to stretch and implies that γ-sarcoglycan is important for inactivation of this pathway. Overall, we assert that altered load-sensing mechanisms exist in muscular dystrophies where the sarcoglycans are absent.
Conclusion: We have identified p70S6K as part of a novel SG-dependent mechanosensitive signaling pathway in skeletal muscle. Our results suggest that γ-SG is required for the inactivation of p70S6K following its activation in response to mechanical stimulation. These studies provide new insights into the normal function of the SG complex, and the mechanisms by which its deficiency in some forms of muscular dystrophy may contribute to pathology.
Overview: This study offers significant new insights into the molecular basis of certain muscular dystrophies by investigating mechanotransduction—how muscle cells sense and respond to physical forces. Researchers identified the signaling protein p70S6K as a key component of a pathway dependent on γ-sarcoglycan, a protein absent in some forms of the disease. The findings suggest that the loss of γ-sarcoglycan uncouples the normal response of p70S6K to mechanical stretch, leading to aberrant signaling that may contribute to muscle degeneration.
Summary:
Background: The dystrophin glycoprotein complex (DGC) provides structural integrity to muscle fibers. The absence of the sarcoglycan (SG) subcomplex within the DGC causes severe muscular dystrophy, believed to result from aberrant signaling rather than structural failure. This study investigated how the loss of γ-sarcoglycan affects mechanosensitive signaling pathways in muscle.

Methods: The study used C2C12 myotubes, primary muscle cultures, and isolated muscles from both normal (C57) and γ-sarcoglycan-null (γ-SG-/-) mice. These samples were subjected to cyclic passive stretch. The phosphorylation (activation) of various signaling proteins, including p70S6K, was measured by immunoblotting. The roles of calcium and the mTOR pathway were assessed using inhibitors.

Results: Passive stretch activated p70S6K in normal muscle cells and tissues. In isolated muscles from γ-SG-/- mice, the basal activation of p70S6K was already elevated. While stretch further increased p70S6K activation in both genotypes, the response was sustained in γ-SG-/- muscles, unlike the transient response in normal muscles. Furthermore, downstream signaling from p70S6K remained elevated in stretched γ-SG-/- muscles even when the mTOR pathway was blocked with rapamycin.

Conclusions: The study identifies p70S6K as a key part of a novel γ-sarcoglycan-dependent mechanosensitive signaling pathway. The results suggest that γ-sarcoglycan is crucial for the proper inactivation of this pathway following mechanical stimulation. Its absence leads to an uncoupled and sustained activation, which may contribute to the pathology of muscular dystrophies where sarcoglycans are deficient.

Title: AtRabD2b and AtRabD2c have overlapping functions in pollen development and pollen tube growth.
Abstract: BackgroundRab GTPases are important regulators of endomembrane trafficking, regulating exocytosis, endocytosis and membrane recycling. Many Rab-like proteins exist in plants, but only a subset have been functionally characterized. ResultsHere we report that AtRabD2b and AtRabD2c play important roles in pollen development, germination and tube elongation. AtrabD2b and AtrabD2c single mutants have no obvious morphological changes compared with wild-type plants across a variety of growth conditions. An AtrabD2b/2c double mutant is also indistinguishable from wild-type plants during vegetative growth; however its siliques are shorter than those in wild-type plants. Compared with wild-type plants, AtrabD2b/2c mutants produce deformed pollen with swollen and branched pollen tube tips. The shorter siliques in the AtrabD2b/2c double mutant were found to be primarily due to the pollen defects. AtRabD2b and AtRabD2c have different but overlapping expression patterns, and they are both highly expressed in pollen. Both AtRabD2b and AtRabD2c protein localize to Golgi bodies. ConclusionsThese findings support a partially redundant role for AtRabD2b and AtRabD2c in vesicle trafficking during pollen tube growth that cannot be fulfilled by the remaining AtRabD family members.
Conclusion: In summary, we used a T-DNA insertion mutant approach to demonstrate the function of AtRabD2b and AtRabD2c. Our data indicated that both are Golgi residents; they have similar but not identical expression patterns, but are both highly expressed in pollen; they are both involved in tip growth of pollen tubes; and they are at least partially functionally redundant. Future work will focus on elucidating the molecular basis for the pollen phenotype in the AtrabD2b/2c double mutant.
Overview: This research in plant biology identifies the crucial and overlapping roles of two specific proteins, AtRabD2b and AtRabD2c, in pollen development and fertilization. By studying mutant Arabidopsis plants, the authors demonstrate that while the loss of one protein has no effect, the loss of both leads to deformed pollen and defective pollen tube growth, resulting in reduced fertility. This study clarifies the function of these Golgi-localized Rab GTPases in vesicle trafficking, a fundamental process for plant reproduction.
Summary:
Background: Rab GTPases are key regulators of vesicle trafficking (exocytosis, endocytosis) in cells. While many Rab-like proteins exist in plants, the specific functions of most are unknown. This study aimed to characterize the roles of AtRabD2b and AtRabD2c in Arabidopsis.

Methods: The researchers created and analyzed single and double knockout mutants for the AtrabD2b and AtrabD2c genes. They observed the plants' vegetative growth, reproductive success (silique length), and pollen morphology. Protein localization was determined, and expression patterns were analyzed to understand where the proteins function.

Results: Single mutants for either gene showed no obvious defects. However, the AtrabD2b/2c double mutant, while appearing normal during vegetative growth, had shorter siliques (seed pods). This was found to be due to pollen defects; the double mutant produced deformed pollen that resulted in swollen and branched pollen tubes, hindering fertilization. Both proteins were found to be localized to the Golgi apparatus and were highly expressed in pollen.

Conclusions: The findings support a partially redundant role for AtRabD2b and AtRabD2c in the vesicle trafficking required for proper pollen development and pollen tube growth. The loss of both proteins disrupts this process in a way that other members of the AtRabD family cannot compensate for, highlighting their specific importance in plant reproduction.

Title: TNO1 is involved in salt tolerance and vacuolar trafficking in Arabidopsis.
Abstract: The Arabidopsis (Arabidopsis thaliana) soluble N-ethylmaleimide-sensitive factor attachment protein receptor SYP41 is involved in vesicle fusion at the trans-Golgi network (TGN) and interacts with AtVPS45, SYP61, and VTI12. These proteins are involved in diverse cellular processes, including vacuole biogenesis and stress tolerance. A previously uncharacterized protein, named TNO1 (for TGN-localized SYP41-interacting protein), was identified by coimmunoprecipitation as a SYP41-interacting protein. TNO1 was found to localize to the TGN by immunofluorescence microscopy. A tno1 mutant showed increased sensitivity to high concentrations of NaCl, KCl, and LiCl and also to mannitol-induced osmotic stress. Localization of SYP61, which is involved in the salt stress response, was disrupted in the tno1 mutant. Vacuolar proteins were partially secreted to the apoplast in the tno1 mutant, suggesting that TNO1 is required for efficient protein trafficking to the vacuole. The tno1 mutant had delayed formation of the brefeldin A (BFA) compartment in cotyledons upon application of BFA, suggesting less efficient membrane fusion processes in the mutant. Unlike most TGN proteins, TNO1 does not relocate to the BFA compartment upon BFA treatment. These data demonstrate that TNO1 is involved in vacuolar trafficking and salt tolerance, potentially via roles in vesicle fusion and in maintaining TGN structure or identity.
Overview: This paper identifies a previously uncharacterized protein, TNO1, and establishes its critical role in plant stress tolerance and intracellular trafficking. Researchers found that TNO1 interacts with the vesicle fusion machinery at the trans-Golgi Network (TGN) in Arabidopsis. Mutants lacking TNO1 were hypersensitive to salt stress and showed defects in transporting proteins to the vacuole. This work provides new insights into how the TGN maintains its structure and function to support essential processes like nutrient storage and stress response in plants.
Summary:
Background: In plant cells, the trans-Golgi network (TGN) is a central hub for sorting and transporting proteins. The protein SYP41 is involved in vesicle fusion at the TGN and is linked to vacuole formation and stress tolerance. This study aimed to identify and characterize new proteins that interact with SYP41.

Methods: Researchers used coimmunoprecipitation to identify proteins that bind to SYP41 and discovered a new protein they named TNO1. They determined its location in the cell using immunofluorescence microscopy. A tno1 knockout mutant was created and tested for its sensitivity to high salt (NaCl, KCl, LiCl) and osmotic stress (mannitol). Vacuolar protein trafficking and the effects of the drug Brefeldin A (BFA), which disrupts the TGN, were also examined.

Results: TNO1 was found to be localized to the TGN. The tno1 mutant showed increased sensitivity to both salt and osmotic stress. In the mutant, vacuolar proteins were incorrectly secreted outside the cell, indicating a defect in vacuolar trafficking. The formation of the Brefeldin A compartment was delayed, suggesting less efficient membrane fusion. Interestingly, TNO1 itself did not relocate to the BFA compartment, unlike most other TGN proteins.

Conclusions: The study demonstrates that TNO1 is a TGN-localized protein involved in both vacuolar trafficking and salt tolerance in Arabidopsis. It may function by participating in vesicle fusion processes and helping to maintain the structure or identity of the TGN.

Title: Functional redundancy between trans-Golgi network SNARE family members in Arabidopsis thaliana.
Abstract: SNAREs play an important role in the process of membrane trafficking. In the present research, we investigated subcellular localization of an uncharacterized Arabidopsis thaliana protein reported to interact with a trans-Golgi network-localized Qa-SNARE, SYNTAXIN OF PLANTS 43. Based on the similarity of its amino acid sequence to metazoan fucosyltransferases, we have named this novel protein AtGTLP (Arabidopsis thaliana GlycosylTransferase-Like Protein) and predicted that it should be a member of yet uncharacterized family of Arabidopsis fucosyltransferases, as it shows no significant sequence similarity to fucosyltransferases previously identified in Arabidopsis. AtGTLP is a membrane-anchored protein, which exhibits a type II-like topology, with a single transmembrane helix and a globular domain in the C-terminal part of its amino acid sequence. Colocalization data we collected suggest that AtGTLP should localize mainly to Golgi apparatus, especially to certain zones of trans-Golgi. As single atgtlp−/− mutants showed no obvious difference in phenotype (primary root length and fresh mass), AtGTLP and proteins related to AtGTLP with high similarity in amino acid sequences may have redundant functions.
Overview: This study provides foundational characterization of a novel, unstudied protein in Arabidopsis thaliana, named AtGTLP, which is predicted to be a new type of fucosyltransferase. Researchers determined that this membrane-anchored protein is located primarily in the Golgi apparatus, a key organelle for protein modification and sorting. Although a single knockout mutant showed no obvious phenotype, suggesting functional redundancy, this work identifies a new family of proteins potentially involved in glycosylation and membrane trafficking, crucial processes for plant cell function.
Summary:
Background: Soluble N-ethylmaleimide-sensitive factor attachment protein receptors (SNAREs) are essential for membrane trafficking. This research focused on characterizing a novel Arabidopsis protein that was reported to interact with a trans-Golgi network-localized SNARE, suggesting a role in this pathway.

Methods: The researchers investigated the subcellular localization of the uncharacterized protein, which they named AtGTLP (Arabidopsis thaliana GlycosylTransferase-Like Protein) based on its sequence similarity to metazoan fucosyltransferases. They analyzed its predicted protein structure and topology. Colocalization studies were performed to pinpoint its location within the cell. Additionally, they created and observed single atgtlp knockout mutants to assess for any visible changes in phenotype, such as primary root length and fresh mass.

Results: AtGTLP was identified as a membrane-anchored protein with a type II-like topology. Colocalization data indicated that it resides mainly in the Golgi apparatus, particularly in the trans-Golgi regions. However, the single knockout mutants did not show any obvious differences in root length or mass compared to wild-type plants.

Conclusions: The lack of an obvious phenotype in the single mutant suggests that AtGTLP and its related proteins likely have redundant functions in the cell. This research lays the groundwork for future studies into this newly identified family of putative fucosyltransferases and their role in Golgi-mediated processes like glycosylation and membrane trafficking.

Title: Root growth movements: Waving and skewing.
Abstract: BackgroundThe movement of plant roots within the soil is key to their ability to interact with the environment and maximize anchorage and nutrient acquisition. Directional growth of roots occurs by a combination of sensing external cues, hormonal signaling and cytoskeletal changes in the root cells. Roots growing on slanted, impenetrable growth medium display a characteristic waving and skewing, and mutants with deviations in these phenotypes assist in identifying genes required for root movement. Our study identifies a role for a trans-Golgi network-localized protein in root skewing. ResultsWe found that Arabidopsis thaliana TNO1 (TGN-localized SYP41-interacting protein), a putative tethering factor localized at the trans-Golgi network, affects root skewing. tno1 knockout mutants display enhanced root skewing and epidermal cell file rotation. Skewing of tno1 roots increases upon microtubule stabilization, but is insensitive to microtubule destabilization. Microtubule destabilization leads to severe defects in cell morphology in tno1 seedlings. Microtubule array orientation is unaffected in the mutant roots, suggesting that the increase in cell file rotation is independent of the orientation of microtubule arrays. ConclusionsWe conclude that TNO1 modulates root skewing in a mechanism that is dependent on microtubules but is not linked to disruption of the orientation of microtubule arrays. In addition, TNO1 is required for maintenance of cell morphology in mature regions of roots and the base of hypocotyls. The TGN-localized SNARE machinery might therefore be important for appropriate epidermal cell file rotation and cell expansion during root growth.
Conclusion: In conclusion, we have discovered a role for a TGN-localized protein in root skewing on the surface of impenetrable media. This adds to the growing list of endogenous factors that aid root movement. Our data, alongside prior investigations, also suggest a possible link between TNO1, auxin-dependent and MT-associated processes. A better understanding of these mechanisms can lead to information that can be used to manipulate root growth and development patterns in various soil conditions and improve overall root architecture. This could subsequently result in engineering superior crops with better soil penetration and nutrient assimilation traits.
Overview: This study uncovers a new molecular player, TNO1, in the complex process of root growth and movement, making it important for plant biologists and agricultural scientists. Researchers found that this protein, located at the trans-Golgi network, influences how Arabidopsis roots skew and twist when growing on a hard surface. The findings link intracellular trafficking machinery to microtubule-dependent root directional growth, providing insights that could ultimately be used to engineer crops with improved soil penetration and nutrient uptake.
Summary:
Background: The movement and directional growth of plant roots are crucial for anchorage and nutrient acquisition. This process involves sensing environmental cues and making cellular changes. The characteristic waving and skewing of roots on slanted surfaces provide a model system to identify genes involved in root movement.

Methods: The study focused on Arabidopsis thaliana TNO1, a protein localized at the trans-Golgi network (TGN). The researchers analyzed the root skewing and epidermal cell file rotation phenotypes of tno1 knockout mutants. They also treated the mutants with microtubule-stabilizing and -destabilizing drugs to investigate the link between TNO1 and the cytoskeleton. Microtubule array orientation was observed to see if it was affected.

Results: tno1 knockout mutants displayed enhanced root skewing and twisting of epidermal cell files. The skewing phenotype was exacerbated by a microtubule-stabilizing drug but was insensitive to a destabilizing drug. While microtubule destabilization caused severe cell morphology defects, the orientation of microtubule arrays in the mutant roots was not affected.

Conclusions: The study concludes that TNO1 modulates root skewing through a mechanism that depends on microtubules but is not linked to the overall orientation of microtubule arrays. TNO1 is also required for maintaining proper cell shape in mature root regions. This suggests that the TGN-localized SNARE machinery, which TNO1 is part of, plays a significant role in cell expansion and directional root growth.

Title: Gravitropism and lateral root emergence are dependent on the trans-Golgi network protein TNO1
Abstract: The trans-Golgi network (TGN) is a dynamic organelle that functions as a relay station for receiving endocytosed cargo, directing secretory cargo, and trafficking to the vacuole. TGN-localized SYP41-interacting protein (TNO1) is a large, TGN-localized, coiled-coil protein that associates with the membrane fusion protein SYP41, a target SNARE, and is required for efficient protein trafficking to the vacuole. Here, we show that a tno1 mutant has auxin transport-related defects. Mutant roots have delayed lateral root emergence, decreased gravitropic bending of plant organs and increased sensitivity to the auxin analog 2,4-dichlorophenoxyacetic acid and the natural auxin 3-indoleacetic acid. Auxin asymmetry at the tips of elongating stage II lateral roots was reduced in the tno1 mutant, suggesting a role for TNO1 in cellular auxin transport during lateral root emergence. During gravistimulation, tno1 roots exhibited delayed auxin transport from the columella to the basal epidermal cells. Endocytosis to the TGN was unaffected in the mutant, indicating that bulk endocytic defects are not responsible for the observed phenotypes. Together these studies demonstrate a role for TNO1 in mediating auxin responses during root development and gravistimulation, potentially through trafficking of auxin transport proteins.
Overview: This paper reveals a new and important function for the protein TNO1 in regulating plant growth and development by linking it to auxin transport. Researchers demonstrate that TNO1, located at the trans-Golgi network (TGN), is essential for proper root gravitropism and the emergence of lateral roots in Arabidopsis. The findings suggest that efficient intracellular trafficking at the TGN is critical for mediating auxin-driven responses, providing a deeper understanding of how plants orient themselves and shape their root systems.
Summary:
Background: The trans-Golgi network (TGN) is a key cellular hub for protein and membrane trafficking. TNO1 is a TGN-localized protein known to be required for efficient protein transport to the vacuole. This study aimed to investigate if TNO1 has a role in processes related to auxin, a critical plant hormone for development.

Methods: The researchers analyzed an Arabidopsis tno1 mutant for defects related to auxin transport. They measured the timing of lateral root emergence, the gravitropic bending of roots, and the plant's sensitivity to natural and synthetic auxins. Auxin distribution in lateral root tips was visualized, and auxin transport during a gravity stimulus was assessed. Endocytosis was also measured to rule out general defects in this process.

Results: The tno1 mutant exhibited delayed lateral root emergence, decreased gravitropic bending in roots, and increased sensitivity to auxin. During lateral root development and gravistimulation, the normal asymmetric distribution of auxin was disrupted in the mutant roots. However, general endocytosis to the TGN was found to be unaffected.

Conclusions: The study demonstrates that TNO1 plays a role in mediating auxin-dependent responses, including lateral root development and gravitropism. The defects observed in the tno1 mutant are likely caused by impaired trafficking of auxin transport proteins, rather than a general endocytic defect, highlighting the importance of the TGN in regulating plant growth.

Title: The Drosophila SUN protein Spag4 cooperates with the coiled-coil protein Yuri Gagarin to maintain association of the basal body and spermatid nucleus.
Abstract: Maintaining the proximity of centrosomes to nuclei is important in several cellular contexts, and LINC complexes formed by SUN and KASH proteins are crucial in this process. Here, we characterize the presumed Drosophila ortholog of the mammalian SUN protein, sperm-associated antigen 4 (Spag4, previously named Giacomo), and demonstrate that Spag4 is required for centriole and nuclear attachment during spermatogenesis. Production of spag4 mRNA is limited to the testis, and Spag4 protein shows a dynamic pattern of association with the germline nuclei, including a concentration of protein at the site of attachment of the single spermatid centriole. In the absence of Spag4, nuclei and centrioles or basal bodies (BBs) dissociate from each other after meiosis. This role of Spag4 in centriolar attachment does not involve either of the two KASH proteins of the Drosophila genome (Klarsicht and MSP-300), but does require the coiled-coil protein Yuri Gagarin. Yuri shows an identical pattern of localization at the nuclear surface to Spag4 during spermatogenesis, and epistasis studies show that the activities of Yuri and dynein-dynactin are downstream of spag4 in this centriole attachment pathway. The later defects in spermatogenesis seen for yuri and spag4 mutants are similar, suggesting they could be secondary to initial disruption of events at the nuclear surface.
Overview: This paper identifies a crucial molecular partnership required for male fertility in Drosophila, providing key insights into the mechanics of sperm development. Researchers demonstrate that the SUN protein Spag4 and the coiled-coil protein Yuri Gagarin work together to anchor the centriole (which becomes the sperm's basal body) to the nucleus during spermatogenesis. The study clarifies that this essential connection is independent of the known KASH proteins, revealing a novel pathway for maintaining nuclear-centrosomal proximity in a vital cellular process.
Summary:
Background: The attachment of centrosomes to the nucleus is a critical process in many cells, often mediated by LINC complexes composed of SUN and KASH proteins. This study investigated this process during sperm development (spermatogenesis) in the fruit fly, Drosophila.

Methods: The researchers characterized the Drosophila ortholog of the mammalian SUN protein Spag4. They analyzed its expression pattern and localization within the testis. They created spag4 mutant flies and observed the effects on the attachment of centrioles and basal bodies (BBs) to the nucleus after meiosis. The involvement of known KASH proteins (Klarsicht, MSP-300) and the protein Yuri Gagarin was investigated through genetic and localization studies.

Results: Spag4 protein was found to be concentrated at the site where the spermatid centriole attaches to the nucleus. In the absence of Spag4, the nuclei and centrioles/basal bodies dissociated from each other after meiosis. This function did not require the known Drosophila KASH proteins. Instead, it required the protein Yuri Gagarin, which showed an identical localization pattern to Spag4. Further experiments suggested that Yuri Gagarin acts downstream of Spag4 in this centriole attachment pathway.

Conclusions: The abstract suggests that the Drosophila SUN protein Spag4 cooperates with the coiled-coil protein Yuri Gagarin in a novel pathway to maintain the crucial connection between the basal body and the nucleus during sperm development. The similar defects seen in both yuri and spag4 mutants indicate they function together, with the later-stage problems in spermatogenesis likely being a secondary consequence of the initial failure of this attachment.

Title: Toll mediated infection response is altered by gravity and spaceflight in Drosophila
Abstract: Space travel presents unlimited opportunities for exploration and discovery, but requires better understanding of the biological consequences of long-term exposure to spaceflight. Immune function in particular is relevant for space travel. Human immune responses are weakened in space, with increased vulnerability to opportunistic infections and immune-related conditions. In addition, microorganisms can become more virulent in space, causing further challenges to health. To understand these issues better and to contribute to design of effective countermeasures, we used the Drosophila model of innate immunity to study immune responses in both hypergravity and spaceflight. Focusing on infections mediated through the conserved Toll and Imd signaling pathways, we found that hypergravity improves resistance to Toll-mediated fungal infections except in a known gravitaxis mutant of the yuri gagarin gene. These results led to the first spaceflight project on Drosophila immunity, in which flies that developed to adulthood in microgravity were assessed for immune responses by transcription profiling on return to Earth. Spaceflight alone altered transcription, producing activation of the heat shock stress system. Space flies subsequently infected by fungus failed to activate the Toll pathway. In contrast, bacterial infection produced normal activation of the Imd pathway. We speculate on possible linkage between functional Toll signaling and the heat shock chaperone system. Our major findings are that hypergravity and spaceflight have opposing effects, and that spaceflight produces stress-related transcriptional responses and results in a specific inability to mount a Toll-mediated infection response.
Overview: This study provides compelling evidence that altered gravity environments directly impact the innate immune system, making it a critical read for space medicine. Using the Drosophila model, researchers found that hypergravity enhances resistance to fungal infections, while spaceflight has the opposite effect. Most notably, flies that developed in microgravity were unable to activate the conserved Toll signaling pathway to fight fungal infection upon return to Earth. This specific impairment highlights a key vulnerability that could affect astronaut health on long-duration missions.
Summary:
Background: Human immune responses are known to be weakened in space, increasing vulnerability to infections. To better understand the biological mechanisms, this study used the fruit fly, Drosophila, as a model for innate immunity to investigate immune responses in both hypergravity and spaceflight.

Methods: The study focused on the conserved Toll and Imd immune signaling pathways. Flies were subjected to hypergravity and their resistance to Toll-mediated fungal infections was measured. In a separate spaceflight experiment, flies developed to adulthood in microgravity on the ISS. Upon their return to Earth, their immune responses were assessed by transcription profiling after being infected with either fungus (to test the Toll pathway) or bacteria (to test the Imd pathway).

Results: Hypergravity improved resistance to fungal infections, an effect that was absent in a gravitaxis mutant. Conversely, spaceflight had a detrimental effect. Flies that developed in microgravity showed activation of heat shock stress genes. When these space-flown flies were subsequently infected with a fungus, they failed to activate the Toll pathway. In contrast, their response to bacterial infection via the Imd pathway was normal.

Conclusions: The study's major findings are that hypergravity and spaceflight have opposing effects on the Drosophila immune system. Spaceflight induces stress-related transcriptional changes and specifically impairs the ability to mount a Toll-mediated immune response against fungal infection, while leaving the Imd pathway intact.

Title: Multi-omics analysis of multiple missions to space reveal a theme of lipid dysregulation in mouse liver
Abstract: Not found
Overview: This research is significant for understanding the long-term health risks of space travel, as it identifies a consistent pattern of lipid dysregulation in the livers of mice across multiple space missions. By integrating multi-omics data (genomics, transcriptomics, etc.), the study establishes that altered lipid metabolism is a recurring theme in response to spaceflight. This finding points to a fundamental biological response to the space environment and suggests that liver health could be a key area of concern for astronauts on long-duration missions.
Summary:
Background: The abstract for this study was not found in the provided data, so the background is inferred from the title. The study likely aimed to investigate the molecular effects of spaceflight on the liver by analyzing and integrating data from multiple space missions involving mice.

Methods: The abstract for this study was not found. The title suggests a multi-omics analysis, which would involve integrating data from transcriptomics (gene expression), proteomics (proteins), and/or metabolomics (metabolites) from mouse liver samples collected during various space missions.

Results: The abstract for this study was not found. The title indicates that the analysis revealed a consistent theme of lipid dysregulation in the mouse liver across the different missions studied.

Conclusions: The abstract and conclusion for this study were not found. Based on the title, the conclusion is likely that spaceflight consistently induces changes in lipid metabolism pathways in the mouse liver, highlighting a common biological response that could have implications for astronaut health.

Title: GeneLab database analyses suggest long-term impact of space radiation on the cardiovascular system by the activation of FYN through reactive oxygen species.
Abstract: Space radiation has recently been considered a risk factor for astronauts’ cardiac health. As an example, for the case of how to query and identify datasets within NASA’s GeneLab database and demonstrate the database utility, we used an unbiased systems biology method for identifying key genes/drivers for the contribution of space radiation on the cardiovascular system. This knowledge can contribute to designing appropriate experiments targeting these specific pathways. Microarray data from cardiomyocytes of male C57BL/6 mice followed-up for 28 days after exposure to 900 mGy of 1 GeV proton or 150 mGy of 1 GeV/n 56Fe were compared to human endothelial cells (HUVECs) cultured for 7 days on the International Space Station (ISS). We observed common molecular pathways between simulated space radiation and HUVECs flown on the ISS. The analysis suggests FYN is the central driver/hub for the cardiovascular response to space radiation: the known oxidative stress induced immediately following radiation would only be transient and would upregulate FYN, which in turn would reduce reactive oxygen species (ROS) levels, protecting the cardiovascular system. The transcriptomic signature of exposure to protons was also much closer to the spaceflight signature than 56Fe’s signature. To our knowledge, this is the first time GeneLab datasets were utilized to provide potential biological indications that the majority of ions on the ISS are protons, clearly illustrating the power of omics analysis. More generally, this work also demonstrates how to combine animal radiation studies done on the ground and spaceflight studies to evaluate human risk in space.
Overview: This paper is a compelling demonstration of the power of open-data systems like NASA's GeneLab for generating new hypotheses about space health risks. By analyzing and comparing disparate datasets—cardiomyocytes from mice exposed to simulated space radiation and endothelial cells flown on the ISS—researchers identified a common molecular pathway centered on the gene FYN. This suggests FYN is a key driver in the cardiovascular response to space radiation, potentially by regulating oxidative stress. The work provides a strong rationale for targeted experiments and showcases how data mining can accelerate our understanding of spaceflight effects.
Summary:
Background: Space radiation is a recognized risk factor for astronaut cardiovascular health. This study used an unbiased systems biology approach on datasets from NASA's GeneLab database to identify key genes and pathways involved in the cardiovascular response to space radiation, which could guide future experiments.
