Abstract: MscL is a bacterial mechanosensitive channel that protects cells from lysis upon acute decrease in external osmotic environment. It is one of the best characterized mechanosensors known, thus serving as a paradigm of how such molecules sense and respond to stimuli. In addition, the fact that it can be genetically modified, expressed, isolated, and manipulated has led to its proposed use as a triggered nanovalve for various functions including sensors within microelectronic array chips, as well as vesicular-based targeted drug release. X-ray crystallography reveals a homo-pentameric complex with each subunit containing two transmembrane α-helices (TM1 and TM2) and a single carboxyl terminal α-helix arranging within the complex to form a five-fold cytoplasmic bundle (CB), whose function and stability remain unclear. In this study, we show three routes that throttle the open channel conductance. When the linker between the TM2 and CB domain is shortened by deletions or constrained by either cross linking or heavy metal coordination, the conductance of the channel is reduced; in later two cases, even reversibly. While having implications for the stability of the CB, these data also provide routes for engineering MscL sensors that are more versatile for potential nanotech devices.
Overview: This research is significant for the field of nanotechnology and biosensor development, as it details three distinct methods for precisely controlling the pore size of the MscL bacterial channel. By modifying the linker region between two key domains through deletions, cross-linking, or metal coordination, the authors demonstrate the ability to throttle the channel's conductance. This engineering capability, including reversible control, makes MscL a more versatile and tunable component for advanced nanodevices like targeted drug-release systems and microelectronic sensors.
Summary:
Background: The MscL bacterial mechanosensitive channel has been proposed for use as a triggered nanovalve in various nanotechnologies. A key feature for such applications is the ability to control its pore size, or conductance. The channel's crystal structure shows a cytoplasmic bundle (CB) whose function and stability are not fully understood.

Methods: The researchers explored three different routes to modulate the channel's conductance. They genetically engineered the MscL channel by: 1) shortening the linker between the transmembrane domain (TM2) and the cytoplasmic bundle (CB) through deletions, 2) constraining the linker by introducing cross-links, and 3) constraining the linker using heavy metal coordination.

Results: All three methods were successful in reducing the open channel conductance. Shortening or constraining the linker region effectively throttled the pore size. Importantly, the methods involving cross-linking and heavy metal coordination allowed for reversible control over the conductance. These findings also provided insights into the stability of the cytoplasmic bundle.

Conclusions: The study successfully demonstrates three distinct routes for tuning the pore size of the MscL nanovalve. This provides valuable engineering strategies for creating more versatile MscL-based sensors and devices for nanotech applications.

Title: The dynamics of protein-protein interactions between domains of MscL at the cytoplasmic-lipid interface
Abstract: The bacterial mechanosensitive channel of large conductance, MscL, is one of the best characterized mechanosensitive channels serving as a paradigm for how proteins can sense and transduce mechanical forces. The physiological role of MscL is that of an emergency release valve that opens a large pore upon a sudden drop in the osmolarity of the environment. A crystal structure of a closed state of MscL shows it as a homopentamer, with each subunit consisting of two transmembrane domains (TM). There is consensus that the TM helices move in an iris like manner tilting in the plane of the membrane while gating. An N-terminal amphipathic helix that lies along the cytoplasmic membrane (S1), and the portion of TM2 near the cytoplasmic interface (TM2ci), are relatively close in the crystal structure, yet predicted to be dynamic upon gating. Here we determine how these two regions interact in the channel complex, and study how these interactions change as the channel opens. We have screened 143 double-cysteine mutants of E. coli MscL for their efficiency in disulfide bridging and generated a map of protein-protein interactions between these two regions. Interesting candidates have been further studied by patch clamp and show differences in channel activity under different redox potentials; the results suggest a model for the dynamics of these two domains during MscL gating.
Overview: This study provides a detailed map of the dynamic protein-protein interactions within the MscL mechanosensitive channel, a key model for understanding how cells sense physical forces. Using a systematic disulfide bridging approach, researchers charted the changing interactions between two crucial domains at the cytoplasmic-lipid interface as the channel opens and closes. This work is important because it offers a glimpse into the molecular mechanics of channel gating, revealing how different parts of the protein move and interact to form a large pore in response to membrane tension.
Summary:
Background: The MscL channel opens a large pore in response to membrane tension. Its structure in the closed state is known, but the dynamic movements of its domains during gating are less understood. Two regions, an N-terminal helix (S1) and a portion of the second transmembrane helix (TM2ci), are close in the crystal structure and predicted to move during opening. This study aimed to map their interactions.

Methods: The researchers used a double-cysteine mutant screening approach. They created 143 different versions of E. coli MscL, each with two cysteine residues at specific positions in the S1 and TM2ci domains. By testing the efficiency of disulfide bridging between these cysteines, they could map which parts of the domains come into close contact. Promising candidates were further studied using patch-clamp electrophysiology to see how redox potential (which controls disulfide bonds) affected channel activity.

Results: The screening generated a map of protein-protein interactions between the S1 and TM2ci domains. Electrophysiological studies on selected mutants showed that their channel activity was altered by different redox potentials, confirming that the engineered disulfide bridges could lock the channel in certain conformations. These results allowed the researchers to model the dynamic movements of these domains during gating.

Conclusions: The study successfully mapped the interactions between the S1 and TM2ci domains and provided a model for their dynamic changes during MscL channel gating. This detailed understanding of the protein's mechanics contributes significantly to our knowledge of how mechanosensitive channels function.

Title: The MscS and MscL families of mechanosensitive channels act as microbial emergency release valves
Abstract: Single-celled organisms must survive exposure to environmental extremes. Perhaps one of the most variable and potentially life-threatening changes that can occur is that of a rapid and acute decrease in external osmolarity. This easily translates into several atmospheres of additional pressure that can build up within the cell. Without a protective mechanism against such pressures, the cell will lyse. Hence, most microbes appear to possess members of one or both families of bacterial mechanosensitive channels, MscS and MscL, which can act as biological emergency release valves that allow cytoplasmic solutes to be jettisoned rapidly from the cell. While this is undoubtedly a function of these proteins, the discovery of the presence of MscS homologues in plant organelles and MscL in fungus and mycoplasma genomes may complicate this simplistic interpretation of the physiology underlying these proteins. Here we compare and contrast these two mechanosensitive channel families, discuss their potential physiological roles, and review some of the most relevant data that underlie the current models for their structure and function.
Overview: This review provides an essential overview of the MscS and MscL families of mechanosensitive channels, which act as crucial 'emergency release valves' in most microbes. It contrasts the structure and function of these two key channel types, which protect cells from bursting under osmotic stress. The paper is valuable for microbiologists and cell biologists as it not only summarizes their primary physiological role but also discusses the complexities arising from their discovery in a wider range of organisms, including plants and fungi, suggesting their functions may be more diverse than previously thought.
Summary:
Background: Single-celled organisms need mechanisms to survive rapid decreases in external osmolarity, which can cause them to burst. Most microbes possess one or both of two families of mechanosensitive channels, MscS and MscL, that act as emergency release valves to jettison solutes and relieve internal pressure.

Methods: This is a review article. The authors compare and contrast the MscS and MscL channel families, drawing on existing literature. They discuss the current models for their structure, function, and physiological roles.

Results: The review summarizes that MscS and MscL are the primary defense against osmotic downshock in microbes. It also notes that the discovery of MscS homologs in plant organelles and MscL in fungi and mycoplasma complicates the simple interpretation of their function, suggesting they may have other physiological roles beyond being just emergency release valves.

Conclusions: The review provides a comprehensive look at the two major families of bacterial mechanosensitive channels. It highlights their critical role as emergency release valves while also pointing to emerging evidence that suggests their functions may be more varied and complex across different domains of life.

Title: Chimeras reveal a single lipid-interface residue that controls MscL channel kinetics as well as mechanosensitivity
Abstract: Summary MscL, the highly conserved bacterial mechanosensitive channel of large conductance, functionally serves as an osmotic “emergency release valve”, is among the best studied mechanosensors and a paradigm of how a channel senses and responds to membrane tension. While all homologues tested thus far encode channel activity, many show functional differences. Here we tested E. coli and S aureus chimeras and find that the periplasmic region of the protein, particularly E. coli I49 and the equivalent S aureus F47 at the periplasmic lipid-aqueous interface of the first transmembrane domain, drastically influences both the open dwell time and threshold of channel opening. One mutant shows a severe hysteresis, confirming the importance of this residue in determining the energy barriers for channel gating. We propose that this site acts similar to a spring for a clasp knife, adjusting the resistance for obtaining and stabilizing an open or closed channel structure.
Overview: This study pinpoints a single amino acid residue at the lipid-water interface that acts as a critical control point for the MscL mechanosensitive channel's function. By creating chimeras of E. coli and S. aureus channels, researchers discovered that this specific residue dramatically influences both how easily the channel opens (threshold) and how long it stays open (kinetics). The finding that this site acts like a 'spring for a clasp knife' provides a powerful new insight into the molecular mechanics of channel gating and protein-lipid interactions.
Summary:
Background: MscL is a highly conserved bacterial mechanosensitive channel that serves as a paradigm for understanding how proteins respond to membrane tension. While all MscL homologs have channel activity, they often show functional differences in their sensitivity and kinetics. This study aimed to identify the structural regions responsible for these differences.

Methods: The researchers created chimeric proteins by swapping different regions between the MscL channels of E. coli and S. aureus. The function of these chimeras was then tested to determine which region controlled the channel's open dwell time and its threshold for opening in response to membrane tension.

Results: The study found that the periplasmic region of the first transmembrane domain, specifically a single residue at the lipid-aqueous interface (I49 in E. coli and F47 in S. aureus), had a drastic influence on both the channel's opening threshold and its kinetics. One mutant at this site exhibited severe hysteresis, confirming the residue's importance in the energy barriers for gating.

Conclusions: The authors propose that this single residue acts like a spring, adjusting the energy required to open the channel and stabilize it in either the open or closed state. This finding reveals a key control mechanism for MscL function and highlights the critical role of specific protein-lipid interface residues in mechanosensitivity.

Title: Tardigrades Use Intrinsically Disordered Proteins to Survive Desiccation.
Abstract: Tardigrades, microscopic animals that survive a broad range of environmental stresses, express a unique set of proteins termed tardigrade-specific intrinsically disordered proteins (TDPs). TDPs are often expressed at high levels in tardigrades upon desiccation, and appear to mediate stress adaptation. Here, we focus on the proteins belonging to the secreted family of tardigrade proteins termed secretory-abundant heat soluble (“SAHS”) proteins, and investigate their ability to protect diverse biological structures. Recombinantly expressed SAHS proteins prevent desiccated liposomes from fusion, and enhance desiccation tolerance of E. coli and Rhizobium tropici upon extracellular application. Molecular dynamics simulation and comparative structural analysis suggest a model by which SAHS proteins may undergo a structural transition upon desiccation, in which removal of water and solutes from a large internal cavity in SAHS proteins destabilizes the beta-sheet structure. These results highlight the potential application of SAHS proteins as stabilizing molecules for preservation of cells.
Overview: This study is crucial for biotechnology and astrobiology, revealing how tardigrade-specific intrinsically disordered proteins (TDPs) protect biological structures from desiccation. It demonstrates that SAHS proteins, a type of TDP, can prevent liposome fusion and enhance bacterial survival when dried. The research proposes a molecular model for how these proteins function, highlighting their potential as powerful stabilizing agents for preserving cells, vaccines, or other biological materials without refrigeration.
Summary:
Background: Tardigrades, known for surviving extreme environmental stresses like dehydration, express unique proteins called tardigrade-specific intrinsically disordered proteins (TDPs). This study focuses on a family of these proteins called SAHS to investigate their ability to protect biological structures from desiccation damage.

Methods: Researchers recombinantly expressed SAHS proteins and tested their protective capabilities. They assessed whether the proteins could prevent desiccated liposomes (artificial cell membranes) from fusing. They also tested if applying SAHS proteins externally could enhance the survival of E. coli and Rhizobium tropici bacteria after desiccation. Molecular dynamics simulations and structural analysis were used to model the protein's behavior upon drying.

Results: The SAHS proteins were highly effective. They prevented desiccated liposomes from fusing together and significantly improved the survival rate of desiccated bacteria. The computer simulations suggest a model where the removal of water causes a structural transition in the SAHS proteins, destabilizing their beta-sheet structure, which is key to their protective function.

Conclusions: The results highlight the potential application of SAHS proteins as stabilizing molecules. They could be used for the preservation of cells, therapeutics, or other biological materials in a dried state, potentially removing the need for cold storage.

Title: The biology of tardigrade disordered proteins in extreme stress tolerance.
Abstract: Anhydrobiosis, a phenomenon in which organisms survive extreme dehydration by entering a reversible ametabolic state, is a remarkable example of survival strategies. This study focuses on anhydrobiosis in tardigrades, which are known for their resilience to severe environmental conditions. Tardigrades utilize several protective mechanisms against desiccation, notably the constitutive expression of cytoplasmic abundant heat soluble (CAHS) proteins in Ramazzottius varieornatus. These proteins share similarities in their amphiphatic alpha helices with late embryogenesis abundant (LEA) proteins, but differ significantly in their amino acid sequences. In this study, we further explored the functionality of CAHS proteins by analyzing their role in aggregation and tolerance to hyperosmotic stress in mammalian cells. Using live cell imaging, we examined the subcellular localization of several CAHS and LEA proteins in response to hyperosmotic stress. The expression of CAHS1, CAHS3, and CAHS8 tended to enhance the resilience to the hyperosmotic conditions. These findings not only deepen our understanding of the molecular mechanisms of anhydrobiosis but also highlight the potential of CAHS proteins as cryoprotectants.
Conclusion: In this study, we expressed R. varieornatus CAHS proteins in HeLa cells to investigate their effects on resistance to hyperosmotic stress, an early step in anhydrobiosis. All of these proteins demonstrated reversible aggregation upon hyperosmotic stress in HeLa cells, exhibiting granular and filamentous structures (Fig. 1). Furthermore, we found that expression of CAHS1, CAHS3, and CAHS8 conferred resistance to sorbitol-induced hyperosmotic stress in HeLa cells (Figs. 2 and 3). These results not only provide new insights into the mechanism of desiccation tolerance in R. varieornatus, but also suggest a potential use of these CAHS proteins as cryoprotectants.
Overview: This study offers valuable insights into the protective mechanisms of tardigrades, with potential applications in cryoprotection and medicine. It investigates how cytoplasmic abundant heat soluble (CAHS) proteins, a type of tardigrade-specific disordered protein, function to protect cells against hyperosmotic stress, a key step in surviving dehydration. By expressing these proteins in human cells, researchers showed they form reversible aggregates and enhance cell resilience, highlighting their potential use as stabilizing agents.
Summary:
Background: Anhydrobiosis is a state of suspended animation that allows organisms like tardigrades to survive extreme dehydration. This process involves protective mechanisms, including the production of cytoplasmic abundant heat soluble (CAHS) proteins. This study aimed to explore the functionality of CAHS proteins in conferring stress tolerance to mammalian cells.

Methods: Researchers expressed several CAHS proteins from the tardigrade Ramazzottius varieornatus in human HeLa cells. Using live-cell imaging, they observed the subcellular localization and aggregation of these proteins in response to hyperosmotic stress induced by sorbitol. The resilience of the cells expressing these proteins was then quantified and compared to control cells.

Results: All the tested CAHS proteins formed reversible aggregates, appearing as granular and filamentous structures within the HeLa cells upon hyperosmotic stress. Importantly, the expression of specific CAHS proteins (CAHS1, CAHS3, and CAHS8) significantly enhanced the cells' resistance to this stress.

Conclusions: The study demonstrates that tardigrade CAHS proteins can function in mammalian cells to confer resistance to hyperosmotic stress, an early stage of anhydrobiosis. This provides new insights into the mechanism of desiccation tolerance and suggests that these proteins have potential applications as cryoprotectants for preserving cells.

Title: Production of reactive oxygen species and involvement of bioprotectants during anhydrobiosis in the tardigrade Paramacrobiotus spatialis
Abstract: Water unavailability is an abiotic stress causing unfavourable conditions for life. Nevertheless, some animals evolved anhydrobiosis, a strategy allowing for the reversible organism dehydration and suspension of metabolism as a direct response to habitat desiccation. Anhydrobiotic animals undergo biochemical changes synthesizing bioprotectants to help combat desiccation stresses. One stress is the generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS). In this study, the eutardigrade Paramacrobiotus spatialis was used to investigate the occurrence of ROS associated with the desiccation process. We observed that the production of ROS significantly increases as a function of time spent in anhydrobiosis and represents a direct demonstration of oxidative stress in tardigrades. The degree of involvement of bioprotectants, including those combating ROS, in the P. spatialis was evaluated by perturbing their gene functions using RNA interference and assessing the successful recovery of animals after desiccation/rehydration. Targeting the glutathione peroxidase gene compromised survival during drying and rehydration, providing evidence for the role of the gene in desiccation tolerance. Targeting genes encoding glutathione reductase and catalase indicated that these molecules play roles during rehydration. Our study also confirms the involvement of aquaporins 3 and 10 during rehydration. Therefore, desiccation tolerance depends on the synergistic action of many different molecules working together.
Overview: This study provides direct evidence of oxidative stress in tardigrades during anhydrobiosis (a state of suspended animation due to dehydration), a critical aspect of their famous survival abilities. Researchers demonstrate that reactive oxygen species (ROS) increase over time in desiccated tardigrades. By using RNA interference to knock down specific antioxidant genes, they show that molecules like glutathione peroxidase are essential for surviving the drying and rehydration process, revealing the synergistic action of multiple bioprotectants.
Summary:
Background: Anhydrobiosis is a survival strategy where organisms reversibly dehydrate. This process involves the synthesis of bioprotectants to combat stresses, one of which is the generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS), or oxidative stress. This study aimed to directly investigate the occurrence of ROS and the role of antioxidant bioprotectants in the tardigrade Paramacrobiotus spatialis during desiccation.

Methods: Researchers measured the production of ROS in P. spatialis as a function of time spent in anhydrobiosis. To evaluate the role of specific bioprotectants, they used RNA interference (RNAi) to perturb the function of genes for glutathione peroxidase, glutathione reductase, and catalase, as well as aquaporins. The survival and successful recovery of these animals after desiccation and rehydration were then assessed.

Results: The study found that ROS production significantly increases the longer a tardigrade spends in anhydrobiosis, providing a direct demonstration of oxidative stress. Targeting the glutathione peroxidase gene compromised the tardigrades' survival during the drying and rehydration process. Targeting glutathione reductase and catalase revealed their roles during the rehydration phase. The study also confirmed the involvement of aquaporins during rehydration.

Conclusions: The abstract suggests that desiccation tolerance in tardigrades is not due to a single mechanism but depends on the synergistic action of many different molecules working together. This includes a crucial role for antioxidant enzymes like glutathione peroxidase in managing the oxidative stress that occurs during anhydrobiosis.

Title: Partial weight suspension: A novel murine model for investigating adaptation to reduced musculoskeletal loading.
Abstract: We developed a new model of hypodynamic loading to support mice in chronic conditions of partial weight bearing, enabling simulations of reduced gravity environments and related clinical conditions. The novel hardware allows for reduced loading between 10 and 80% of normal body weight on all four limbs and enables characteristic quadrupedal locomotion. Ten-week-old female BALB/cByJ mice were supported for 21 days under Mars-analog suspension (38% weight bearing) and compared with age-matched and jacketed (100% weight bearing) controls. After an initial adaptation, weight gain did not differ between groups, suggesting low levels of animal stress. Relative to age-matched controls, mice exposed to Mars-analog loading had significantly lower muscle mass (−23% gastrocnemius wet mass, P < 0.0001); trabecular and cortical bone morphology (i.e., trabecular bone volume: −24% at the distal femur, and cortical thickness: −11% at the femoral midshaft, both P < 0.001); and biomechanical properties of the femoral midshaft (i.e., −27% ultimate moment, P < 0.001). Bone formation indexes were decreased compared with age-matched full-weight-bearing mice, whereas resorption parameters were largely unchanged. Singly housed, full-weight-bearing controls with forelimb jackets were largely similar to age-matched, group-housed controls, although a few variables differed and warrant further investigation. Altogether, these data provide strong rationale for use of our new model of partial weight bearing to further explore the musculoskeletal response to reduced loading environments.
Overview: This paper is essential for space medicine research as it introduces and validates a novel murine model for simulating partial gravity environments like Mars (38% g). The 'Partial Weight Suspension' system allows for chronic, controlled unloading of all four limbs while permitting normal quadrupedal locomotion. The study demonstrates that this Mars-analog loading causes significant muscle atrophy and bone deterioration, providing a robust and much-needed tool for investigating musculoskeletal adaptation to reduced gravity and testing potential countermeasures.
Summary:
Background: To better understand and counteract the musculoskeletal decline seen in astronauts, researchers need reliable animal models that can simulate the reduced gravity environments of the Moon or Mars. This study details the development and validation of a new hardware system for inducing chronic partial weight bearing in mice.

Methods: A novel partial weight suspension (PWS) system was developed to support mice at a tunable percentage of their normal body weight (from 10% to 80%). Ten-week-old female BALB/cByJ mice were suspended for 21 days under a Mars-analog condition (38% weight bearing). Their outcomes were compared to age-matched controls and a jacketed, full-weight-bearing control group. Musculoskeletal health was assessed via muscle mass, micro-CT analysis of trabecular and cortical bone, and biomechanical testing of the femur.

Results: After an initial adaptation period, suspended mice gained weight normally, suggesting low stress levels. Compared to controls, mice in the Mars-analog group had significantly lower gastrocnemius muscle mass (-23%), reduced trabecular bone volume in the femur (-24%), thinner femoral cortical bone (-11%), and weaker femoral bones (-27% ultimate moment). Bone formation was decreased, while bone resorption parameters were largely unchanged.

Conclusions: The data provide a strong rationale for using this new partial weight bearing model to explore the musculoskeletal response to reduced loading environments. The system effectively simulates partial gravity, producing significant and measurable deficits in both muscle and bone, making it a valuable tool for future spaceflight-related research.

Title: Partial reductions in mechanical loading yield proportional changes in bone density, bone architecture, and muscle mass
Abstract: Although the musculoskeletal system is known to be sensitive to changes in its mechanical environment, the relationship between functional adaptation and below-normal mechanical stimuli is not well defined. We investigated bone and muscle adaptation to a range of reduced loading using the partial weight suspension (PWS) system, in which a two-point harness is used to offload a tunable amount of body weight while maintaining quadrupedal locomotion. Skeletally mature female C57Bl/6 mice were exposed to partial weight bearing at 20%, 40%, 70%, or 100% of body weight for 21 days. A hindlimb unloaded (HLU) group was included for comparison in addition to age-matched controls in normal housing. Gait kinematics was measured across the full range of weight bearing, and some minor alterations in gait from PWS were identified. With PWS, bone and muscle changes were generally proportional to the degree of unloading. Specifically, total body and hindlimb bone mineral density, calf muscle mass, trabecular bone volume of the distal femur, and cortical area of the femur midshaft were all linearly related to the degree of unloading. Even a load reduction to 70% of normal weight bearing was associated with significant bone deterioration and muscle atrophy. Weight bearing at 20% did not lead to better bone outcomes than HLU despite less muscle atrophy and presumably greater mechanical stimulus, requiring further investigation. These data confirm that the PWS model is highly effective in applying controllable, reduced, long-term loading that produces predictable, discrete adaptive changes in muscle and bone of the hindlimb.
Overview: This research provides crucial, quantitative data for understanding how the musculoskeletal system adapts to reduced gravity, making it highly relevant for space medicine. Using a partial weight suspension (PWS) model in mice, the study demonstrates a clear, linear relationship between the degree of mechanical unloading and the extent of bone and muscle loss. The finding that even a small reduction in loading (to 70% of body weight) causes significant deterioration underscores the sensitivity of bone and muscle to mechanical stimuli and informs the development of exercise countermeasures for astronauts.
Summary:
Background: While it is well-known that the musculoskeletal system adapts to its mechanical environment, the precise relationship between varying levels of below-normal loading and the resulting adaptation is not well defined. This study aimed to quantify bone and muscle changes across a range of reduced loading levels.

Methods: Skeletally mature female C57Bl/6 mice were subjected to 21 days of partial weight suspension (PWS) at 20%, 40%, 70%, or 100% of their normal body weight. A hindlimb unloaded (HLU) group was also included for comparison. Gait kinematics, bone mineral density, calf muscle mass, and femoral trabecular and cortical bone architecture were measured.

Results: The study found that bone and muscle changes were generally proportional to the degree of unloading. Total body and hindlimb bone mineral density, calf muscle mass, trabecular bone volume, and femoral cortical area all showed a linear relationship with the level of weight bearing. Even a modest reduction to 70% weight bearing led to significant bone deterioration and muscle atrophy. Interestingly, 20% weight bearing did not produce better bone outcomes than complete hindlimb unloading.

Conclusions: The PWS model is highly effective in applying controllable levels of reduced loading that produce predictable and discrete adaptive changes in the muscle and bone of the hindlimb. The findings confirm that the musculoskeletal system is highly sensitive to the magnitude of mechanical stimuli, with deterioration occurring in proportion to the degree of unloading.

Title: Spaceflight and hind limb unloading induce similar changes in electrical impedance characteristics of mouse gastrocnemius muscle
Abstract: ObjectiveTo assess the potential of electrical impedance myography (EIM) to serve as a marker of muscle fiber atrophy and secondarily as an indicator of bone deterioration by assessing the effects of spaceflight or hind limb unloading. MethodsIn the first experiment, 6 mice were flown aboard the space shuttle (STS-135) for 13 days and 8 earthbound mice served as controls. In the second experiment, 14 mice underwent hind limb unloading (HLU) for 13 days; 13 additional mice served as controls. EIM measurements were made on ex vivo gastrocnemius muscle. Quantitative microscopy and areal bone mineral density (aBMD) measurements of the hindlimb were also performed. ResultsReductions in the multifrequency phase-slope parameter were observed for both the space flight and HLU cohorts compared to their respective controls. For ground control and spaceflight groups, the values were 24.7±1.3°/MHz and 14.1±1.6°/MHz, respectively (p=0.0013); for control and HLU groups, the values were 23.9±1.6°/MHz and 19.0±1.0°/MHz, respectively (p=0.014). This parameter also correlated with muscle fiber size (ρ=0.65, p=0.011) for spaceflight and hind limb aBMD (ρ=0.65, p=0.0063) for both groups. ConclusionsThese data support the concept that EIM may serve as a useful tool for assessment of muscle disuse secondary to immobilization or microgravity.
Overview: This study is valuable for space medicine and clinical diagnostics as it validates Electrical Impedance Myography (EIM) as a potential non-invasive tool for monitoring muscle health in microgravity. Researchers found that EIM measurements on gastrocnemius muscles from mice flown on the space shuttle and from mice in a ground-based unloading model showed similar changes. Crucially, the key EIM parameter correlated strongly with both muscle fiber size and hindlimb bone mineral density, suggesting EIM could serve as a useful, integrated biomarker for musculoskeletal deconditioning.
Summary:
Background: Muscle atrophy and bone deterioration are major concerns in spaceflight and disuse conditions on Earth. This study aimed to assess whether Electrical Impedance Myography (EIM), a non-invasive technique that measures electrical properties of muscle, could serve as a reliable marker for these changes.

Methods: Two experiments were conducted. In the first, gastrocnemius muscles were collected from mice after a 13-day space shuttle mission (STS-135) and compared to ground controls. In the second, mice underwent 13 days of hindlimb unloading (HLU), a ground-based analog for microgravity, and were compared to controls. EIM measurements were made on the ex vivo muscles. Muscle fiber size and hindlimb areal bone mineral density (aBMD) were also measured to correlate with the EIM data.

Results: Both the spaceflight and HLU groups showed significant reductions in the EIM multifrequency phase-slope parameter compared to their respective controls, indicating similar changes in muscle electrical properties due to unloading. This EIM parameter also showed a strong correlation with muscle fiber size (ρ=0.65) and with hindlimb aBMD (ρ=0.65), linking the muscle electrical changes directly to physical muscle atrophy and associated bone loss.

Conclusions: The data support the concept that EIM may be a useful and non-invasive tool for assessing muscle disuse atrophy secondary to either immobilization on Earth or exposure to microgravity in space.

Title: Spaceflight Activates Lipotoxic Pathways in Mouse Liver
Abstract: Spaceflight has several detrimental effects on the physiology of astronauts, many of which are recapitulated in rodent models. Mouse studies performed on the Space Shuttle showed disruption of lipid metabolism in liver. However, given that these animals were not sacrificed on-orbit and instead returned live to earth, it is unclear if these disruptions were solely induced by space stressors (e.g. microgravity, space radiation) or in part explained by the stress of return to Earth. In this work we analyzed three liver datasets from two different strains of mice (C57BL/6 (Jackson) & BALB/c (Taconic)) flown aboard the International Space Station (ISS). Notably, these animals were sacrificed on-orbit and exposed to varying spaceflight durations (i.e. 21, 37, and 42 days vs 13 days for the Shuttle mice). Oil Red O (ORO) staining showed abnormal lipid accumulation in all space-flown mice compared to ground controls regardless of strain or exposure duration. Similarly, transcriptomic analysis by RNA-sequencing revealed several pathways that were affected in both strains related to increased lipid metabolism, fatty acid metabolism, lipid and fatty acid processing, lipid catabolic processing, and lipid localization. In addition, key upstream regulators were predicted to be commonly regulated across all conditions including Glucagon (GCG) and Insulin (INS). Moreover, quantitative proteomic analysis showed that a number of lipid related proteins were changed in the livers during spaceflight. Taken together, these data indicate that activation of lipotoxic pathways are the result of space stressors alone and this activation occurs in various genetic backgrounds during spaceflight exposures of weeks to months. If similar responses occur in humans, a prolonged change of these pathways may result in the development of liver disease and should be investigated further.
Overview: This is a critical study for understanding the health risks of long-duration spaceflight, as it confirms that space exposure itself—independent of the stress of re-entry—activates lipotoxic pathways in the liver. By analyzing liver tissue from mice on multiple long-duration ISS missions, researchers found consistent evidence of abnormal lipid accumulation and altered gene and protein expression related to fat metabolism. These findings suggest that astronauts may be at risk for developing liver disease on extended missions, highlighting a need for further investigation and potential countermeasures.
Summary:
Background: Previous studies on Space Shuttle mice showed disruption of lipid metabolism in the liver, but it was unclear if these changes were caused by spaceflight or the stress of returning to Earth. This study aimed to clarify this by analyzing liver samples from mice that were euthanized on-orbit during long-duration missions on the International Space Station (ISS).

Methods: The study analyzed liver datasets from two different strains of mice flown on the ISS for varying durations (21, 37, and 42 days). Methods included Oil Red O staining to visualize lipid accumulation, RNA-sequencing for transcriptomic analysis, and quantitative proteomics to measure protein levels.

Results: Abnormal lipid accumulation was observed in the livers of all space-flown mice compared to ground controls, regardless of mouse strain or flight duration. Transcriptomic analysis revealed commonly affected pathways related to increased lipid metabolism, fatty acid processing, and lipid localization across all conditions. Key upstream regulators like Glucagon (GCG) and Insulin (INS) were predicted to be involved. Proteomic analysis confirmed that a number of lipid-related proteins were also altered during spaceflight.

Conclusions: The study concludes that the activation of lipotoxic pathways in the liver is a direct result of space stressors alone. This response occurs in different genetic backgrounds and across flight durations from weeks to months. The authors suggest that if similar responses occur in humans, prolonged activation of these pathways could lead to liver disease, warranting further investigation.

Title: Treatment with a soluble bone morphogenetic protein type 1A receptor (BMPR1A) fusion protein increases bone mass and bone formation in mice subjected to hindlimb unloading.
Abstract: ABSTRACT Previous work has shown that the soluble murine BMPR1A–fusion protein (mBMPR1A‐mFc) binds to BMP2 and BMP4 with high affinity, preventing downstream signaling. Further, treatment of intact and ovariectomized mice with mBMPR1A‐mFc leads to increased bone mass, and improved bone microarchitecture and strength, via increased bone formation and reduced resorption. In this study, we tested the effects of mBMPR1A‐mFc on disuse‐induced bone loss caused by 21 days of hindlimb unloading (HLU) via tail suspension versus cage controls (CONs). Adult female C57BL/6J mice (12 weeks old) were assigned to one of four groups (n = 10 each): CON‐VEH; CON‐mBMPR1A‐mFc; HLU‐VEH; and HLU‐mBMPR1A‐mFc. Mice were injected subcutaneously with VEH or mBMPR1A‐mFc (4.5 mg/kg, 2×/week). Leg BMD declined in the HLU‐VEH group (–5.3% ± 1.3%), whereas it was unchanged in HLU‐mBMPR1A‐mFc (–0.3% ± 0.9%, p < 0.05 versus HLU‐VEH). Leg BMD increased significantly more in CON‐mBMPR1A‐mFc than CON‐VEH (10.2% ± 0.6% versus 4.4% ± 0.8%). In the femur, trabecular, and cortical bone microarchitecture was worse in the HLU‐VEH compared to CON‐VEH mice, whereas mBMPR1A‐mFc treatment for 3 weeks led to greater Tb.BV/TV, Tb.Th, and midshaft Ct.Th in both the HLU and CON groups compared to comparable VEH‐treated counterparts (p < 0.05). HLU‐mBMPR1A‐mFc mice also had 21% greater failure load (p < 0.05) compared to their VEH‐treated counterparts. Dynamic histomorphometry indicated that treatment with mBMPR1A‐mFc led to significantly greater mineralizing surface and mineral apposition rate, resulting in a 3.5‐fold and fivefold higher bone formation rate in the mBMPR1A‐mFc‐treated CON and HLU animals versus VEH groups, respectively. mBMPR1A‐mFc‐treated mice had a similar osteoblast surface but significantly lower osteoclast surface than VEH‐treated animals in both the CON and HLU groups. Altogether, these findings suggest that treatment with the soluble BMPR1A fusion protein may be useful for maintenance of skeletal integrity in the setting of disuse‐induced bone loss. © 2017 The Authors JBMR Plus published by Wiley Periodicals, Inc. on behalf of American Society for Bone and Mineral Research.
Overview: This research offers a promising new therapeutic strategy for combating bone loss caused by disuse, such as in prolonged bed rest or spaceflight. The study demonstrates that a soluble BMP receptor fusion protein (mBMPR1A–mFc) can not only prevent disuse-induced bone loss but also actively increase bone mass in mice subjected to hindlimb unloading. By simultaneously boosting bone formation and reducing resorption, this agent shows significant potential for maintaining skeletal integrity in unloading conditions.
Summary:
Background: A soluble fusion protein, mBMPR1A–mFc, which blocks certain bone morphogenetic protein (BMP) signals, has been previously shown to increase bone mass in normal and ovariectomized mice. This study aimed to test its effectiveness against disuse-induced bone loss.

Methods: Adult female mice were subjected to 21 days of hindlimb unloading (HLU) to simulate disuse. During this period, mice were treated with either a vehicle (VEH) or the mBMPR1A–mFc fusion protein. Normally loaded control (CON) mice were also treated with either VEH or the protein. Bone mineral density (BMD), bone microarchitecture (via micro-CT), bone strength (via biomechanical testing), and bone cell activity (via dynamic histomorphometry) were assessed.

Results: In vehicle-treated mice, HLU caused a significant decline in leg BMD and worsened bone microarchitecture. However, in HLU mice treated with mBMPR1A–mFc, leg BMD was unchanged and bone microarchitecture was significantly greater than in their vehicle-treated counterparts. The treatment dramatically increased the bone formation rate (by fivefold in HLU animals) and reduced the osteoclast surface. As a result, treated HLU mice had 21% greater femoral failure load than untreated HLU mice.

Conclusions: The findings suggest that treatment with the soluble BMPR1A fusion protein is a potent strategy for maintaining skeletal integrity in the setting of disuse-induced bone loss. Its dual action of stimulating bone formation and reducing resorption makes it a promising therapeutic candidate.

Title: RNAseq and RNA molecular barcoding reveal differential gene expression in cortical bone following hindlimb unloading in female mice
Abstract: Disuse-induced bone loss is seen following spinal cord injury, prolonged bed rest, and exposure to microgravity. We performed whole transcriptomic profiling of cortical bone using RNA sequencing (RNAseq) and RNA molecular barcoding (NanoString) on a hindlimb unloading (HLU) mouse model to identify genes whose mRNA transcript abundances change in response to disuse. Eleven-week old female C57BL/6 mice were exposed to ambulatory loading or HLU for 7 days (n = 8/group). Total RNA from marrow-flushed femoral cortical bone was analyzed on HiSeq and NanoString platforms. The expression of several previously reported genes associated with Wnt signaling and metabolism was altered by HLU. Furthermore, the increased abundance of transcripts, such as Pfkfb3 and Mss51, after HLU imply these genes also have roles in the cortical bone’s response to altered mechanical loading. Our study demonstrates that an unbiased approach to assess the whole transcriptomic profile of cortical bone can reveal previously unidentified mechanosensitive genes and may eventually lead to novel targets to prevent disuse-induced osteoporosis.
Overview: This study provides a valuable, unbiased look into the early molecular response of cortical bone to disuse, which is crucial for understanding conditions like osteoporosis from spaceflight or bed rest. Using two advanced transcriptomic profiling methods on bone from a hindlimb unloading mouse model, researchers identified previously unknown mechanosensitive genes, such as Pfkfb3 and Mss51. This whole-transcriptome approach reveals new players in the bone's response to mechanical loading, offering potential new targets for preventing disuse-induced bone loss.
Summary:
Background: Disuse, such as from spinal cord injury or microgravity exposure, leads to bone loss. To identify the genes and pathways involved in the cortical bone's response to this unloading, a whole transcriptomic analysis was needed.

Methods: Eleven-week-old female mice were subjected to hindlimb unloading (HLU) for 7 days. Total RNA was extracted from their marrow-flushed femoral cortical bone. The researchers then used two different platforms for whole transcriptomic profiling: RNA sequencing (RNAseq) and RNA molecular barcoding (NanoString), and compared the results to ambulatory control mice.

Results: The analysis confirmed that HLU altered the expression of several genes previously linked to Wnt signaling and metabolism in bone. More importantly, the unbiased approach revealed the increased abundance of transcripts for genes not previously identified as mechanosensitive, such as Pfkfb3 and Mss51. These genes are now implicated in the cortical bone's response to altered mechanical loading.

Conclusions: The study demonstrates that using an unbiased, whole-transcriptomic approach on cortical bone can reveal previously unidentified mechanosensitive genes. These newly discovered genes may serve as novel targets for developing interventions to prevent disuse-induced osteoporosis.

Title: Proteomic and phosphoproteomic characterization of cardiovascular tissues after long term exposure to simulated space radiation
Abstract: Introduction: It may take decades to develop cardiovascular dysfunction following exposure to high doses of ionizing radiation from medical therapy or from nuclear accidents. Since astronauts may be exposed continually to a complex space radiation environment unlike that experienced on Earth, it is unresolved whether there is a risk to cardiovascular health during long-term space exploration missions. Previously, we have described that mice exposed to a single dose of simplified Galactic Cosmic Ray (GCR5-ion) develop cardiovascular dysfunction by 12 months post-radiation. Methods: To investigate the biological basis of this dysfunction, here we performed a quantitative mass spectrometry-based proteomics analysis of heart tissue (proteome and phosphoproteome) and plasma (proteome only) from these mice at 8 months post-radiation. Results: Differentially expressed proteins (DEPs) for irradiated versus sham irradiated samples (fold-change ≥1.2 and an adjusted p-value of ≤0.05) were identified for each proteomics data set. For the heart proteome, there were 87 significant DEPs (11 upregulated and 76 downregulated); for the heart phosphoproteome, there were 60 significant differentially phosphorylated peptides (17 upregulated and 43 downregulated); and for the plasma proteome, there was only one upregulated protein. A Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA) technique that assesses canonical pathways from BIOCARTA, KEGG, PID, REACTOME, and WikiPathways revealed significant perturbation in pathways in each data set. For the heart proteome, 166 pathways were significantly altered (36 upregulated and 130 downregulated); for the plasma proteome, there were 73 pathways significantly altered (25 upregulated and 48 downregulated); and for the phosphoproteome, there were 223 pathways significantly affected at 0.1 adjusted p-value cutoff. Pathways related to inflammation were the most highly perturbed in the heart and plasma. In line with sustained inflammation, neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) were demonstrated to be increased in GCR5-ion irradiated hearts at 12-month post irradiation. NETs play a fundamental role in combating bacterial pathogens, modulating inflammatory responses, inflicting damage on healthy tissues, and escalating vascular thrombosis. Discussion: These findings suggest that a single exposure to GCR5-ion results in long-lasting changes in the proteome and that these proteomic changes can potentiate acute and chronic health issues for astronauts, such as what we have previously described with late cardiac dysfunction in these mice.
Overview: This paper is critical for understanding the long-term cardiovascular risks of deep space travel, providing a detailed molecular snapshot of the heart's response to simulated galactic cosmic radiation (GCR). Using proteomics, researchers identified persistent changes in heart and plasma proteins 8 months after a single GCR exposure in mice. The most highly perturbed pathways were related to inflammation, a finding supported by the late-stage presence of neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs). This suggests that a single GCR exposure can trigger long-lasting inflammation, potentiating chronic cardiovascular health issues for astronauts.
Summary:
Background: There is a risk of cardiovascular dysfunction following exposure to space radiation, but the biological basis is not well understood. Previous work showed that mice exposed to a simplified 5-ion Galactic Cosmic Ray simulation (GCR5-ion) develop cardiovascular dysfunction 12 months later. This study aimed to investigate the molecular changes at an earlier time point.

Methods: Heart tissue (proteome and phosphoproteome) and plasma (proteome) were collected from mice 8 months after a single exposure to GCR5-ion radiation. Quantitative mass spectrometry-based proteomics was used to identify differentially expressed proteins (DEPs) and differentially phosphorylated peptides compared to sham-irradiated controls. Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA) was used to identify altered biological pathways. Neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) were also measured in heart tissue at 12 months post-irradiation.

Results: The heart proteome showed 87 DEPs, while the phosphoproteome had 60 differentially phosphorylated peptides. Pathway analysis revealed significant perturbations in all datasets, with inflammation-related pathways being the most highly affected in both the heart and plasma. Consistent with sustained inflammation, the presence of NETs, which are involved in inflammation and thrombosis, was found to be increased in the irradiated hearts 12 months after exposure.

Conclusions: The study suggests that a single exposure to simulated GCR results in long-lasting changes to the proteome of the heart and plasma. These changes, particularly the sustained inflammation, can potentiate both acute and chronic health issues, such as the late cardiac dysfunction previously observed in these mice, and may represent a significant risk for astronauts.

Title: Adaptive Changes in the Vestibular System of Land Snail to a 30-Day Spaceflight and Readaptation on Return to Earth
Abstract: The vestibular system receives a permanent influence from gravity and reflexively controls equilibrium. If we assume gravity has remained constant during the species' evolution, will its sensory system adapt to abrupt loss of that force? We address this question in the land snail Helix lucorum exposed to 30 days of near weightlessness aboard the Bion-M1 satellite, and studied geotactic behavior of postflight snails, differential gene expressions in statocyst transcriptome, and electrophysiological responses of mechanoreceptors to applied tilts. Each approach revealed plastic changes in the snail's vestibular system assumed in response to spaceflight. Absence of light during the mission also affected statocyst physiology, as revealed by comparison to dark-conditioned control groups. Readaptation to normal tilt responses occurred at ~20 h following return to Earth. Despite the permanence of gravity, the snail responded in a compensatory manner to its loss and readapted once gravity was restored.
Overview: This study provides fascinating evidence of neuroplasticity in a simple organism's gravity-sensing system in response to spaceflight. By examining land snails after a 30-day mission, researchers found behavioral, transcriptomic, and electrophysiological changes indicating a compensatory adaptation to the absence of gravity. The snail's vestibular system became more sensitive to acceleration, and it readapted to Earth's gravity within about 20 hours. This work demonstrates that even systems evolved under a constant gravitational pull can adapt to its loss, offering insights into fundamental principles of sensory plasticity.
Summary:
Background: The vestibular system, which controls balance, has evolved under the constant influence of Earth's gravity. This study addressed whether this sensory system could adapt to the abrupt loss of that force by studying the land snail Helix lucorum after a 30-day spaceflight on the Bion-M1 satellite.

Methods: The study used a multi-pronged approach. Post-flight, researchers examined the snails' geotactic behavior (orientation to gravity). They performed transcriptome analysis to measure differential gene expression in the statocyst (the gravity-sensing organ). Finally, they made electrophysiological recordings of mechanoreceptors from the statocyst to measure their responses to applied tilts.

Results: All three approaches revealed plastic changes in the snail's vestibular system. Post-flight snails showed an enhanced negative gravitaxis response (faster re-orientation away from a head-down tilt). Their statoreceptors responded with a larger magnitude to tilts, indicating increased sensitivity to acceleration. Transcriptome analysis revealed a significant increase in the expression of a gene encoding Helix pedal peptide (HPep), which is linked to ciliary beating in the statoreceptors. These changes began to readapt back to normal around 20 hours after returning to Earth.

Conclusions: Despite the evolutionary permanence of gravity, the snail's vestibular system responded in a compensatory manner to its absence and was able to readapt upon its restoration. This suggests a fundamental capacity for neuroplasticity in gravity-sensing systems.

Title: Morphology of the Utricular Otolith Organ in the Toadfish, Opsanus tau
Abstract: The utricle provides the vestibular reflex pathways with the sensory codes of inertial acceleration of self motion and head orientation with respect to gravity to control balance and equilibrium. Here we present an anatomical description of this structure in the adult oyster toadfish, and establish a morphological basis for interpretation of subsequent functional studies. Light, scanning and transmission electron microscopy techniques were applied to visualize the sensory epithelium at varying levels of detail, its neural innervation and its synaptic organization. Scanning electron microscopy was used to visualize otolith mass and morphological polarization patterns of hair cells. Afferent nerve fibers were visualized following labeling with biocytin, and light microscope images were used to make three-dimensional (3-D) reconstructions of individual labeled afferents to identify dendritic morphology with respect to epithelial location. Transmission electron micrographs were compiled to create a serial 3-D reconstruction of a labeled afferent over a segment of its dendritic field and to examine the cell-afferent synaptic contacts. Major observations are: a well-defined striola, medial and lateral extra-striolar regions with a zonal organization of hair bundles; prominent lacinia projecting laterally; dependence of hair cell density on macular location; narrow afferent dendritic fields that follow the hair bundle polarization; synaptic specializations issued by afferents are typically directed towards a limited number of 7–13 hair cells, but larger dendritic fields in the medial extra-striola can be associated with > 20 hair cells also; and hair cell synaptic bodies can be confined to only an individual afferent or can synapse upon several afferents.
Overview: This paper provides a detailed anatomical and structural blueprint of the utricle, a key organ for balance and gravity sensing, in the oyster toadfish. By combining light, scanning, and transmission electron microscopy, the authors create a comprehensive 3D visualization of the sensory epithelium, its hair cells, and their intricate neural connections. This foundational morphological work is essential for interpreting functional studies of the vestibular system, not only in toadfish but also as a comparative model for understanding vertebrate balance and equilibrium.
Summary:
Background: The utricle is a vestibular organ that provides the brain with sensory information about linear acceleration and head orientation relative to gravity, which is crucial for controlling balance. This study aimed to provide a detailed anatomical description of this structure in the adult oyster toadfish to serve as a basis for future functional research.

Methods: A combination of microscopy techniques was used. Light microscopy, along with neural tracing with biocytin, was used to create 3D reconstructions of individual afferent nerve fibers. Scanning electron microscopy was used to visualize the otolith and the polarization patterns of sensory hair cells. Transmission electron microscopy was used to create serial 3D reconstructions of synaptic contacts between hair cells and afferent nerves.

Results: The study revealed a well-defined organization of the sensory macula, with a distinct striola and extra-striolar regions. Hair cell density varied by location. Afferent nerve fibers had narrow dendritic fields that followed the hair cell polarization patterns. A typical afferent synapsed with a limited number of hair cells (7-13), though some larger fields could connect to more than 20. Synaptic bodies on hair cells could be dedicated to a single afferent or synapse with several.

Conclusions: This study establishes a detailed morphological basis for the toadfish utricle. The major observations on the zonal organization of hair cells, the structure of afferent dendritic fields, and the patterns of synaptic connectivity provide a critical anatomical framework for interpreting subsequent functional studies on vestibular reflexes and gravity sensing.

Title: Influence of Magnitude and Duration of Altered Gravity and Readaptation to 1g on the Structure and Function of the Utricle in Toadfish, Opsanus tau.
Abstract: Gravity has remained constant during animal evolution and the neural sensory systems detecting acceleration forces have remained remarkably conserved among vertebrates. The utricular organ senses the sum of inertial force due to head translation and head tilt relative to gravitational vertical. Change in gravitational force would be expected to have profound effects on how an organism maintains equilibrium. We characterize the physiology of utricular afferents to applied accelerations in the oyster toadfish, Opsanus tau, in normal 1 g to establish benchmarks, after 1–32-day exposures to 2.24 g (resultant) via centrifugation (hypergravity, HG), after 4- and 16-day exposures to 1.12 g (resultant), and following 1–8 days recovery to HG exposures to study re-adaptation to 1 g. Afferents were also examined during activation of efferent vestibular pathway. Centrifugation at 2.24 g included 228°/s constant angular velocity component, and thus horizontal canal afferent responses to yaw rotation were recorded as an internal control in each fish. Afferents studied after 228°/s rotation for 4 and 16 days without centripetal acceleration, called On-Center-Control, were indistinguishable from their control counterparts. Principal response to HG was an adjustment of afferent sensitivity as a function of magnitude and duration of exposure: an initial robust increase at 3–4 days followed by a significant decrease from 16 to 32 days. Initial increase observed after 4 days of HG took >4 days in 1 g to recover, and the decrease observed after 16 days of HG took >2 days to readapt to 1 g. Hair cells in striola and medial extrastriola macula regions were serially reconstructed in 3D from thin sections using transmission electron microscopy in control fish and fish exposed to 4 and 16 days of HG. Despite the highly significant differences in afferent physiology, synaptic body counts quantified in the same fish were equivalent in their inter-animal variability and averages. No clear role of the efferent pathway as a feedback mechanism regulating afferent behavior to HG was found. Transfer from 1 g to HG imparts profound effects on gravitational sensitivity of utricular afferents and the accompanying transfer from the HG back to the 1 g resembles in part (as an analog) the transfer from 1 g to the micrograms.
Overview: This study provides a detailed investigation into how the vestibular system adapts to altered gravity, using the toadfish as a model. By exposing fish to sustained hypergravity via centrifugation, researchers found that the sensitivity of utricular afferent neurons first increases and then decreases over time, demonstrating a complex, time-dependent plasticity. These findings are highly relevant to space medicine, as the adaptation to hypergravity and subsequent readaptation to 1 g serve as a valuable analog for understanding the profound effects that transferring from 1 g to microgravity might have on astronaut balance and orientation.
Summary:
Background: The utricular organ senses linear acceleration, including gravity. Changes in gravitational force are expected to have a profound effect on an organism's sense of equilibrium. This study aimed to characterize how the physiology of utricular afferents in the toadfish adapts to sustained hypergravity (HG) and then readapts to normal 1 g.

Methods: The researchers exposed toadfish to 2.24 g or 1.12 g via centrifugation for durations ranging from 1 to 32 days. They then performed electrophysiological recordings of utricular afferents to measure their sensitivity to applied accelerations. The responses were compared to normal 1 g controls and animals that readapted to 1 g for 1-8 days after HG exposure. The synaptic structure of hair cells was also examined using 3D transmission electron microscopy.

Results: The principal response to hypergravity was an adjustment of afferent sensitivity that depended on both the magnitude and duration of the exposure. After 3-4 days of 2.24 g, afferent sensitivity robustly increased. However, with longer exposure (16-32 days), the sensitivity significantly decreased. These changes took several days to recover upon return to 1 g. Despite these significant physiological changes, there were no corresponding changes in the number of synaptic bodies in the hair cells.

Conclusions: The study demonstrates that transfer to a hypergravity environment imparts profound, time-dependent effects on the gravitational sensitivity of utricular afferents. The process of adapting to HG and then readapting to 1 g is proposed as an analog for the sensory changes that occur during the transition from 1 g to microgravity during spaceflight, which could have implications for astronaut vestibular function.

Title: Organization of the ER-Golgi interface for membrane traffic control.
Abstract: Coat protein complex I (COPI) and COPII are required for bidirectional membrane trafficking between the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and the Golgi. While these core coat machineries and other transport factors are highly conserved across species, high-resolution imaging studies indicate that the organization of the ER–Golgi interface is varied in eukaryotic cells. Regulation of COPII assembly, in some cases to manage distinct cellular cargo, is emerging as one important component in determining this structure. Comparison of the ER–Golgi interface across different systems, particularly mammalian and plant cells, reveals fundamental elements and distinct organization of this interface. A better understanding of how these interfaces are regulated to meet varying cellular secretory demands should provide key insights into the mechanisms that control efficient trafficking of proteins and lipids through the secretory pathway.
Overview: This review is valuable for cell biologists as it compares the organization of the ER-Golgi interface—a critical hub for protein and lipid trafficking—across different eukaryotic systems, particularly mammals and plants. It highlights how the core machinery (COPI and COPII coats) is conserved, yet the structural organization of this interface varies significantly. The paper emphasizes the emerging role of COPII assembly regulation in determining this structure, providing insights into how cells manage varying secretory demands.
Summary:
Background: The coat protein complexes COPI and COPII are essential for the bidirectional transport of materials between the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and the Golgi apparatus. While these core components are highly conserved across species, the physical organization of the ER-Golgi interface differs among eukaryotes.

Methods: This is a review article. It compares high-resolution imaging studies of the ER-Golgi interface in different systems, with a focus on mammalian and plant cells, to identify fundamental elements and distinct organizational strategies. It discusses the role of COPI and COPII coat machinery in this process.

Results: The review highlights that while the core trafficking machinery is conserved, the structure of the ER-Golgi interface is varied. One emerging theme is that the regulation of COPII coat assembly, sometimes to manage specific types of cargo, is a key factor in determining the organization of this interface.

Conclusions: The abstract suggests that a better understanding of how the ER-Golgi interface is regulated to meet different cellular secretory demands is crucial. Comparing these interfaces across diverse systems reveals both fundamental principles and unique adaptations, providing key insights into the mechanisms that control efficient protein and lipid trafficking through the secretory pathway.

Title: IRE1: ER stress sensor and cell fate executor.
Abstract: Cells operate a signaling network termed unfolded protein response (UPR) to monitor protein-folding capacity in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER). IRE1 is an ER transmembrane sensor that activates UPR to maintain ER and cellular function. While mammalian IRE1 promotes cell survive, it can initiate apoptosis via decay of anti-apoptotic microRNAs. Convergent and divergent IRE1 characteristics between plants and animals underscore its significance in cellular homeostasis. This review provides an updated scenario of IRE1 signaling model, discusses emerging IRE1 sensing mechanisms, compares IRE1 features among species, and outlines exciting future directions in UPR research.
Overview: This review provides an updated and comparative look at IRE1, a crucial sensor of endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress that plays a key role in determining cell fate. It is an essential read for cell biologists as it discusses the dual nature of IRE1 signaling, which can promote cell survival under stress but can also trigger apoptosis (cell death). By comparing IRE1 features across different species, the paper underscores its fundamental importance in cellular homeostasis and outlines exciting future directions for research into the unfolded protein response.
Summary:
Background: The unfolded protein response (UPR) is a signaling network that cells use to monitor protein-folding capacity in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER). IRE1 is a key transmembrane sensor in the ER that activates the UPR to maintain cellular function under stress.

Methods: This is a review article. It synthesizes current research on IRE1 signaling, discusses emerging models for how IRE1 senses stress, compares the features of IRE1 in different species (e.g., plants and animals), and identifies key unanswered questions in the field.

Results: The review highlights the convergent and divergent characteristics of IRE1 across species, underscoring its central role in cellular homeostasis. It explains how IRE1 can promote cell survival by activating the UPR, but also how, in mammals, it can initiate apoptosis by causing the decay of anti-apoptotic microRNAs. This dual function makes it a critical executor of cell fate under ER stress.

Conclusions: The article presents an updated view of the IRE1 signaling model and its significance in protein quality control and cell fate decisions. It outlines important future research directions for understanding the complex mechanisms of the unfolded protein response.

Title: Inter-regulation of the unfolded protein response and auxin signaling.
Abstract: SUMMARY The unfolded protein response (UPR) is a signaling network triggered by overload of protein-folding demand in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), a condition termed ER stress. The UPR is critical for growth and development; nonetheless, connections between the UPR and other cellular regulatory processes remain largely unknown. Here, we identify a link between the UPR and the phytohormone auxin, a master regulator of plant physiology. We show that ER stress triggers down-regulation of auxin sensors and transporters in Arabidopsis thaliana. We also demonstrate that an Arabidopsis mutant of a conserved ER stress sensor IRE1 exhibits defects in the auxin response and levels. These data not only support that the plant IRE1 is required for auxin homeostasis, they also reveal a species-specific feature of IRE1 in multicellular eukaryotes. Furthermore, by establishing that UPR activation is reduced in mutants of ER-localized auxin transporters, including PIN5, we define a long-neglected biological significance of ER-based auxin regulation. We further examine the functional relationship of IRE1 and PIN5 by showing that an ire1 pin5 triple mutant enhances defects of UPR activation and auxin homeostasis in ire1 or pin5. Our results imply that the plant UPR has evolved a hormone-dependent strategy for coordinating ER function with physiological processes.
Overview: This study reveals a novel and significant link between two fundamental cellular processes in plants: the unfolded protein response (UPR) for managing ER stress and auxin signaling, which governs growth and development. Researchers demonstrate a two-way interaction where ER stress downregulates auxin response, and mutants in the ER stress sensor IRE1 have defects in auxin homeostasis. This discovery of hormone-dependent UPR coordination is crucial for understanding how plants integrate organelle function with overall physiological processes to manage stress.
Summary:
Background: The unfolded protein response (UPR) is a critical signaling network that responds to stress in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER). However, its connections to other cellular regulatory processes, like hormone signaling, are largely unknown. This study aimed to investigate a potential link between the UPR and the master plant hormone, auxin.

Methods: The researchers used Arabidopsis thaliana to study the interplay between ER stress and auxin. They induced ER stress and measured the expression of auxin sensors and transporters. They analyzed an ire1 mutant (lacking a key ER stress sensor) for defects in auxin levels and response. They also used mutants of ER-localized auxin transporters (like pin5) to see if this affected UPR activation. Finally, they created a triple mutant (ire1 pin5) to examine the functional relationship.

Results: ER stress was found to trigger the downregulation of auxin sensors and transporters. The ire1 mutant exhibited defects in both auxin response and auxin levels. Conversely, UPR activation was reduced in pin5 mutants, establishing a role for ER-based auxin regulation in the UPR. The ire1 pin5 triple mutant showed even greater defects in both UPR activation and auxin homeostasis, confirming a functional link.

Conclusions: The results imply that the plant UPR has evolved a strategy to coordinate ER function with physiological processes through a dependency on hormone signaling. This study establishes a previously unknown inter-regulation between the UPR and auxin signaling, highlighting a species-specific feature of the IRE1 sensor.

Title: Endoplasmic reticulum-shape and function in stress translation
Abstract: Not found
Overview: This paper is significant for plant biologists as it connects the physical shape and structure of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) to its functional role in translating stress signals into cellular responses. It highlights the ER as a dynamic organelle that not only manages protein folding under stress (via the UPR and ERAD) but also undergoes morphological changes, such as forming ER bodies. This link between ER shape and function is crucial for understanding how plants manage stress, from protein quality control to programmed cell death.
Summary:
Background: The abstract for this paper was not found. The title suggests the paper explores how the shape and structure of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) are linked to its function, particularly in how the cell translates stress signals into appropriate responses.

Methods: The abstract was not found. The study likely involved advanced microscopy to observe changes in ER morphology under various stress conditions. Title: Galactose-depleted xycoglucan is dysfunctional and leads to dwarfism in Arabidopsis
Abstract: Depleting galactose from the cell wall polysaccharide xyloglucan leads to a disruption of diverse cellular and physiological processes involved in normal plant growth.
Overview: This study provides a clear demonstration of the critical structural role of a specific sugar, galactose, on the cell wall polysaccharide xyloglucan, making it highly relevant for plant cell biologists. By creating an Arabidopsis mutant that lacks galactose on its xyloglucan, researchers showed that this single modification leads to dysfunctional cell walls and severe dwarfism. This finding underscores the importance of precise polysaccharide structure for a wide range of cellular and physiological processes necessary for normal plant growth and development.
Summary:
Background: The abstract for this study is a single sentence, indicating that the research investigates the consequences of altering the structure of the cell wall polysaccharide xyloglucan in plants.

Methods: The abstract was not found, but the title and single-sentence abstract imply the main method was the creation and characterization of a mutant Arabidopsis plant. This mutant would be specifically deficient in adding galactose to its xyloglucan. The researchers would have then analyzed the plant's growth, cellular processes, and overall physiology to determine the effects of this structural change.

Results: The key result, as stated in the abstract, is that depleting galactose from xyloglucan disrupts a diverse range of cellular and physiological processes. This leads to the ultimate phenotype of dwarfism, indicating that the modified xyloglucan is dysfunctional.

Conclusions: The conclusion was not found. The study likely concludes that the presence of galactose on xyloglucan side chains is structurally critical for the proper function of the cell wall. Its absence compromises cell wall integrity and function, which in turn broadly disrupts the cellular processes required for normal plant growth.

Title: Unfolded protein response in plants: one master, many questions.
Abstract: To overcome endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress, ER-localized stress sensors actuate distinct downstream organelle-nucleus signaling pathways to invoke a cytoprotective response, known as the unfolded protein response (UPR). Compared to yeast and metazoans, plant UPR studies are more recent but nevertheless fascinating. Here we discuss recent discoveries in plant UPR, highlight conserved and unique features of the plant UPR as well as critical yet-open questions whose answers will likely make significant contributions to the understanding plant ER stress management.
Overview: This review provides a concise yet comprehensive update on the unfolded protein response (UPR) in plants, a crucial mechanism for managing stress in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER). It is a valuable read for plant and cell biologists as it highlights both the conserved and unique features of the plant UPR compared to yeast and animals. By outlining recent discoveries and posing critical, unanswered questions, the article serves as both a summary of the field and a roadmap for future research into plant ER stress management.
Summary:
Background: The unfolded protein response (UPR) is a cytoprotective signaling network that is activated by stress in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER). While well-studied in yeast and metazoans, research into the plant UPR is more recent.

Methods: This is a review article. The authors discuss recent discoveries in the field of plant UPR, compare the plant system to that of other eukaryotes, and highlight key questions that remain to be answered.

Results: The review summarizes the current understanding of the plant UPR, pointing out features that are conserved across kingdoms as well as aspects that are unique to plants. It brings together recent findings to present an up-to-date picture of how plants manage ER stress.

Conclusions: The article concludes by emphasizing the many critical yet open questions in the field. It suggests that answering these questions will likely lead to significant contributions to our understanding of how plants manage proteotoxic stress in the ER.

Title: Vesicles versus Tubes: Is Endoplasmic Reticulum-Golgi Transport in Plants Fundamentally Different from Other Eukaryotes?
Abstract: Four leading cell biologists reflect on the controversial nature of the vector for transport between the ER and Golgi apparatus in higher plants.
