Results: Mice reconstituted with db/db bone marrow (lacking leptin signaling in their immune cells) had significantly lower body weight and adiposity on the HFD compared to mice with WT bone marrow. Their adipose tissue showed lower expression of inflammatory genes, fewer crown-like structures, and a higher proportion of anti-inflammatory (MGL1+) macrophages. Consequently, these mice also exhibited greater insulin sensitivity.

Conclusions: The study shows that disrupting leptin signaling specifically in bone marrow-derived cells attenuates the pro-inflammatory conditions that characterize obesity. This establishes a novel mechanism for the regulation of obesity-associated inflammation and provides strong support for the hypothesis that leptin functions as a pro-inflammatory cytokine.

Title: Establishment and characterization of DB-1: a leptin receptor-deficient murine macrophage cell line
Abstract: Metabolic and immune mediators activate many of the same signal transduction pathways. Therefore, molecules that regulate metabolism often affect immune responses. Leptin is an adipokine that exemplifies this interplay. Leptin is the body’s major nutritional status sensor, but it also plays a key role in immune system regulation. To provide an in vitro tool to investigate the link between leptin and innate immunity, we immortalized and characterized a leptin receptor-deficient macrophage cell line, DB-1. The cell line was created using bone marrow cells from leptin receptor-deficient mice. Bone marrow cells were differentiated into macrophages by culturing them with recombinant mouse macrophage colony stimulating factor, and passaged when confluent for 6 months. The cells spontaneously immortalized at approximately passage 20. Cells were cloned twice by limiting dilution cloning prior to characterization. The macrophage cell line is diploid and grows at a linear rate for 4–5 days before reaching the growth plateau. The cells are MAC-2 and F4/80 positive and have phagocytic activity similar to primary macrophages from wild-type and leptin receptor-deficient mice. DB-1 cells were responsive to stimulation with interferon-γ as measured by increase in Nos2 transcript levels. In addition, DB-1 macrophages are not responsive to the chemotactic signaling of adipocyte conditioned media nor leptin when compared to primary WT macrophages. We believe that DB-1 cells provide a dependable tool to study the role of leptin or the leptin receptor in obesity-associated inflammation and immune system dysregulation.
Overview: This paper is a valuable resource for researchers studying the intersection of metabolism and immunity, as it describes the creation and characterization of a new tool: the DB-1 macrophage cell line. This cell line, derived from leptin receptor-deficient mice, provides a stable and reliable in vitro model to investigate the role of leptin signaling in macrophage function. By offering a system that lacks leptin responsiveness, the DB-1 cell line will help scientists dissect the mechanisms linking the metabolic hormone leptin to obesity-associated inflammation and immune system dysregulation.
Summary:
Background: Leptin is a key metabolic hormone that also plays a crucial role in regulating the immune system. To provide a better in vitro tool for investigating the link between leptin and innate immunity, the researchers aimed to create an immortalized macrophage cell line that is deficient in the leptin receptor.

Methods: The cell line was created by differentiating bone marrow cells from leptin receptor-deficient mice into macrophages and then continuously passaging them for 6 months until they spontaneously immortalized. The resulting cell line, named DB-1, was cloned and then extensively characterized. Its growth rate, chromosome number, expression of macrophage markers (MAC-2, F4/80), phagocytic activity, and responsiveness to interferon-γ were measured. Its lack of response to leptin was confirmed in chemotaxis assays.

Results: The DB-1 cell line was successfully established. It is diploid, grows at a linear rate, expresses key macrophage markers, and has phagocytic activity similar to primary macrophages. The cells are responsive to interferon-γ stimulation, as expected for macrophages. Crucially, DB-1 cells do not respond to the chemotactic signals of leptin, confirming their leptin receptor deficiency.

Conclusions: The DB-1 cell line provides a dependable and stable tool for studying the role of leptin and its receptor in processes like obesity-associated inflammation and immune system regulation. It allows for controlled in vitro experiments that were previously difficult to perform with primary cells.

Title: Validation of methods to assess the immunoglobulin gene repertoire in tissues obtained from mice on the International Space Station.
Abstract: Spaceflight is known to affect immune cell populations. In particular, splenic B cell numbers decrease during spaceflight and in ground-based physiological models. Although antibody isotype changes have been assessed during and after space flight, an extensive characterization of the impact of spaceflight on antibody composition has not been conducted in mice. Next Generation Sequencing and bioinformatic tools are now available to assess antibody repertoires. We can now identify immunoglobulin gene- segment usage, junctional regions, and modifications that contribute to specificity and diversity. Due to limitations on the International Space Station, alternate sample collection and storage methods must be employed. Our group compared Illumina MiSeq sequencing data from multiple sample preparation methods in normal C57Bl/6J mice to validate that sample preparation and storage would not bias the outcome of antibody repertoire characterization. In this report, we also compared sequencing techniques and a bioinformatic workflow on the data output when we assessed the IgH and Igκ variable gene usage. This included assessments of our bioinformatic workflow on Illumina HiSeq and MiSeq datasets and is specifically designed to reduce bias, capture the most information from Ig sequences, and produce a data set that provides other data mining options. We validated our workflow by comparing our normal mouse MiSeq data to existing murine antibody repertoire studies validating it for future antibody repertoire studies.
Overview: This study is a crucial methods paper for researchers planning to conduct immunological studies using samples from the International Space Station (ISS). It validates that alternative sample collection and storage methods, which are necessary due to on-orbit limitations, do not bias the outcome of antibody repertoire characterization using next-generation sequencing. By comparing different sample preparation techniques and sequencing platforms, the authors establish a robust bioinformatic workflow that ensures reliable and comparable data can be obtained from precious spaceflight samples.
Summary:
Background: Spaceflight affects immune cell populations, but a detailed characterization of its impact on the mouse antibody repertoire has been limited by the challenges of sample collection and storage on the International Space Station (ISS). This study aimed to validate methods to ensure that the necessary on-orbit sample preparation techniques would not introduce bias into subsequent antibody repertoire analysis.

Methods: The researchers compared Illumina MiSeq sequencing data from splenic tissue of normal C57Bl/6J mice that was prepared using multiple different methods, simulating the constraints of spaceflight sample collection. They also compared different sequencing techniques (HiSeq vs. MiSeq) and developed a bioinformatic workflow designed to reduce bias and maximize the information captured from immunoglobulin (Ig) sequences. The validity of their workflow was confirmed by comparing their results to existing murine antibody repertoire studies.

Results: The study successfully validated that the alternate sample preparation and storage methods did not significantly bias the outcome of the antibody repertoire analysis. The developed bioinformactic workflow proved to be robust across different sequencing platforms and was validated against established data, ensuring it could be reliably used for future studies.

Conclusions: The authors conclude that their validated workflow and methods are suitable for future antibody repertoire studies using samples collected under the constraints of spaceflight. This work ensures that high-quality, unbiased immunological data can be obtained from valuable ISS experiments.

Title: Characterization of the naive murine antibody repertoire using unamplified high-throughput sequencing
Abstract: Antibody specificity and diversity are generated through the enzymatic splicing of genomic gene segments within each B cell. Antibodies are heterodimers of heavy- and light-chains encoded on separate loci. We studied the antibody repertoire from pooled, splenic tissue of unimmunized, adult female C57BL/6J mice, using high-throughput sequencing (HTS) without amplification of antibody transcripts. We recovered over 90,000 heavy-chain and over 135,000 light-chain immunoglobulin sequences. Individual V-, D-, and J-gene segment usage was uniform among the three mouse pools, particularly in highly abundant gene segments, with low frequency V-gene segments not being detected in all pools. Despite the similar usage of individual gene segments, the repertoire of individual B-cell CDR3 amino acid sequences in each mouse pool was highly varied, affirming the combinatorial diversity in the B-cell pool that has been previously demonstrated. There also was some skewing in the V-gene segments that were detected depending on chromosomal location. This study presents a unique, non-primer biased glimpse of the conventionally housed, unimmunized antibody repertoire of the C57BL6/J mouse.
Overview: This study provides a unique and unbiased baseline of the naive mouse antibody repertoire, making it a valuable resource for immunologists. By using a high-throughput sequencing method that avoids amplification bias, the researchers offer a clear glimpse into the composition of heavy and light chain immunoglobulin transcripts in the spleens of unimmunized mice. The findings confirm the vast combinatorial diversity of the B-cell pool while also revealing uniformity in the usage of highly abundant gene segments, providing a foundational dataset for future immunological research.
Summary:
Background: Antibody diversity is generated through the combinatorial splicing of V, D, and J gene segments. This study aimed to characterize the unimmunized antibody repertoire of C57BL/6J mice using a high-throughput sequencing (HTS) method that does not rely on PCR amplification, which can introduce bias.

Methods: Splenic tissue was pooled from unimmunized, adult female C57BL/6J mice. Antibody transcripts (both heavy and light chains) were sequenced directly using HTS without any amplification step. The researchers then analyzed the usage of individual V, D, and J gene segments and the diversity of the complementarity-determining region 3 (CDR3), which is key for antigen binding.

Results: The method recovered over 90,000 unique heavy-chain and 135,000 unique light-chain immunoglobulin sequences. The usage of individual, highly abundant gene segments was found to be very uniform among the different mouse pools. However, despite this uniformity in segment usage, the repertoire of individual CDR3 amino acid sequences was highly varied, confirming the vast combinatorial diversity of the B-cell population. Some skewing in V-gene segment usage based on chromosomal location was also detected.

Conclusions: The study presents a unique, non-primer biased characterization of the naive antibody repertoire in the C57BL/6J mouse. It provides a detailed and unbiased baseline of immunoglobulin gene usage and diversity, which is valuable for future studies on immune responses and repertoire changes.

Title: Effects of spaceflight on the immunoglobulin repertoire of unimmunized C57BL/6 mice
Abstract: Spaceflight has been shown to suppress the adaptive immune response, altering the distribution and function of lymphocyte populations. B lymphocytes express highly specific and highly diversified receptors, known as immunoglobulins (Ig), that directly bind and neutralize pathogens. Ig diversity is achieved through the enzymatic splicing of gene segments within the genomic DNA of each B cell in a host. The collection of Ig specificities within a host, or Ig repertoire, has been increasingly characterized in both basic research and clinical settings using high-throughput sequencing technology (HTS). We utilized HTS to test the hypothesis that spaceflight affects the B-cell repertoire. To test this hypothesis, we characterized the impact of spaceflight on the unimmunized Ig repertoire of C57BL/6 mice that were flown aboard the International Space Station (ISS) during the Rodent Research One validation flight in comparison to ground controls. Individual gene segment usage was similar between ground control and flight animals, however, gene segment combinations and the junctions in which gene segments combine was varied among animals within and between treatment groups. We also found that spontaneous somatic mutations in the IgH and Igκ gene loci were not increased. These data suggest that space flight did not affect the B cell repertoire of mice flown and housed on the ISS over a short period of time.
Overview: This study is important for space medicine as it provides the first characterization of the antibody repertoire in mice after a short-duration spaceflight. Using high-throughput sequencing, researchers found that while individual gene segment usage was similar between flight and ground control animals, the overall diversity and composition of the B-cell repertoire was not significantly affected by the spaceflight environment. The finding that spontaneous somatic mutations were not increased also provides reassuring data regarding the short-term impact of spaceflight on the B-cell compartment.
Summary:
Background: Spaceflight is known to suppress the adaptive immune response. This study aimed to test the hypothesis that spaceflight affects the B-cell immunoglobulin (Ig) repertoire by using high-throughput sequencing (HTS) to characterize it in mice flown on the International Space Station (ISS).

Methods: The researchers characterized the unimmunized Ig repertoire of C57BL/6 mice that were flown aboard the ISS during the Rodent Research One validation flight. Splenic tissue was analyzed using HTS, and the results were compared to ground control mice. The analysis focused on individual gene segment usage, the combinations of gene segments, the junctions between them, and the rate of spontaneous somatic mutations.

Results: The usage of individual gene segments was found to be similar between the flight and ground control groups. While the specific combinations of gene segments and their junctional regions varied among individual animals, there were no systematic differences between the treatment groups. Importantly, the study found that the rate of spontaneous somatic mutations in the IgH and Igκ loci was not increased by spaceflight.

Conclusions: The data suggest that a short period of spaceflight did not significantly affect the B-cell repertoire of mice housed on the ISS. The overall diversity and composition of the unimmunized antibody pool remained stable during this mission.

Title: A comparison of unamplified and massively multiplexed PCR amplification for murine antibody repertoire sequencing.
Abstract: Sequencing antibody repertoires has steadily become cheaper and easier. Sequencing methods usually rely on some form of amplification, often a massively multiplexed PCR prior to sequencing. To eliminate potential biases and create a data set that could be used for other studies, our lab compared unamplified sequencing results from the splenic heavy-chain repertoire in the mouse to those processed through two commercial applications. We also compared the use of mRNA vs total RNA, reverse transcriptase, and primer usage for cDNA synthesis and submission. The use of mRNA for cDNA synthesis resulted in higher read counts but reverse transcriptase and primer usage had no statistical effects on read count. Although most of the amplified data sets contained more antibody reads than the unamplified data set, we detected more unique V-gene segments in the unamplified data set. Although unique CDR3 detection was much lower in the unamplified data set, RNASeq detected 98% of the high frequency CDR3s. We have shown that unamplified profiling of the antibody repertoire is possible, detects more V-gene segments, and detects high frequency clones in the repertoire.
Overview: This is a key methodological paper for immunologists and bioinformaticians, as it directly compares unamplified antibody repertoire sequencing with two commercial, amplification-based methods. The study reveals a critical trade-off: while amplification yields more antibody reads, the unamplified method detects a greater number of unique V-gene segments, providing a less biased view of the repertoire's breadth. This finding is important for researchers choosing a sequencing strategy, as it demonstrates that unamplified profiling, though yielding fewer reads, can offer a more accurate representation of the repertoire's diversity.
Summary:
Background: Sequencing antibody repertoires is becoming easier, but most methods rely on amplification steps (like multiplexed PCR), which can introduce significant bias. This study aimed to compare the results of an unamplified sequencing method for the murine splenic heavy-chain repertoire to those obtained from two commercial amplification-based applications.

Methods: The researchers compared the antibody repertoire data generated from mouse spleen using an unamplified RNA-Seq approach versus two commercial applications that use massively multiplexed PCR. They also tested the effects of different starting materials (mRNA vs. total RNA) and different components of the cDNA synthesis process (reverse transcriptase, primers).

Results: Using mRNA as the starting material resulted in higher read counts, but the choice of reverse transcriptase and primers had no statistical effect. Although the amplified datasets contained more total antibody reads than the unamplified dataset, the unamplified method detected more unique V-gene segments. While the unamplified dataset detected fewer unique CDR3 sequences overall, it successfully detected 98% of the high-frequency CDR3 clones found in the amplified datasets.

Conclusions: The study shows that unamplified profiling of the antibody repertoire is a viable method. It demonstrates that this approach, while producing fewer reads, can detect a wider range of V-gene segments and still identify the high-frequency clones, making it a less biased option for assessing repertoire diversity.

Title: Effects of skeletal unloading on the antibody repertoire of tetanus toxoid and/or CpG treated C57BL/6J mice.
Abstract: This report concerns the preclinical development of TAK-754, an AAV8-based human factor VIII (FVIII) vector designed to deliver a codon-optimized and CpG-depleted B domain-deleted F8 transgene under the control of a liver-specific promoter for gene therapy in patients with hemophilia A. A dose-dependent increase in plasma FVIII activity was detected in FVIII knockout mice at a dose of 1.0 × 1012 TAK-754 capsid particles (CP)/kg or higher. This increase was shown to be in accordance with a dose-dependent decrease in blood loss in a hemostatic efficacy assay. TAK-754 (3.1 × 1012 CP/kg) mediated long-term and stable FVIII expression in immunologically tolerant transgenic human FVIII mice. Toxicology and biodistribution assessments with a single administration of TAK-754 ranging between 1.9 × 1012 and 5.0 × 1013 CP/kg were conducted in male C57BL/6J mice. The highest TAK-754 dose occurred without TAK-754-related adverse clinical signs. Biodistribution profiling showed predominant detection in the liver with a low occurrence of vector DNA in other tissues. Integration site analysis revealed minimal vector integration, with no observations of clonal outgrowth or preferred integrations in genes previously implicated in hepatocellular carcinoma formation within the observation period. These preclinical studies demonstrate a good safety and efficacy profile for TAK-754.
Overview: The provided abstract for this study does not match its title. The abstract describes the successful preclinical development of TAK-754, a gene therapy vector for hemophilia A, showing it increases Factor VIII activity and corrects bleeding in mice with a good safety profile. This research is significant for hematology and gene therapy. The title, however, suggests the study is about how skeletal unloading affects the antibody repertoire in mice after vaccination, a completely different topic related to space immunology.
Summary:
Background: (Based on the abstract) Developing a safe and effective gene therapy for hemophilia A is a critical clinical goal. This study reports on the preclinical development of TAK-754, an AAV8-based vector designed to deliver the human factor VIII (FVIII) gene to the liver.

Methods: (Based on the abstract) The efficacy of TAK-754 was tested in FVIII knockout mice by measuring plasma FVIII activity and blood loss in a hemostatic efficacy assay. Long-term expression was assessed in immunologically tolerant mice. Toxicology and biodistribution were evaluated in C57BL/6J mice after a single administration at various doses, including an analysis of vector integration sites.

Results: (Based on the abstract) TAK-754 produced a dose-dependent increase in FVIII activity, reduced blood loss, and mediated long-term, stable FVIII expression. The therapy showed a good safety profile with no adverse clinical signs. The vector was predominantly detected in the liver and showed minimal genomic integration, with no evidence of clonal outgrowth or preferential integration into cancer-associated genes.

Conclusions: (Based on the abstract) The preclinical studies demonstrate a good safety and efficacy profile for the TAK-754 gene therapy vector, supporting its further development for treating hemophilia A. (Note: The provided title 'Effects of skeletal unloading on the antibody repertoire...' is not addressed by the abstract.)

Title: An Analysis of the Effects of Spaceflight and Vaccination on Antibody Repertoire Diversity
Abstract: Ab repertoire diversity plays a critical role in the host’s ability to fight pathogens. CDR3 is partially responsible for Ab–Ag binding and is a significant source of diversity in the repertoire. CDR3 diversity is generated during VDJ rearrangement because of gene segment selection, gene segment trimming and splicing, and the addition of nucleotides. We analyzed the Ab repertoire diversity across multiple experiments examining the effects of spaceflight on the Ab repertoire after vaccination. Five datasets from four experiments were analyzed using rank-abundance curves and Shannon indices as measures of diversity. We discovered a trend toward lower diversity as a result of spaceflight but did not find the same decrease in our physiological model of microgravity in either the spleen or bone marrow. However, the bone marrow repertoire showed a reduction in diversity after vaccination. We also detected differences in Shannon indices between experiments and tissues. We did not detect a pattern of CDR3 usage across the experiments. Overall, we were able to find differences in the Ab repertoire diversity across experimental groups and tissues.
Overview: This study provides a nuanced analysis of how spaceflight and vaccination impact the diversity of the antibody repertoire, a key measure of immune health. By comparing data from four different experiments, including spaceflight and ground-based unloading models, the researchers found a trend toward lower antibody diversity as a result of actual spaceflight. This is an important finding for space medicine, as it suggests that the space environment may constrain the immune system's ability to respond to new threats, although this effect was not replicated in the physiological models on the ground.
Summary:
Background: The diversity of the antibody (Ab) repertoire is critical for fighting pathogens. This study aimed to analyze how this diversity is affected by spaceflight and vaccination, using data from multiple experiments.

Methods: The researchers analyzed five datasets from four different experiments that examined the effects of spaceflight, a ground-based physiological model of microgravity (skeletal unloading), and vaccination on the antibody repertoire. They used rank-abundance curves and Shannon indices, which are metrics of diversity, to compare the Ab repertoires across different experimental groups and tissues (spleen and bone marrow).

Results: The analysis revealed a trend toward lower Ab repertoire diversity as a result of spaceflight. However, a similar decrease in diversity was not observed in the ground-based microgravity model in either the spleen or the bone marrow. In the bone marrow, vaccination was found to cause a reduction in diversity. There were also differences in diversity detected between the different experiments and between the two tissues. No consistent pattern of CDR3 usage was detected across the experiments.

Conclusions: The study found differences in antibody repertoire diversity across various experimental groups and tissues, with a notable trend of reduced diversity after actual spaceflight. This suggests that spaceflight may have a unique impact on the immune system that is not fully captured by ground-based analogs.

Title: Effects of spaceflight aboard the International Space Station on mouse estrous cycle and ovarian gene expression
Abstract: Ovarian steroids dramatically impact normal homeostatic and metabolic processes of most tissues within the body, including muscle, bone, neural, immune, cardiovascular, and reproductive systems. Determining the effects of spaceflight on the ovary and estrous cycle is, therefore, critical to our understanding of all spaceflight experiments using female mice. Adult female mice (n = 10) were exposed to and sacrificed on-orbit after 37 days of spaceflight in microgravity. Contemporary control (preflight baseline, vivarium, and habitat; n = 10/group) groups were maintained at the Kennedy Space Center, prior to sacrifice and similar tissue collection at the NASA Ames Research Center. Ovarian tissues were collected and processed for RNA and steroid analyses at initial carcass thaw. Vaginal wall tissue collected from twice frozen/thawed carcasses was fixed for estrous cycle stage determinations. The proportion of animals in each phase of the estrous cycle (i.e., proestrus, estrus, metestrus, and diestrus) did not appreciably differ between baseline, vivarium, and flight mice, while habitat control mice exhibited greater numbers in diestrus. Ovarian tissue steroid concentrations indicated no differences in estradiol across groups, while progesterone levels were lower (p < 0.05) in habitat and flight compared to baseline females. Genes involved in ovarian steroidogenic function were not differentially expressed across groups. As ovarian estrogen can dramatically impact multiple non-reproductive tissues, these data support vaginal wall estrous cycle classification of all female mice flown in space. Additionally, since females exposed to long-term spaceflight were observed at different estrous cycle stages, this indicates females are likely undergoing ovarian cyclicity and may yet be fertile.
Overview: This study is crucial for all spaceflight research involving female mice, as it investigates the impact of long-duration spaceflight on the estrous cycle and ovarian function. Researchers found that despite some hormonal changes, female mice flown for 37 days on the ISS appeared to continue cycling. This finding is vital because it underscores the necessity of accounting for the hormonal status of female animals to ensure the accurate interpretation of data from any spaceflight experiment, as ovarian steroids impact nearly every tissue.
Summary:
Background: Ovarian steroids dramatically impact the normal function of most tissues, including muscle, bone, and the immune system. Therefore, understanding the effects of spaceflight on the ovary and estrous cycle is critical for interpreting data from any spaceflight experiment using female mice.

Methods: Ovarian and vaginal tissues were collected from adult female mice that were sacrificed on-orbit after 37 days of spaceflight. These were compared to several ground control groups (preflight baseline, vivarium, and habitat-matched). Vaginal wall tissue was used for histological determination of the estrous cycle stage, while ovarian tissues were analyzed for steroid concentrations and the expression of genes involved in steroid production.

Results: The proportion of animals in each phase of the estrous cycle (proestrus, estrus, metestrus, diestrus) did not differ significantly between flight mice and baseline controls, although habitat control mice showed a greater number in diestrus. Ovarian progesterone levels were lower in flight mice compared to baseline, but estradiol levels were unchanged. Genes involved in ovarian steroidogenic function were not differentially expressed.

Conclusions: The observation of females in different estrous cycle stages after long-term spaceflight indicates that they are likely undergoing ovarian cyclicity and may remain fertile. The authors strongly recommend that vaginal wall estrous cycle classification be performed for all female mice flown in space, as hormonal status can dramatically impact the interpretation of data from non-reproductive tissues.

Title: Effect of spaceflight on Pseudomonas aeruginosa final cell density is modulated by nutrient and oxygen availability.
Abstract: BackgroundAbundant populations of bacteria have been observed on Mir and the International Space Station. While some experiments have shown that bacteria cultured during spaceflight exhibit a range of potentially troublesome characteristics, including increases in growth, antibiotic resistance and virulence, other studies have shown minimal differences when cells were cultured during spaceflight or on Earth. Although the final cell density of bacteria grown during spaceflight has been reported for several species, we are not yet able to predict how different microorganisms will respond to the microgravity environment. In order to build our understanding of how spaceflight affects bacterial final cell densities, additional studies are needed to determine whether the observed differences are due to varied methods, experimental conditions, or organism specific responses. ResultsHere, we have explored how phosphate concentration, carbon source, oxygen availability, and motility affect the growth of Pseudomonas aeruginosa in modified artificial urine media during spaceflight. We observed that P. aeruginosa grown during spaceflight exhibited increased final cell density relative to normal gravity controls when low concentrations of phosphate in the media were combined with decreased oxygen availability. In contrast, when the availability of either phosphate or oxygen was increased, no difference in final cell density was observed between spaceflight and normal gravity. Because motility has been suggested to affect how microbes respond to microgravity, we compared the growth of wild-type P. aeruginosa to a ΔmotABCD mutant deficient in swimming motility. However, the final cell densities observed with the motility mutant were consistent with those observed with wild type for all conditions tested. ConclusionsThese results indicate that differences in bacterial final cell densities observed between spaceflight and normal gravity are due to an interplay between microgravity conditions and the availability of substrates essential for growth. Further, our results suggest that microbes grown under nutrient-limiting conditions are likely to reach higher cell densities under microgravity conditions than they would on Earth. Considering that the majority of bacteria inhabiting spacecrafts and space stations are likely to live under nutrient limitations, our findings highlight the need to explore the impact microgravity and other aspects of the spaceflight environment have on microbial growth and physiology.
Conclusion: Our findings indicate that differences in P. aeruginosa final cell densities observed between spaceflight and normal gravity are due to an interplay between changes in mixing and transport that occur under microgravity conditions and the availability of substrates essential for growth. These results may improve our ability to predict how different microbes will respond to microgravity and how combinations of environmental and genetic factors affect important behaviors, such as growth and virulence, both during spaceflight and on Earth. Here, we have shown that the microgravity environment encountered during spaceflight appears to allow cells to grow better with limited resources when compared to similar conditions on Earth. Considering the majority of bacteria, including those that are found on spacecrafts and space stations, live in nutrient-limited environments, this finding highlights the need for ongoing studies of how these effects may affect crew health during long-term spaceflight.
Overview: This study provides key insights into how bacteria might behave in resource-limited spacecraft environments. It demonstrates that for Pseudomonas aeruginosa, the increased final cell density often seen in spaceflight only occurs under specific conditions of low phosphate and limited oxygen. This finding is important because it shows that the microbial response to microgravity is not universal but is context-dependent, helping to predict and manage microbial risks during long-term missions.
Summary:
Background: Previous spaceflight experiments have shown inconsistent results regarding bacterial growth, with some studies showing increases and others showing minimal differences. This study aimed to understand how environmental factors like nutrient and oxygen availability modulate the growth response of Pseudomonas aeruginosa to spaceflight.

Methods: P. aeruginosa was grown during spaceflight in a modified artificial urine medium with varying phosphate concentrations, carbon sources, and oxygen availability. A mutant deficient in swimming motility was also tested to see if motility played a role. Final cell density was compared between spaceflight and normal gravity controls using flow cytometry.

Results: P. aeruginosa grown in spaceflight reached a higher final cell density compared to ground controls only when both phosphate concentration was low and oxygen availability was decreased. When either phosphate or oxygen was abundant, no difference in growth was observed. The motility mutant showed the same responses as the wild-type, indicating motility was not a factor in this outcome.

Conclusions: The findings indicate that differences in P. aeruginosa final cell densities between spaceflight and normal gravity are due to an interplay between changes in mixing that occur in microgravity and the availability of essential growth substrates. The results suggest that microbes in nutrient-limited environments, which are common in spacecraft, are likely to reach higher cell densities in microgravity than they would on Earth.

Title: Spaceflight promotes biofilm formation by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
Abstract: Understanding the effects of spaceflight on microbial communities is crucial for the success of long-term, manned space missions. Surface-associated bacterial communities, known as biofilms, were abundant on the Mir space station and continue to be a challenge on the International Space Station. The health and safety hazards linked to the development of biofilms are of particular concern due to the suppression of immune function observed during spaceflight. While planktonic cultures of microbes have indicated that spaceflight can lead to increases in growth and virulence, the effects of spaceflight on biofilm development and physiology remain unclear. To address this issue, Pseudomonas aeruginosa was cultured during two Space Shuttle Atlantis missions: STS-132 and STS-135, and the biofilms formed during spaceflight were characterized. Spaceflight was observed to increase the number of viable cells, biofilm biomass, and thickness relative to normal gravity controls. Moreover, the biofilms formed during spaceflight exhibited a column-and-canopy structure that has not been observed on Earth. The increase in the amount of biofilms and the formation of the novel architecture during spaceflight were observed to be independent of carbon source and phosphate concentrations in the media. However, flagella-driven motility was shown to be essential for the formation of this biofilm architecture during spaceflight. These findings represent the first evidence that spaceflight affects community-level behaviors of bacteria and highlight the importance of understanding how both harmful and beneficial human-microbe interactions may be altered during spaceflight.
Overview: This research provides the first direct evidence that spaceflight promotes the formation of bacterial biofilms, a finding with significant implications for astronaut health and spacecraft maintenance. By culturing Pseudomonas aeruginosa during two Space Shuttle missions, researchers observed not only an increase in biofilm mass and thickness but also the formation of a novel 'column-and-canopy' structure not seen on Earth. This highlights how microgravity can alter community-level bacterial behaviors, which is critical for assessing risks from both harmful and beneficial microbes on long-term missions.
Summary:
Background: Bacterial biofilms were a known issue on past and present space stations, posing health and safety hazards. While the effects of spaceflight on individual (planktonic) bacteria had been studied, its impact on the development and physiology of these surface-associated communities was unclear.

Methods: Pseudomonas aeruginosa was cultured in specialized hardware during two Space Shuttle Atlantis missions (STS-132 and STS-135). The resulting biofilms were characterized and compared to normal gravity controls. The analyses included measuring the number of viable cells, total biofilm biomass, and thickness. The structure of the biofilms was also examined. The roles of nutrient availability and flagella-driven motility were investigated.

Results: Biofilms formed during spaceflight had a significantly greater number of viable cells, more biomass, and were thicker than ground controls. They also exhibited a unique 'column-and-canopy' architecture that has not been observed in Earth-based experiments. This effect was found to be independent of the nutrient concentrations in the media but was dependent on flagella-driven motility.

Conclusions: This study presents the first evidence that spaceflight affects community-level behaviors in bacteria. The findings highlight the importance of understanding how human-microbe interactions, including the formation of potentially harmful biofilms, may be altered during spaceflight.

Title: GeneLab: Omics database for spaceflight experiments
Abstract: Summary With the development of transcriptomic technologies, we are able to quantify precise changes in gene expression profiles from astronauts and other organisms exposed to spaceflight. Members of NASA GeneLab and GeneLab-associated analysis working groups (AWGs) have developed a consensus pipeline for analyzing short-read RNA-sequencing data from spaceflight-associated experiments. The pipeline includes quality control, read trimming, mapping, and gene quantification steps, culminating in the detection of differentially expressed genes. This data analysis pipeline and the results of its execution using data submitted to GeneLab are now all publicly available through the GeneLab database. We present here the full details and rationale for the construction of this pipeline in order to promote transparency, reproducibility, and reusability of pipeline data; to provide a template for data processing of future spaceflight-relevant datasets; and to encourage cross-analysis of data from other databases with the data available in GeneLab.
Overview: This paper is an essential guide for researchers working with spaceflight transcriptomic data, as it details the standardized RNA-sequencing analysis pipeline developed by NASA's GeneLab and its associated working groups. By providing a transparent and reproducible consensus pipeline—covering everything from quality control to differential gene expression—the authors aim to standardize data processing across the field. This promotes cross-analysis of diverse spaceflight experiments and ensures the reusability of valuable omics data.
Summary:
Background: The ability to quantify changes in gene expression through transcriptomic technologies is a powerful tool for understanding the biological effects of spaceflight. To ensure consistency and comparability across different experiments, NASA's GeneLab and its Analysis Working Groups (AWGs) developed a consensus pipeline for processing short-read RNA-sequencing data.

Methods: The paper describes the rationale and full details of the developed data analysis pipeline. The pipeline includes standardized steps for quality control, read trimming, mapping to a reference genome, gene quantification, and finally, the detection of differentially expressed genes between experimental conditions.

Results: The standardized pipeline has been implemented and executed on the data submitted to the GeneLab database. The resulting processed data, along with the pipeline itself, are now publicly available through the GeneLab repository. This allows any researcher to use the same standardized methods for their own analysis or for cross-comparison with existing datasets.

Conclusions: The authors present the consensus pipeline to promote transparency, reproducibility, and reusability of spaceflight-associated omics data. It is intended to serve as a template for processing future datasets and to encourage the broader research community to perform cross-analyses with the wealth of data available in GeneLab.

Title: NASA GeneLab: Interfaces for the exploration of space omics data
Abstract: Abstract The mission of NASA’s GeneLab database (https://genelab.nasa.gov/) is to collect, curate, and provide access to the genomic, transcriptomic, proteomic and metabolomic (so-called ‘omics’) data from biospecimens flown in space or exposed to simulated space stressors, maximizing their utilization. This large collection of data enables the exploration of molecular network responses to space environments using a systems biology approach. We review here the various components of the GeneLab platform, including the new data repository web interface, and the GeneLab Online Data Entry (GEODE) web portal, which will support the expansion of the database in the future to include companion non-omics assay data. We discuss our design for GEODE, particularly how it promotes investigators providing more accurate metadata, reducing the curation effort required of GeneLab staff. We also introduce here a new GeneLab Application Programming Interface (API) specifically designed to support tools for the visualization of processed omics data. We review the outreach efforts by GeneLab to utilize the spaceflight data in the repository to generate novel discoveries and develop new hypotheses, including spearheading data analysis working groups, and a high school student training program. All these efforts are aimed ultimately at supporting precision risk management for human space exploration.
Overview: This article is a key resource for any scientist interested in space biology, as it provides a comprehensive overview of NASA's GeneLab platform, a critical open-science repository for space omics data. The paper details the various components of the platform, including its data repository, a new data entry portal (GEODE) designed to improve metadata quality, and a new API for data visualization. By reviewing GeneLab's interfaces and outreach efforts, the authors showcase how the platform is enabling systems biology approaches to maximize scientific discovery and support risk management for human space exploration.
Summary:
Background: NASA’s GeneLab is a database designed to collect, curate, and provide public access to omics data (genomic, transcriptomic, proteomic, metabolomic) from biological specimens exposed to spaceflight or simulated space stressors. The goal is to maximize the scientific utilization of these valuable datasets.

Methods: This paper reviews the various components and interfaces of the GeneLab platform. It describes the design of the new data repository web interface and the GeneLab Online Data Entry (GEODE) portal, which is intended to streamline the submission of data and metadata. It also introduces a new Application Programming Interface (API) for data visualization and discusses GeneLab's outreach activities, such as analysis working groups.

Results: The review details the features of the GeneLab platform. The GEODE portal is highlighted as a tool to promote more accurate metadata submission from investigators, reducing the curation burden. The new API is presented as a way to support the development of tools for visualizing processed omics data. The success of outreach efforts in generating new discoveries from the repository's data is also discussed.

Conclusions: The GeneLab platform, with its various interfaces and community engagement, is a powerful tool for exploring the molecular responses of biological systems to the space environment. The ultimate aim of these efforts is to enable a systems biology approach that will support precision risk management for human space exploration.

Title: Comprehensive multi-omics analysis reveals mitochondrial stress as a central biological hub for spaceflight impact
Abstract: Summary Spaceflight is known to impose changes on human physiology with unknown molecular etiologies. To reveal these causes, we used a multi-omics, systems biology analytical approach using biomedical profiles from fifty-nine astronauts and data from NASA’s GeneLab derived from hundreds of samples flown in space, to determine transcriptomic, proteomic, metabolomic, and epigenetic responses to spaceflight. Overall pathway analyses on the multi-omic datasets showed significant enrichment for mitochondrial processes, as well as innate immunity, chronic inflammation, cell cycle, circadian rhythm, and olfactory functions. Importantly, NASA’s Twin Study provided a platform to confirm several of our principal findings. Evidence of altered mitochondrial function and DNA damage was also found in the urine and blood metabolic data compiled from the astronaut cohort and NASA Twin Study data, indicating mitochondrial stress as a consistent phenotype of spaceflight.
Overview: This landmark study presents a comprehensive, multi-omics systems biology analysis that identifies mitochondrial stress as a central biological hub for the impact of spaceflight. By integrating transcriptomic, proteomic, metabolomic, and epigenetic data from astronauts and hundreds of space-flown samples in NASA's GeneLab, the research reveals that altered mitochondrial function is a consistent and overarching theme. This is a critical read for space medicine, as it provides a unifying biological principle for the diverse physiological changes seen in space and points to a key target for countermeasures.
Summary:
Background: Spaceflight is known to cause a range of physiological changes in humans, but the underlying molecular causes are not well understood. This study aimed to identify these causes using a large-scale, multi-omics, systems biology approach.

Methods: The researchers conducted a comprehensive analysis using biomedical profiles from 59 astronauts, including data from NASA’s Twin Study, and integrated them with hundreds of transcriptomic, proteomic, metabolomic, and epigenetic datasets from space-flown samples in NASA’s GeneLab repository. This allowed for an overall pathway analysis across different data types and organisms.

Results: The integrated, multi-omic analysis consistently showed significant enrichment for mitochondrial processes across the datasets. Other significantly enriched pathways included innate immunity, chronic inflammation, cell cycle, and circadian rhythm. The findings from the broader analysis were confirmed in the specific data from the NASA Twin Study. Evidence of altered mitochondrial function and DNA damage was also found in the urine and blood metabolic data from the astronaut cohort.

Conclusions: The study concludes that mitochondrial stress is a consistent and central biological phenotype of the response to spaceflight. This finding provides a unifying molecular mechanism that could underlie many of the diverse physiological changes observed in astronauts.

Title: A New Era for Space Life Science: International Standards for Space Omics Processing
Abstract: Summary Space agencies have announced plans for human missions to the Moon to prepare for Mars. However, the space environment presents stressors that include radiation, microgravity, and isolation. Understanding how these factors affect biology is crucial for safe and effective crewed space exploration. There is a need to develop countermeasures, to adapt plants and microbes for nutrient sources and bioregenerative life support, and to limit pathogen infection. Scientists across the world are conducting space omics experiments on model organisms and, more recently, on humans. Optimal extraction of actionable scientific discoveries from these precious datasets will only occur at the collective level with improved standardization. To address this shortcoming, we established ISSOP (International Standards for Space Omics Processing), an international consortium of scientists who aim to enhance standard guidelines between space biologists at a global level. Here we introduce our consortium and share past lessons learned and future challenges related to spaceflight omics.
Overview: This paper marks a pivotal moment for space life sciences, announcing the formation of the International Standards for Space Omics Processing (ISSOP) consortium. It is an essential read for researchers in the field as it addresses the critical need for standardization in how space omics experiments are conducted and how data is processed. By sharing lessons learned and outlining future challenges, the consortium aims to create global guidelines that will enhance collaboration and maximize the scientific discoveries from precious spaceflight datasets.
Summary:
Background: As human space exploration plans expand, understanding the biological effects of the space environment is crucial. Scientists worldwide are conducting space omics experiments, but a lack of standardization hinders the ability to compare and integrate these valuable datasets for optimal scientific return.

Methods: This paper introduces the International Standards for Space Omics Processing (ISSOP), an international consortium of scientists. The authors discuss the rationale for the consortium's formation, share lessons learned from past space omics experiments (such as the NASA Twins Study), and outline the challenges that need to be addressed to improve standardization.

Results: The paper serves as a mission statement for the ISSOP. It highlights the shortcomings of the current lack of standards and proposes a collaborative, international effort to establish them. The goal is to enhance standard guidelines for experimental design, sample processing, data analysis, and metadata collection among space biologists at a global level.

Conclusions: The consortium aims to improve the quality and interoperability of space omics data. By establishing international standards, ISSOP will help ensure that data from diverse experiments can be more effectively combined and analyzed, leading to a more rapid and comprehensive understanding of how biology adapts to space.

Title: Knowledge Network Embedding of Transcriptomic Data from Spaceflown Mice Uncovers Signs and Symptoms Associated with Terrestrial Diseases
Abstract: There has long been an interest in understanding how the hazards from spaceflight may trigger or exacerbate human diseases. With the goal of advancing our knowledge on physiological changes during space travel, NASA GeneLab provides an open-source repository of multi-omics data from real and simulated spaceflight studies. Alone, this data enables identification of biological changes during spaceflight, but cannot infer how that may impact an astronaut at the phenotypic level. To bridge this gap, Scalable Precision Medicine Oriented Knowledge Engine (SPOKE), a heterogeneous knowledge graph connecting biological and clinical data from over 30 databases, was used in combination with GeneLab transcriptomic data from six studies. This integration identified critical symptoms and physiological changes incurred during spaceflight.
Overview: This study showcases an innovative approach to translational space medicine by linking molecular data from space-flown mice to human disease symptoms. By integrating NASA GeneLab transcriptomic data with a vast biomedical knowledge graph (SPOKE), researchers were able to predict the physiological changes and symptoms that might arise from the gene expression patterns observed in space. This is a powerful demonstration of how knowledge network embedding can bridge the gap between animal model data and human clinical outcomes, helping to better understand the health risks of space travel.
Summary:
Background: Understanding how the molecular changes induced by spaceflight might translate into human disease symptoms is a major goal of space medicine. NASA GeneLab provides a repository of molecular data from spaceflight studies, but connecting this data to phenotypic outcomes is a challenge.

Methods: The researchers used a heterogeneous knowledge graph called the Scalable Precision Medicine Oriented Knowledge Engine (SPOKE), which connects biological and clinical data from over 30 databases. They integrated transcriptomic data from six GeneLab studies of space-flown mice into this knowledge network. This integration allowed them to identify connections between the differentially expressed genes in the mice and known human symptoms, diseases, and physiological changes.

Results: The integration of GeneLab data with the SPOKE knowledge graph successfully identified critical symptoms and physiological changes that are known to be incurred during spaceflight. This process effectively translated the molecular signatures from the mouse model into relevant human clinical phenotypes.

Conclusions: This study demonstrates that knowledge network embedding is a powerful tool for bridging the gap between molecular data from animal models and potential human health outcomes. This approach can be used to advance our understanding of the physiological risks associated with space travel.

Title: Spatially resolved multiomics on the neuronal effects induced by spaceflight in mice
Abstract: Impairment of the central nervous system (CNS) poses a significant health risk for astronauts during long-duration space missions. In this study, we employed an innovative approach by integrating single-cell multiomics (transcriptomics and chromatin accessibility) with spatial transcriptomics to elucidate the impact of spaceflight on the mouse brain in female mice. Our comparative analysis between ground control and spaceflight-exposed animals revealed significant alterations in essential brain processes including neurogenesis, synaptogenesis and synaptic transmission, particularly affecting the cortex, hippocampus, striatum and neuroendocrine structures. Additionally, we observed astrocyte activation and signs of immune dysfunction. At the pathway level, some spaceflight-induced changes in the brain exhibit similarities with neurodegenerative disorders, marked by oxidative stress and protein misfolding. Our integrated spatial multiomics approach serves as a stepping stone towards understanding spaceflight-induced CNS impairments at the level of individual brain regions and cell types, and provides a basis for comparison in future spaceflight studies. For broader scientific impact, all datasets from this study are available through an interactive data portal, as well as the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) Open Science Data Repository (OSDR).
Overview: This study offers an unprecedented high-resolution view of the mouse brain's response to spaceflight, making it a landmark paper for space neuroscience. By integrating single-cell multi-omics with spatial transcriptomics, researchers have mapped the specific cellular and molecular alterations in different brain regions. The findings reveal significant changes in processes like neurogenesis and synaptic transmission, along with astrocyte activation and signs of immune dysfunction. This detailed map provides a crucial foundation for understanding and mitigating the neurological risks of long-duration space missions.
Summary:
Background: Impairment of the central nervous system (CNS) is a significant health risk for astronauts on long-duration missions. This study aimed to elucidate the impact of spaceflight on the mouse brain at the level of individual brain regions and cell types.

Methods: The researchers used an innovative, integrated approach combining single-cell multi-omics (simultaneously measuring transcriptomics and chromatin accessibility) with spatial transcriptomics. This allowed them to analyze gene expression and regulation in specific cell types and map these changes to their physical locations within the brain of female mice exposed to spaceflight compared to ground controls.

Results: The comparative analysis revealed significant alterations in essential brain processes, including neurogenesis, synaptogenesis, and synaptic transmission. These changes particularly affected the cortex, hippocampus, striatum, and neuroendocrine structures. Additionally, the study observed signs of astrocyte activation and immune dysfunction. At the pathway level, some of the spaceflight-induced changes showed similarities to those seen in neurodegenerative disorders, such as oxidative stress and protein misfolding.

Conclusions: This integrated spatial multi-omics approach provides a detailed stepping stone for understanding spaceflight-induced CNS impairments at a cellular and regional level. It serves as a basis for comparison in future studies and all datasets have been made publicly available through an interactive data portal and the NASA Open Science Data Repository (OSDR) to facilitate broader scientific impact.

Title: Inspiration4 data access through the NASA Open Science Data Repository
Abstract: The increasing accessibility of commercial and private space travel necessitates a profound understanding of its impact on human health. The NASA Open Science Data Repository (OSDR) provides transparent and FAIR access to biological studies, notably the SpaceX Inspiration4 (I4) mission, which amassed extensive data from civilian astronauts. This dataset encompasses omics and clinical assays, facilitating comprehensive research on space-induced biological responses. These data allow for multi-modal, longitudinal assessments, bridging the gap between human and model organism studies. Crucially, community-driven data standards established by NASA’s OSDR Analysis Working Groups empower artificial intelligence and machine learning to glean invaluable insights, guiding future mission planning and health risk mitigation. This article presents a concise guide to access and analyze I4 data in OSDR, including programmatic access through GLOpenAPI. This pioneering effort establishes a precedent for post-mission health monitoring programs within space agencies, propelling research in the burgeoning field of commercial space travel’s impact on human physiology.
Overview: This article is an essential guide for researchers wanting to access and analyze the groundbreaking biomedical data from the SpaceX Inspiration4 mission, the first all-civilian orbital flight. It details how to access this rich dataset of omics and clinical assays through NASA's Open Science Data Repository (OSDR) and its API. By making these multi-modal, longitudinal data from civilian astronauts FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable), this effort sets a new standard for post-mission health monitoring and propels research into the health impacts of commercial space travel.
Summary:
Background: The rise of commercial space travel necessitates a deep understanding of its impact on human health. The SpaceX Inspiration4 (I4) mission generated a vast and valuable dataset from its civilian crew, which has been made publicly available through NASA's Open Science Data Repository (OSDR) to facilitate research.

Methods: This article provides a concise guide on how to access and analyze the I4 data within the OSDR. It details the types of data available (omics and clinical assays) and explains how to use programmatic access through the GLOpenAPI. The paper emphasizes how the data standards established by NASA's OSDR Analysis Working Groups enable the use of AI and machine learning for data analysis.

Results: The paper presents the I4 dataset as a key resource for comprehensive, multi-modal, and longitudinal assessments of the biological responses to spaceflight. It highlights the dataset's value in bridging the gap between human and model organism studies and its potential for yielding new insights through advanced computational analysis.

Conclusions: This pioneering effort to make the I4 data transparently and FAIRly accessible establishes a precedent for post-mission health monitoring programs within space agencies. It provides a crucial resource for propelling research in the burgeoning field of commercial space travel and its impact on human physiology, guiding future mission planning and health risk mitigation.

Title: NASA GeneLab derived microarray studies of Mus musculus and Homo sapiens organisms in altered gravitational conditions.
Abstract: One of the greatest challenges of humanity for deep space exploration is to fully understand how altered gravitational conditions affect human physiology. It is evident that the spaceflight environment causes multiple alterations to musculoskeletal, cardiovascular, immune and central nervous systems, to name a few known effects. To better characterize these biological effects, we compare gene expression datasets from microarray studies found in NASA GeneLab, part of the NASA Open Science Data Repository. In this review, we summarize these archived results for various tissues, emphasizing key genes which are highly reproducible in different mice or human experiments. Such exhaustive mining shows the potential of NASA Open Science data to identify and validate mechanisms taking place when mammalian organisms are exposed to microgravity or other spaceflight conditions. Our comparative meta-analysis findings highlight certain degrees of overlap and reproducibility in genes identified as differentially expressed within musculoskeletal tissues in each species across a variety of altered gravity conditions. However, the level of overlap between species was found to be significantly limited, partly attributed to the limited availability of human samples.
Overview: This review provides a valuable meta-analysis of microarray gene expression studies from NASA's GeneLab, comparing the biological effects of altered gravity on mice and humans. It is an important read for space biologists as it highlights both the power and the limitations of cross-species comparisons. While the analysis confirms reproducible gene expression changes within musculoskeletal tissues for each species, it finds that the overlap between mouse and human responses is significantly limited, underscoring the challenges in translating findings from animal models to astronauts.
Summary:
Background: Understanding how altered gravity affects human physiology is a major challenge for space exploration. NASA's GeneLab provides a repository of gene expression datasets from spaceflight and ground-based experiments that can be mined to identify and validate biological mechanisms.

Methods: This paper reviews and summarizes archived gene expression datasets from microarray studies on Mus musculus (mouse) and Homo sapiens (human) found in the NASA GeneLab. The researchers performed a comparative meta-analysis, emphasizing the identification of key genes that are reproducibly altered in different experiments within the same species and then comparing the responses between species.

Results: The comparative meta-analysis revealed a certain degree of overlap and reproducibility in the genes identified as differentially expressed within the musculoskeletal tissues of each species across various altered gravity conditions. However, when comparing the responses between mice and humans, the level of overlap was found to be significantly limited. This was partly attributed to the limited availability of human samples.

Conclusions: This exhaustive data mining demonstrates the potential of NASA's Open Science data to identify and validate mechanisms that occur when mammalian organisms are exposed to microgravity. However, it also highlights the significant limitations in directly translating gene expression responses from mice to humans, emphasizing the need for more human data and careful interpretation of animal model results.

Title: Celebrating 30 years of access to NASA space life sciences data
Abstract: Abstract NASA’s space life sciences research programs established a decades-long legacy of enhancing our ability to safely explore the cosmos. From Skylab and the Space Shuttle Program to the NASA Balloon Program and the International Space Station National Lab, these programs generated priceless data that continue to paint a vibrant picture of life in space. These data are available to the scientific community in various data repositories, including the NASA Ames Life Sciences Data Archive (ALSDA) and NASA GeneLab. Here we recognize the 30-year anniversary of data access through ALSDA and the 10-year anniversary of GeneLab.
Overview: This article commemorates a significant milestone for open science in space life sciences: the 30th anniversary of the Ames Life Sciences Data Archive (ALSDA) and the 10th anniversary of GeneLab. It is a valuable read for the research community as it celebrates the decades-long legacy of NASA's commitment to making priceless data from missions like Skylab, the Space Shuttle, and the ISS accessible. By highlighting these pioneering data repositories, the paper underscores the critical role that open data access plays in painting a vibrant, collaborative picture of life in space.
Summary:
Background: NASA’s space life sciences research programs have generated invaluable data over several decades, contributing to our ability to explore space safely. This paper was written to recognize the 30-year anniversary of data access through the Ames Life Sciences Data Archive (ALSDA) and the 10-year anniversary of the GeneLab data repository.

Methods: This is a commemorative and perspective article. It reviews the history and legacy of NASA's life sciences programs, from early missions like Skylab and the Space Shuttle to the current International Space Station National Lab. It highlights the role of data repositories like ALSDA and GeneLab in making the data generated from these programs available to the scientific community.

Results: The article celebrates the decades-long commitment to open science that has allowed researchers worldwide to access and analyze data from NASA's space life sciences experiments. It emphasizes how these repositories have preserved a rich history of research and continue to support new discoveries about the effects of spaceflight on living organisms.

Conclusions: The paper recognizes the immense value of these long-standing data archives. It implicitly concludes that the principles of open and FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable) data, championed by these repositories, are fundamental to advancing our understanding of space biology and ensuring the success of future exploration missions.

Title: Dichotomous effects on lymphatic transport with loss of caveolae in mice.
Abstract: Aim:Fluid and macromolecule transport from the interstitium into and through lymphatic vessels is necessary for tissue homeostasis. While lymphatic capillary structure suggests that passive, paracellular transport would be the predominate route of macromolecule entry, active caveolae-mediated transcellular transport has been identified in lymphatic endothelial cells (LECs) in vitro. Caveolae also mediate a wide array of endothelial cell processes, including nitric oxide regulation. Thus, how does the lack of caveolae impact “lymphatic function”? Methods:Various aspects of lymphatic transport were measured in mice constitutively lacking caveolin-1 (“CavKO”), the protein required for caveolae formation in endothelial cells, and in mice with a LEC-specific Cav1 gene deletion (Lyve1-Cre x Cav1flox/flox; “LyCav”) and ex vivo in their vessels and cells. Results:In each model, lymphatic architecture was largely unchanged. The lymphatic conductance, or initial tissue uptake, was significantly higher in both CavKO mice and LyCav mice by quantitative microlymphangiography and the permeability to 70kDa dextran was significantly increased in monolayers of LECs isolated from CavKO mice. Conversely, transport within the lymphatic system to the sentinel node was significantly reduced in anesthetized CavKO and LyCav mice. Isolated, cannulated collecting vessel studies identified significantly reduced phasic contractility when lymphatic endothelium lacks caveolae. Inhibition of nitric oxide synthase was able to partially restore ex vivo vessel contractility. Conclusion:Macromolecule transport across lymphatics is increased with loss of caveolae, yet phasic contractility reduced, resulting in reduced overall lymphatic transport function. These studies identify lymphatic caveolar biology as a key regulator of active lymphatic transport functions.
Overview: This research uncovers a paradoxical role for caveolae (small invaginations in the cell membrane) in lymphatic function, which is critical for tissue fluid balance and immune surveillance. By studying mice lacking caveolin-1, the authors found that while the absence of caveolae increases the initial uptake of macromolecules into lymphatic vessels, it simultaneously impairs the pumping action of collecting vessels. This results in an overall reduction in lymphatic transport, identifying caveolar biology as a key, and complex, regulator of both lymphatic permeability and propulsion.
Summary:
Background: Lymphatic vessels are essential for transporting fluid and macromolecules from tissues back into circulation. While passive transport is thought to be the dominant route for macromolecule entry, active, caveolae-mediated transport has been identified in lymphatic endothelial cells (LECs) in vitro. This study aimed to determine how the lack of caveolae impacts overall lymphatic function in vivo.

Methods: The study used two mouse models: one constitutively lacking caveolin-1 (CavKO), the protein required for caveolae formation, and one with a LEC-specific deletion of the Cav1 gene (LyCav). Lymphatic transport was measured in vivo using quantitative microlymphangiography. The permeability of LEC monolayers was measured in vitro, and the phasic contractility of isolated collecting vessels was assessed ex vivo.

Results: In both mouse models, the initial tissue uptake of macromolecules into lymphatic capillaries was significantly higher in the absence of caveolae. Conversely, the transport of these macromolecules within the collecting lymphatic system to the sentinel lymph node was significantly reduced. Ex vivo studies of isolated collecting vessels revealed that vessels lacking caveolae had significantly reduced phasic contractility. This reduced contractility could be partially restored by inhibiting nitric oxide synthase.

Conclusions: The study identifies a dichotomous effect of losing caveolae on lymphatic function. Macromolecule transport across the initial lymphatic barrier is increased, yet the active propulsion of lymph through collecting vessels is reduced. This results in a net impairment of overall lymphatic transport, highlighting lymphatic caveolar biology as a key regulator of active lymphatic processes.

Title: Fungal diversity differences in the indoor dust microbiome from built environments on Earth and in space.
Abstract: Human occupied built environments are no longer confined to Earth. In fact, there have been humans living and working in low-Earth orbit on the International Space Station (ISS) since November 2000. With NASA’s Artemis missions and the age of commercial space stations set to begin, more human-occupied spacecraft than ever will be in Earth’s orbit and beyond. On Earth and in the ISS, microbes, especially fungi, can be found in dust and grow when unexpected, elevated moisture conditions occur. However, we do not yet know how indoor microbiomes in Earth-based homes and in the ISS differ due to their unique set of environmental conditions. Here we show that bacterial and fungal communities are different in dust collected from vacuum bags on Earth and the ISS, with Earth-based homes being more diverse (465 fungal OTUs and 237 bacterial ASVs) compared to the ISS (102 fungal OTUs and 102 bacterial ASVs). When dust from these locations were exposed to varying equilibrium relative humidity conditions (ERH), there were also significant fungal community composition changes as ERH and time elevated increased (Bray Curtis: R2 = 0.35, P = 0.001). These findings can inform future spacecraft design to promote healthy indoor microbiomes that support crew health, spacecraft integrity, and planetary protection.
Overview: This study provides a novel comparison of the fungal microbiomes in two unique built environments: homes on Earth and the International Space Station (ISS). Researchers found that the fungal diversity in ISS dust is significantly lower than in Earth-based homes. Importantly, they demonstrated that changes in relative humidity can rapidly alter the fungal community composition in dust from both environments. This is a crucial finding for spacecraft design and astronaut health, as it informs strategies for managing moisture to control microbial growth in closed habitats.
Summary:
Background: Human-occupied built environments, including the International Space Station (ISS), contain indoor microbiomes. While microbes like fungi are known to be present in dust and can grow in moist conditions, the differences between the microbiomes of Earth-based homes and the ISS are not well understood.

Methods: Dust was collected from vacuum bags used in homes on Earth and on the ISS. The bacterial and fungal communities in this dust were characterized. The dust samples were then exposed to varying equilibrium relative humidity (ERH) conditions over time to observe how moisture affects the microbial community composition, which was analyzed using sequencing techniques.

Results: The study found that Earth-based homes are more microbially diverse than the ISS, with 465 fungal OTUs and 237 bacterial ASVs compared to 102 fungal OTUs and 102 bacterial ASVs on the ISS. Exposure to elevated ERH and increased time caused significant changes in the fungal community composition in dust from both locations.

Conclusions: The findings can inform the design of future spacecraft to promote healthy indoor microbiomes. Understanding how humidity drives changes in the fungal community is critical for supporting crew health, maintaining spacecraft integrity, and ensuring planetary protection.

Title: Predicting how varying moisture conditions impact the microbiome of dust collected from the International Space Station
Abstract: BackgroundThe commercialization of space travel will soon lead to many more people living and working in unique built environments similar to the International Space Station, which is a specialized closed environment that contains its own indoor microbiome. Unintended microbial growth can occur in these environments as in buildings on Earth from elevated moisture, such as from a temporary ventilation system failure. This growth can drive negative health outcomes and degrade building materials. We need a predictive approach for modeling microbial growth in these critical indoor spaces. ResultsHere, we demonstrate that even short exposures to varying elevated relative humidity can facilitate rapid microbial growth and microbial community composition changes in dust from spacecraft. We modeled fungal growth in dust from the International Space Station using the time-of-wetness framework with activation and deactivation limited growth occurring at 85% and 100% relative humidity, respectively. Fungal concentrations ranged from an average of 4.4 × 106 spore equivalents per milligram of dust in original dust with no exposure to relative humidity to up to 2.1 × 1010 when exposed to 100% relative humidity for 2 weeks. As relative humidity and time-elevated increased, fungal diversity was significantly reduced for both alpha (Q < 0.05) and beta (R2 = 0.307, P = 0.001) diversity metrics. Bacteria were unable to be modeled using the time-of-wetness framework. However, bacterial communities did change based on constant relative humidity incubations for both beta (R2 = 0.22, P = 0.001) and alpha diversity decreasing with increasing moisture starting at 85% relative humidity (Q < 0.05). ConclusionOur results demonstrate that moisture conditions can be used to develop and predict changes in fungal growth and composition onboard human-occupied spacecraft. This predictive model can be expanded upon to include other spacecraft environmental factors such as microgravity, elevated carbon dioxide conditions, and radiation exposure. Understanding microbial growth in spacecraft can help better protect astronaut health, fortify spacecraft integrity, and promote planetary protection as human activity increases in low-Earth orbit, the moon, Mars, and beyond. Video Abstract Supplementary InformationThe online version contains supplementary material available at 10.1186/s40168-024-01864-3.
Conclusion: Our results provide important foundational knowledge for the prediction of fungal growth in future spacecraft, space stations, and surface habitats. The time-of-wetness framework, which utilizes varying ERH conditions, as shown in this study can be expanded and refined to incorporate other key environmental factors present in spaceflight. With the appropriate model based on time exposure to elevated relative humidity levels, we can predict how much and what type of microbial growth will be present in spacecraft dust during long-duration human space missions.
