We can continue to refine moisture control on spacecraft to preserve a healthy environment. As crewed commercial spacecraft and missions beyond low-Earth orbit become a reality, a better understanding of microbes onboard a spacecraft will protect human health and spacecraft integrity and aid in developing planetary protection protocols to prevent forward and/or backward microbial contamination of Earth and the other celestial bodies we will visit in the future [61].
Overview: This research provides a critical predictive tool for managing microbial risks on spacecraft, a key concern for long-duration missions. By exposing dust from the International Space Station (ISS) to varying moisture levels, the study demonstrates that even short periods of high humidity can cause rapid fungal growth and community shifts. Importantly, the authors successfully modeled this fungal growth using a 'time-of-wetness' framework, offering a way to predict and potentially prevent microbial blooms that could compromise astronaut health and spacecraft integrity.
Summary:
Background: Unintended microbial growth due to elevated moisture is a risk in closed built environments like the International Space Station (ISS), potentially affecting crew health and hardware. A predictive approach for modeling this growth is needed to manage these risks effectively.

Methods: Dust collected from the ISS was incubated under varying and constant elevated relative humidity (RH) conditions. Fungal and bacterial concentrations and community composition were measured. The researchers applied a 'time-of-wetness' framework to model the fungal growth dynamics based on the duration of exposure to high humidity.

Results: Even short exposures to elevated RH (85% and 100%) facilitated rapid microbial growth and significant changes in microbial community composition. Fungal growth was successfully modeled using the time-of-wetness framework, with fungal concentrations increasing by several orders of magnitude after two weeks at 100% RH. As humidity and time increased, fungal diversity was significantly reduced. Bacterial communities also changed with increasing moisture but could not be modeled with the same framework.

Conclusions: The results demonstrate that moisture conditions can be used to develop and predict changes in fungal growth and composition on spacecraft. This predictive model can be expanded to include other spaceflight factors like microgravity and radiation, helping to better protect astronaut health and spacecraft integrity on future missions.

Title: Aging and estrogen status: A possible endothelium-dependent vascular coupling mechanism in bone remodeling.
Abstract: Bone loss with aging and menopause may be linked to vascular endothelial dysfunction. The purpose of the study was to determine whether putative modifications in endothelium-dependent vasodilation of the principal nutrient artery (PNA) of the femur are associated with changes in trabecular bone volume (BV/TV) with altered estrogen status in young (6 mon) and old (24 mon) female Fischer-344 rats. Animals were divided into 6 groups: 1) young intact, 2) old intact, 3) young ovariectomized (OVX), 4) old OVX, 5) young OVX plus estrogen replacement (OVX+E2), and 6) old OVX+E2. PNA endothelium-dependent vasodilation was assessed in vitro using acetylcholine. Trabecular bone volume of the distal femoral metaphysis was determined by microCT. In young rats, vasodilation was diminished by OVX and restored with estrogen replacement (intact, 82±7; OVX, 61±9; OVX+E2, 90±4%), which corresponded with similar modifications in BV/TV (intact, 28.7±1.6; OVX, 16.3±0.9; OVX+E2, 25.7±1.4%). In old animals, vasodilation was unaffected by OVX but enhanced with estrogen replacement (intact, 55±8; OVX, 59±7; OVX+E2, 92±4%). Likewise, modifications in BV/TV followed the same pattern (intact, 33.1±1.6; OVX, 34.4±3.7; OVX+E2, 42.4±2.1%). Furthermore, in old animals with low endogenous estrogen (i.e., intact and old OVX), vasodilation was correlated with BV/TV (R2 = 0.630; P<0.001). These data demonstrate parallel effects of estrogen on vascular endothelial function and BV/TV, and provide for a possible coupling mechanism linking endothelium-dependent vasodilation to bone remodeling.
Overview: This study provides compelling evidence for a vascular coupling mechanism in bone remodeling, linking bone loss with aging and menopause to endothelial dysfunction. By comparing young and old rats with varying estrogen levels, researchers found a parallel effect of estrogen on both the vasodilation of the main femoral artery and the volume of trabecular bone. This is an important read because it suggests that maintaining vascular health could be a key strategy for preventing age-related and postmenopausal osteoporosis.
Summary:
Background: Bone loss associated with aging and menopause may be connected to a decline in the function of the vascular endothelium (the inner lining of blood vessels). This study aimed to determine if changes in the endothelium-dependent vasodilation of the femur's principal nutrient artery (PNA) are associated with changes in trabecular bone volume under different estrogen statuses.

Methods: Young (6-month) and old (24-month) female rats were divided into three groups each: intact, ovariectomized (OVX) to remove estrogen, and OVX with estrogen replacement (OVX+E2). The endothelium-dependent vasodilation of the PNA was assessed in vitro. Trabecular bone volume (BV/TV) of the distal femur was determined by microCT.

Results: In young rats, vasodilation and BV/TV were both diminished by OVX and restored by estrogen replacement, showing a clear parallel effect. In old animals, vasodilation was not affected by OVX but was significantly enhanced by estrogen replacement; BV/TV followed the same pattern. Furthermore, in old animals with naturally low estrogen (intact and OVX groups), there was a significant correlation between the level of vasodilation and the amount of trabecular bone.

Conclusions: The study demonstrates parallel effects of estrogen on vascular endothelial function and trabecular bone volume. This provides evidence for a possible coupling mechanism that links the health and function of the bone's blood supply to the process of bone remodeling.

Title: Chronic skeletal unloading of the rat femur: mechanisms and functional consequences of vascular remodeling.
Abstract: Chronic skeletal unloading diminishes hindlimb bone blood flow. The purpose of the present investigation was to determine 1) whether 7 and 14 days of skeletal unloading alters femoral bone and marrow blood flow and vascular resistance during reloading, and 2) whether putative changes in bone perfusion are associated with a gross structural remodeling of the principal nutrient artery (PNA) of the femur. Six-month old male Sprague-Dawley rats were assigned to 7-d or 14-d hindlimb unloading (HU) or weight-bearing control groups. Bone perfusion was measured following 10 min of standing (reloading) following the unloading treatment. Histomorphometry was used to determine PNA media wall thickness and maximal diameter. Bone blood flow, arterial pressure and PNA structural characteristics were used to calculate arterial shear stress and circumferential wall stress. During reloading, femoral perfusion was lower in the distal metaphyseal region of 7-d HU rats, and in the proximal and distal metaphyses, diaphysis and diaphyseal marrow of 14-d HU animals relative to that in control rats. Vascular resistance was also higher in all regions of the femur in 14-d HU rats during reloading relative to control animals. Intraluminal diameter of PNAs from 14-d HU rats (138 ± 5 μm) was smaller than that of control PNAs (162 ± 6 μm), and medial wall thickness was thinner in PNAs from 14-d HU (14.3 ± 0.6 μm) versus that of control (18.0 ± 0.8 μm) rats. Decreases in both shear stress and circumferential stress occurred in the PNA with HU that later returned to control levels with the reductions in PNA maximal diameter and wall thickness, respectively. The results demonstrate that chronic skeletal unloading attenuates the ability to increase blood flow and nutrient delivery to bone and marrow with immediate acute reloading due, in part, to a remodeling of the bone resistance vasculature.
Overview: This study reveals a critical mechanism behind reduced bone blood flow following periods of disuse, a finding relevant to conditions like prolonged bed rest and spaceflight. By subjecting rats to skeletal unloading, researchers demonstrated that the principal nutrient artery of the femur undergoes significant structural remodeling, becoming narrower and thinner-walled. This remodeling impairs the bone's ability to increase blood flow upon reloading, suggesting that vascular adaptation is a key contributor to the negative skeletal effects of chronic unloading.
Summary:
Background: Chronic skeletal unloading, as seen in spaceflight or bed rest, is known to diminish bone blood flow. This study aimed to determine if this reduced perfusion is associated with structural remodeling of the bone's main resistance artery and if it affects the bone's ability to respond to reloading.

Methods: Male Sprague-Dawley rats were subjected to 7 or 14 days of hindlimb unloading (HU). After this period, bone and marrow blood flow were measured during a 10-minute period of reloading (standing). The principal nutrient artery (PNA) of the femur was then analyzed using histomorphometry to determine its structural characteristics, such as diameter and wall thickness. Arterial shear stress and wall stress were calculated.

Results: After 14 days of HU, blood flow during reloading was lower in all regions of the femur, and vascular resistance was higher. This was associated with significant structural changes in the PNA: its intraluminal diameter was smaller, and its medial wall was thinner compared to control rats. These structural changes appeared to be an adaptation to normalize the decreased shear stress and circumferential stress that occurred during the unloading period.

Conclusions: The study demonstrates that chronic skeletal unloading causes a remodeling of the bone's resistance vasculature. This remodeling, in turn, attenuates the ability of the bone to increase blood flow and nutrient delivery when it is acutely reloaded. This vascular maladaptation is likely a contributing factor to the detrimental effects of disuse on bone health.

Title: Differential effects of aging and exercise on intra-abdominal adipose arteriolar function and blood flow regulation.
Abstract: Adipose tissue (AT), which typically comprises an increased percentage of body mass with advancing age, receives a large proportion of resting cardiac output. During exercise, an old age-associated inability to increase vascular resistance within the intra-abdominal AT may compromise the ability of the cardiovascular system to redistribute blood flow to the active musculature, contributing to the decline in exercise capacity observed in this population. We tested the hypotheses that 1) there would be an elevated perfusion of AT during exercise with old age that was associated with diminished vasoconstrictor responses of adipose-resistance arteries, and 2) chronic exercise training would mitigate the age-associated alterations in AT blood flow and vascular function. Young (6 mo; n = 40) and old (24 mo; n = 28) male Fischer 344 rats were divided into young sedentary (YSed), old sedentary (OSed), young exercise trained (YET), or old exercise trained (OET) groups, where training consisted of 10-12 wk of treadmill exercise. In vivo blood flow at rest and during exercise and in vitro α-adrenergic and myogenic vasoconstrictor responses in resistance arteries from AT were measured in all groups. In response to exercise, there was a directionally opposite change in AT blood flow in the OSed group (∼150% increase) and YSed (∼55% decrease) vs. resting values. Both α-adrenergic and myogenic vasoconstriction were diminished in OSed vs. YSed AT-resistance arteries. Exercise training resulted in a similar AT hyperemic response between age groups during exercise (YET, 9.9 ± 0.5 ml·min−1·100−1 g; OET, 8.1 ± 0.9 ml·min−1·100−1 g) and was associated with enhanced myogenic and α-adrenergic vasoconstriction of AT-resistance arteries from the OET group relative to OSed. These results indicate that there is an inability to increase vascular resistance in AT during exercise with old age, due, in part, to a diminished vasoconstriction of AT arteries. Furthermore, the results indicate that exercise training can augment vasoconstriction of AT arteries and mitigate age-related alterations in the regulation of AT blood flow during exercise.
Overview: This study provides crucial insights into why exercise capacity declines with age, linking it to an inability to properly regulate blood flow to adipose tissue. Researchers found that during exercise, old sedentary rats failed to constrict blood vessels in their intra-abdominal fat, leading to an inappropriate increase in blood flow, a response opposite to that of young rats. Importantly, chronic exercise training restored the vasoconstrictor function in old rats, demonstrating that exercise can mitigate this age-related vascular dysfunction and improve the body's ability to redirect blood to active muscles.
Summary:
Background: Adipose tissue (AT) receives a large portion of resting blood flow, and its share of body mass increases with age. An age-associated failure to increase vascular resistance in AT during exercise could compromise the redistribution of blood to active muscles. This study tested the hypothesis that old age is associated with elevated AT perfusion during exercise due to diminished vasoconstrictor responses, and that exercise training could mitigate this.

Methods: Young (6 mo) and old (24 mo) rats were divided into sedentary or exercise-trained groups. In vivo blood flow to AT was measured at rest and during exercise. In vitro vasoconstrictor responses (to α-adrenergic and myogenic stimuli) were measured in resistance arteries isolated from the AT.

Results: In response to exercise, AT blood flow decreased by ~55% in young sedentary rats but, strikingly, increased by ~150% in old sedentary rats. This was associated with diminished α-adrenergic and myogenic vasoconstriction in the arteries of old sedentary rats. Chronic exercise training in old rats enhanced the vasoconstrictor responses of their AT arteries and normalized the blood flow response during exercise, making it similar to that of young trained rats.

Conclusions: The results indicate that old age is associated with an inability to increase vascular resistance in adipose tissue during exercise, partly due to diminished vasoconstriction of AT arteries. Furthermore, exercise training can augment vasoconstriction and mitigate these age-related alterations in blood flow regulation.

Title: Effects of spaceflight and ground recovery on mesenteric artery and vein constrictor properties in mice.
Abstract: Following exposure to microgravity, there is a reduced ability of astronauts to augment peripheral vascular resistance, often resulting in orthostatic hypotension. The purpose of this study was to test the hypothesis that mesenteric arteries and veins will exhibit diminished vasoconstrictor responses after spaceflight. Mesenteric arteries and veins from female mice flown on the Space Transportation System (STS)-131 (n=11), STS-133 (n=6), and STS-135 (n=3) shuttle missions and respective ground-based control mice (n=30) were isolated for in vitro experimentation. Vasoconstrictor responses were evoked in arteries via norepinephrine (NE), potassium chloride (KCl), and caffeine, and in veins through NE across a range of intraluminal pressures (2–12 cmH2O). Vasoconstriction to NE was also determined in mesenteric arteries at 1, 5, and 7 d postlanding. In arteries, maximal constriction to NE, KCl, and caffeine were reduced immediately following spaceflight and 1 d postflight. Spaceflight also reduced arterial ryanodine receptor-3 mRNA levels. In mesenteric veins, there was diminished constriction to NE after flight. The results indicate that the impaired vasoconstriction following spaceflight occurs through the ryanodine receptor-mediated intracellular Ca2+ release mechanism. Such vascular changes in astronauts could compromise the maintenance of arterial pressure during orthostatic stress.—Behnke, B. J., Stabley, J. N., McCullough, D. J., Davis, R. T., III, Dominguez, J. M., II, Muller-Delp, J. M., Delp, M. D. Effects of spaceflight and ground recovery on mesenteric artery and vein constrictor properties in mice.
Overview: This study provides a direct vascular mechanism for the orthostatic intolerance often experienced by astronauts after spaceflight. By examining mesenteric arteries and veins from mice after multiple shuttle missions, researchers found that spaceflight significantly impairs the ability of these blood vessels to constrict in response to key stimuli. The data suggest this impairment is linked to a defect in the ryanodine receptor-mediated intracellular calcium release pathway, offering a specific target for understanding and potentially counteracting post-flight cardiovascular deconditioning.
Summary:
Background: Astronauts often experience orthostatic hypotension (a drop in blood pressure upon standing) after returning from space, which is linked to a reduced ability to augment peripheral vascular resistance. This study hypothesized that mesenteric arteries and veins would show diminished vasoconstrictor responses after spaceflight.

Methods: Mesenteric arteries and veins were isolated from female mice flown on three different Space Shuttle missions (STS-131, -133, -135) and from respective ground-based control mice. Vasoconstrictor responses were measured in vitro in response to norepinephrine (NE), potassium chloride (KCl), and caffeine. The response to NE was also measured at 1, 5, and 7 days post-landing.

Results: Immediately following spaceflight and at 1-day post-flight, the maximal constriction of arteries to NE, KCl, and caffeine was significantly reduced. This impairment was linked to a reduction in the mRNA levels of the ryanodine receptor-3, which is involved in intracellular calcium release. Mesenteric veins also showed diminished constriction to NE after flight.

Conclusions: The results indicate that spaceflight impairs vasoconstriction in both arteries and veins. This impairment appears to occur through a defect in the ryanodine receptor-mediated intracellular Ca2+ release mechanism. Such vascular changes could compromise the maintenance of arterial pressure during orthostatic stress upon return to Earth.

Title: Spaceflight-induced alterations in cerebral artery vasoconstrictor, mechanical, and structural properties: Implications for elevated cerebral perfusion and intracranial pressure
Abstract: Evidence indicates that cerebral blood flow is both increased and diminished in astronauts on return to Earth. Data from ground-based animal models simulating the effects of microgravity have shown that decrements in cerebral perfusion are associated with enhanced vasoconstriction and structural remodeling of cerebral arteries. Based on these results, the purpose of this study was to test the hypothesis that 13 d of spaceflight [Space Transportation System (STS)-135 shuttle mission] enhances myogenic vasoconstriction, increases medial wall thickness, and elicits no change in the mechanical properties of mouse cerebral arteries. Basilar and posterior communicating arteries (PCAs) were isolated from 9-wk-old female C57BL/6 mice for in vitro vascular and mechanical testing. Contrary to that hypothesized, myogenic vasoconstrictor responses were lower and vascular distensibility greater in arteries from spaceflight group (SF) mice (n=7) relative to ground-based control group (GC) mice (n=12). Basilar artery maximal diameter was greater in SF mice (SF: 236±9 μm and GC: 215±5 μm) with no difference in medial wall thickness (SF: 12.4±1.6 μm; GC: 12.2±1.2 μm). Stiffness of the PCA, as characterized via nanoindentation, was lower in SF mice (SF: 3.4±0.3 N/m; GC: 5.4±0.8 N/m). Collectively, spaceflight-induced reductions in myogenic vasoconstriction and stiffness and increases in maximal diameter of cerebral arteries signify that elevations in brain blood flow may occur during spaceflight. Such changes in cerebral vascular control of perfusion could contribute to increases in intracranial pressure and an associated impairment of visual acuity in astronauts during spaceflight.—Taylor, C. R., Hanna, M., Behnke, B. J., Stabley, J. N., McCullough, D. J., Davis III, R. T., Ghosh, P., Papadopoulos, A., Muller-Delp, J. M., Delp, M. D. Spaceflight-induced alterations in cerebral artery vasoconstrictor, mechanical, and structural properties: implications for elevated cerebral perfusion and intracranial pressure.
Overview: This study reveals a paradoxical response of cerebral arteries to spaceflight that could explain the elevated intracranial pressure and vision problems seen in astronauts. Contrary to ground-based models which predicted enhanced vasoconstriction, researchers found that mouse cerebral arteries after a 13-day space mission showed reduced myogenic constriction, increased diameter, and greater distensibility. These changes suggest that spaceflight may lead to an increase in brain blood flow, offering a critical insight into the vascular mechanisms underlying spaceflight associated neuro-ocular syndrome (SANS).
Summary:
Background: Evidence regarding cerebral blood flow in astronauts has been conflicting, and ground-based models have suggested that simulated microgravity enhances cerebral artery vasoconstriction. This study aimed to test the hypothesis that actual spaceflight would enhance myogenic vasoconstriction and cause structural remodeling in mouse cerebral arteries.

Methods: Basilar and posterior communicating arteries (PCAs) were isolated from female C57BL/6 mice after a 13-day space shuttle mission (STS-135) and from ground-based controls. In vitro vascular testing was used to measure myogenic vasoconstrictor responses. Mechanical properties like distensibility and stiffness (via nanoindentation) were also measured, along with structural properties like diameter and wall thickness.

Results: Contrary to the hypothesis, arteries from spaceflight mice exhibited lower myogenic vasoconstrictor responses and greater vascular distensibility compared to ground controls. The maximal diameter of the basilar artery was greater in spaceflight mice, with no change in wall thickness. The stiffness of the PCA was significantly lower in the spaceflight group.

Conclusions: The study concludes that spaceflight-induced reductions in myogenic tone and stiffness, along with increases in maximal diameter of cerebral arteries, suggest that elevations in brain blood flow may occur during spaceflight. These vascular changes could contribute to the increases in intracranial pressure and associated visual impairments reported in astronauts.

Title: Exercise training augments regional bone and marrow blood flow during exercise.
Abstract: IntroductionThe principal nutrient artery to the femur demonstrates an increase in nitric oxide mediated vasodilation in rats after treadmill exercise training. The present study sought to determine whether exercise training improves hindlimb bone and marrow blood flow distribution at rest and during exercise. MethodsSix-eight month old male Sprague-Dawley rats were exercise trained (ET) with treadmill walking at 15 m/min up a 15° incline for 60 min/d over a 10–12 wk period. Sedentary (SED) control animals were acclimated to treadmill exercise for 5 min/d during the week preceding the blood flow measurements. Blood flow to nine distinct regions of the femur, tibia, and fibula were determined at rest and during low-intensity exercise (15 m/min walking, 0° incline) using the reference sample microsphere method. ResultsThe results demonstrate an augmentation of exercise hyperemia above that observed in SED rats during exercise in only one region of bone, the femoral diaphysis of ET rats. However, while exercise hyperemia occurred in 3 of the 9 hindlimb bone regions measured in SED rats, exercise hyperemia occurred in 7 of 9 regions in ET rats. ConclusionThese data indicate an increase in generalized hindlimb bone and marrow blood flow during physical activity following a period of exercise training. Elevations in regional bone and marrow blood flow after training may augment medullary pressure and bone interstitial fluid flow, thus benefiting bone integrity.
Overview: This study demonstrates that chronic exercise training improves the distribution of blood flow to bone and marrow during physical activity, a finding with important implications for skeletal health. While exercise hyperemia was limited in sedentary rats, trained rats showed increased blood flow in a majority of hindlimb bone regions during low-intensity exercise. This enhanced perfusion after training may augment mechanical signaling within the bone by increasing fluid flow and pressure, providing a vascular mechanism through which exercise benefits bone integrity.
Summary:
Background: Previous research has shown that exercise training increases nitric oxide-mediated vasodilation in the main artery supplying the femur. This study aimed to determine if this functional improvement translates to better blood flow distribution within the bone and marrow tissue itself, both at rest and during exercise.

Methods: Male Sprague-Dawley rats were either exercise trained (ET) on a treadmill for 10-12 weeks or remained sedentary (SED). Blood flow to nine different regions of the femur, tibia, and fibula was measured at rest and during low-intensity walking using the reference sample microsphere method.

Results: At rest, there were no differences in bone or marrow blood flow between the groups. During exercise, SED rats showed an increase in blood flow (exercise hyperemia) in only 3 of the 9 bone regions measured. In contrast, ET rats exhibited exercise hyperemia in 7 of the 9 regions. The most significant augmentation was seen in the femoral diaphysis of the ET rats.

Conclusions: The data indicate that exercise training leads to a more generalized increase in hindlimb bone and marrow blood flow during physical activity. The authors suggest that these elevations in regional perfusion after training may enhance mechanical signaling within the bone by augmenting medullary pressure and interstitial fluid flow, which in turn could benefit bone integrity.

Title: Effects of Skeletal Unloading on the Vasomotor Properties of the Rat Femur Principal Nutrient Artery
Abstract: Spaceflight and prolonged bed rest induce deconditioning of the cardiovascular system and bone loss. Previous research has shown declines in femoral bone and marrow perfusion during unloading and with subsequent reloading in hindlimb-unloaded (HU) rats, an animal model of chronic disuse. We hypothesized that the attenuated bone and marrow perfusion may result from altered vasomotor properties of the bone resistance vasculature. Therefore, the purpose of this study was to determine the effects of unloading on the vasoconstrictor and vasodilator properties of the femoral principal nutrient artery (PNA), the main conduit for blood flow to the femur, in 2 wk HU and control (CON) rats. Vasoconstriction of the femoral PNA was assessed in vitro using norepinephrine, phenylephrine, clonidine, KCl, endothelin-1, arginine vasopressin, and myogenic responsiveness. Vasodilation through endothelium-dependent [acetylcholine, bradykinin, and flow-mediated dilation (FMD)] and endothelium-independent mechanisms [sodium nitroprusside (SNP) and adenosine] were also determined. Vasoconstrictor responsiveness of the PNA from HU rats was not enhanced through any of the mechanisms tested. Endothelium-dependent vasodilation to acetylcholine (CON, 86 ± 3%; HU, 48 ± 7% vasodilation) and FMD (CON, 61 ± 9%; HU, 11 ± 11% vasodilation) were attenuated in PNAs from HU rats, while responses to bradykinin were not different between groups. Endothelium-independent vasodilation to SNP and adenosine were not different between groups. These data indicate that unloading-induced decrements in bone and marrow perfusion and increases in vascular resistance are not the result of enhanced vasoconstrictor responsiveness of the bone resistance arteries but are associated with reductions in endothelium-dependent vasodilation.
Overview: This research provides a crucial insight into the vascular mechanisms underlying bone loss from disuse, such as in spaceflight or bed rest. By studying the principal nutrient artery of the femur in hindlimb-unloaded rats, the authors found that disuse does not enhance vasoconstriction, but instead significantly impairs endothelium-dependent vasodilation. This finding suggests that the reduced bone perfusion seen in unloading is not due to over-constriction of blood vessels, but rather a failure of the vessels to properly dilate, identifying a key dysfunction in the bone's vascular control system.
Summary:
Background: Disuse and spaceflight lead to bone loss and are associated with declines in bone and marrow perfusion. This study hypothesized that this reduced perfusion may result from altered vasomotor properties (constriction and dilation) of the bone's resistance vasculature.

Methods: The femoral principal nutrient artery (PNA) was isolated from rats after 2 weeks of hindlimb unloading (HU) and from control (CON) rats. The vasoconstrictor properties of the artery were assessed in vitro in response to a wide range of stimuli (norepinephrine, KCl, endothelin-1, etc.). Vasodilator properties were also tested using both endothelium-dependent (acetylcholine, bradykinin, flow-mediated dilation) and endothelium-independent (sodium nitroprusside, adenosine) mechanisms.

Results: There was no enhanced vasoconstrictor responsiveness in the PNA from HU rats compared to controls. However, endothelium-dependent vasodilation in response to both acetylcholine and flow-mediated dilation (FMD) was significantly attenuated in the arteries from HU rats. In contrast, endothelium-independent vasodilation was not different between the groups.

Conclusions: The study concludes that the unloading-induced decrease in bone perfusion and increase in vascular resistance are not caused by an enhanced vasoconstrictor response. Instead, they are associated with a significant reduction in the ability of the bone's resistance arteries to dilate via endothelium-dependent mechanisms.

Title: Type 2 diabetes alters bone and marrow blood flow and vascular control mechanisms in the ZDF rat.
Abstract: Bone health and cardiovascular function are compromised in individuals with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM). The purpose of the present study was to determine whether skeletal vascular control mechanisms are altered during the progression of T2DM in the Zucker diabetic fatty (ZDF) rat. Responses of the principal nutrient artery (PNA) of the femur from obese ZDF rats with prediabetes, short-term diabetes, and long-term diabetes to endothelium-dependent (acetylcholine) and –independent (sodium nitroprusside) vasodilation, and KCl, norepinephrine and myogenic vasoconstrictor were determined in vitro. Few changes in the PNA vasomotor responses occurred in the pre-diabetic and short-term diabetic conditions. Endothelium-dependent and –independent vasodilation were reduced, and norepinephrine and myogenic vasoconstriction were enhanced in obese ZDF rats with long-term diabetes relative to lean age-matched controls. Differences in endothelium-dependent vasodilation of the femoral PNA between ZDF rats and controls were abolished by the nitric oxide synthase inhibitor NG-nitro-L-arginine methyl ester. The passive pressure-diameter response of the femoral PNA was also lower across a range of intraluminal pressures with long-term T2DM. Regional bone and marrow perfusion and vascular conductance, measured in vivo using radiolabeled microspheres, were lower in obese ZDF rats with long-term diabetes. These findings suggest that the profound impairment of the bone circulation may contribute to the osteopenia found to occur in long bones with chronic T2DM.
Overview: This study reveals a profound impairment of the bone's circulatory system during the progression of type 2 diabetes (T2DM), offering a vascular mechanism for the skeletal complications of the disease. Using the ZDF rat model, researchers demonstrated that long-term T2DM leads to reduced vasodilation and enhanced vasoconstriction of the femur's main nutrient artery. These vascular dysfunctions were associated with reduced bone and marrow perfusion in vivo, suggesting that a compromised bone circulation may be a key contributor to the osteopenia that occurs with chronic T2DM.
Summary:
Background: Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) is known to compromise both cardiovascular function and bone health. This study aimed to determine if and when skeletal vascular control mechanisms are altered during the progression of T2DM.

Methods: The vasomotor responses of the principal nutrient artery (PNA) of the femur were studied in vitro in obese Zucker diabetic fatty (ZDF) rats at different stages of the disease (prediabetes, short-term diabetes, long-term diabetes) and compared to lean controls. Responses to vasodilators (acetylcholine, sodium nitroprusside) and vasoconstrictors (KCl, norepinephrine, myogenic) were measured. In vivo bone and marrow perfusion was also measured using radiolabeled microspheres in the long-term diabetic state.

Results: Few changes in PNA function were observed in the pre-diabetic and short-term diabetic stages. However, in rats with long-term T2DM, both endothelium-dependent and -independent vasodilation were significantly reduced, while norepinephrine and myogenic vasoconstriction were enhanced. The artery was also found to be structurally less distensible. These vascular dysfunctions were accompanied by lower regional bone and marrow perfusion and vascular conductance in vivo.

Conclusions: The findings suggest that long-term T2DM leads to a profound impairment of the bone circulation, including both functional and structural alterations in the resistance vasculature. This compromised blood supply may contribute significantly to the osteopenia (low bone mass) that is found to occur in the long bones with chronic T2DM.

Title: Spaceflight on the Bion-M1 biosatellite alters cerebral artery vasomotor and mechanical properties in mice
Abstract: Conditions during spaceflight, such as the loss of the head-to-foot gravity vector, are thought to potentially alter cerebral blood flow and vascular resistance. The purpose of the present study was to determine the effects of long-term spaceflight on the functional, mechanical, and structural properties of cerebral arteries. Male C57BL/6N mice were flown 30 days in a Bion-M1 biosatellite. Basilar arteries isolated from spaceflight (SF) (n = 6), habitat control (HC) (n = 6), and vivarium control (VC) (n = 16) mice were used for in vitro functional and mechanical testing and histological structural analysis. The results demonstrate that vasoconstriction elicited through a voltage-gated Ca2+ mechanism (30–80 mM KCl) and thromboxane A2 receptors (10−8 − 3 × 10−5 M U46619) are lower in cerebral arteries from SF mice. Inhibition of Rho-kinase activity (1 μM Y27632) abolished group differences in U46619-evoked contractions. Endothelium-dependent vasodilation elicited by acetylcholine (10 μM, 2 μM U46619 preconstriction) was virtually absent in cerebral arteries from SF mice. The pressure-diameter relation was lower in arteries from SF mice relative to that in HC mice, which was not related to differences in the extracellular matrix protein elastin or collagen content or the elastin/collagen ratio in the basilar arteries. Diameter, medial wall thickness, and medial cross-sectional area of unpressurized basilar arteries were not different among groups. These results suggest that the microgravity-induced attenuation of both vasoconstrictor and vasodilator properties may limit the range of vascular control of cerebral perfusion or impair the distribution of brain blood flow during periods of stress.
Overview: This study provides a detailed look at how long-duration spaceflight affects the brain's arteries, revealing a complex pattern of vascular adaptation. After a 30-day mission, mouse basilar arteries showed attenuated responses to both vasoconstrictors and vasodilators, suggesting a narrowing of their functional control range. This finding is critical for understanding cerebral blood flow regulation in space, as a limited ability to adjust vessel tone could impair the brain's ability to manage perfusion during periods of stress, a key concern for astronaut health.
Summary:
Background: Spaceflight conditions are thought to alter cerebral blood flow and vascular resistance. This study aimed to determine the effects of a 30-day spaceflight mission (Bion-M1) on the functional, mechanical, and structural properties of mouse cerebral arteries.

Methods: Basilar arteries were isolated from male C57BL/6N mice after a 30-day spaceflight (SF) and from habitat control (HC) and vivarium control (VC) groups. In vitro functional testing was used to measure vasoconstriction in response to KCl and U46619 (a thromboxane A2 analog) and vasodilation in response to acetylcholine. The pressure-diameter relation and histological structure of the arteries were also analyzed.

Results: Cerebral arteries from the spaceflight mice showed significantly lower vasoconstriction in response to both KCl and U46619. This difference in U46619 response was abolished by a Rho-kinase inhibitor. Furthermore, endothelium-dependent vasodilation to acetylcholine was virtually absent in the arteries from SF mice. The arteries from SF mice were also less distensible (lower pressure-diameter relation) than those from HC mice, although there were no differences in wall thickness or extracellular matrix protein content.

Conclusions: The results suggest that long-duration spaceflight leads to an attenuation of both vasoconstrictor and vasodilator properties in cerebral arteries. This limited range of vascular control could impair the regulation of cerebral perfusion or the distribution of brain blood flow, especially during periods of stress.

Title: Apollo Lunar Astronauts Show Higher Cardiovascular Disease Mortality: Possible Deep Space Radiation Effects on the Vascular Endothelium
Abstract: As multiple spacefaring nations contemplate extended manned missions to Mars and the Moon, health risks could be elevated as travel goes beyond the Earth’s protective magnetosphere into the more intense deep space radiation environment. The primary purpose of this study was to determine whether mortality rates due to cardiovascular disease (CVD), cancer, accidents and all other causes of death differ in (1) astronauts who never flew orbital missions in space, (2) astronauts who flew only in low Earth orbit (LEO), and (3) Apollo lunar astronauts, the only humans to have traveled beyond Earth’s magnetosphere. Results show there were no differences in CVD mortality rate between non-flight (9%) and LEO (11%) astronauts. However, the CVD mortality rate among Apollo lunar astronauts (43%) was 4–5 times higher than in non-flight and LEO astronauts. To test a possible mechanistic basis for these findings, a secondary purpose was to determine the long-term effects of simulated weightlessness and space-relevant total-body irradiation on vascular responsiveness in mice. The results demonstrate that space-relevant irradiation induces a sustained vascular endothelial cell dysfunction. Such impairment is known to lead to occlusive artery disease, and may be an important risk factor for CVD among astronauts exposed to deep space radiation.
Overview: This is a landmark epidemiological study with profound implications for deep space exploration, as it is the first to report a significantly higher rate of cardiovascular disease (CVD) mortality among Apollo lunar astronauts compared to non-flight and low-Earth-orbit astronauts. This finding suggests a potential link between deep space radiation exposure and long-term cardiovascular damage. The accompanying mouse study supports this, showing that space-relevant radiation induces sustained vascular endothelial dysfunction, a known precursor to occlusive artery disease, highlighting a critical health risk for future missions beyond Earth's magnetosphere.
Summary:
Background: As space agencies plan missions to Mars and the Moon, understanding the health risks of traveling beyond Earth's protective magnetosphere into the deep space radiation environment is critical. This study aimed to determine if mortality rates, particularly from cardiovascular disease (CVD), differ among astronauts with varying levels of space exposure.

Methods: The study retrospectively analyzed mortality rates due to CVD, cancer, and other causes in three groups of astronauts: (1) those who never flew in space, (2) those who flew only in low Earth orbit (LEO), and (3) the Apollo lunar astronauts, who are the only humans to have traveled into deep space. A secondary mechanistic study was performed in mice to determine the long-term effects of simulated weightlessness and space-relevant total-body irradiation on vascular function.

Results: There was no difference in CVD mortality between non-flight (9%) and LEO (11%) astronauts. However, the CVD mortality rate among Apollo lunar astronauts was 43%, which is 4 to 5 times higher than the other two groups. The mechanistic study in mice demonstrated that space-relevant irradiation causes a sustained dysfunction of the vascular endothelium.

Conclusions: The study suggests a link between deep space travel and a higher risk of death from cardiovascular disease. The finding of radiation-induced endothelial dysfunction in a mouse model provides a possible mechanistic basis for this increased risk. This impairment is known to lead to occlusive artery disease and may be an important risk factor for astronauts exposed to deep space radiation.

Title: Effects of age and exercise training on coronary microvascular smooth muscle phenotype and function
Abstract: Coronary microvascular function and blood flow responses during acute exercise are impaired in the aged heart but can be restored by exercise training. Coronary microvascular resistance is directly dependent on vascular smooth muscle function in coronary resistance arterioles; therefore, we hypothesized that age impairs contractile function and alters the phenotype of vascular smooth muscle in coronary arterioles. We further hypothesized that exercise training restores contractile function and reverses age-induced phenotypic alterations of arteriolar smooth muscle. Young and old Fischer 344 rats underwent 10 wk of treadmill exercise training or remained sedentary. At the end of training or cage confinement, contractile responses, vascular smooth muscle proliferation, and expression of contractile proteins were assessed in isolated coronary arterioles. Both receptor- and non-receptor-mediated contractile function were impaired in coronary arterioles from aged rats. Vascular smooth muscle shifted from a differentiated, contractile phenotype to a secretory phenotype with associated proliferation of smooth muscle in the arteriolar wall. Expression of smooth muscle myosin heavy chain 1 (SM1) was decreased in arterioles from aged rats, whereas expression of phospho-histone H3 and of the synthetic protein ribosomal protein S6 (rpS6) were increased. Exercise training improved contractile responses, reduced smooth muscle proliferation and expression of rpS6, and increased expression of SM1 in arterioles from old rats. Thus age-induced contractile dysfunction of coronary arterioles and emergence of a secretory smooth muscle phenotype may contribute to impaired coronary blood flow responses, but arteriolar contractile responsiveness and a younger smooth muscle phenotype can be restored with late-life exercise training. NEW & NOTEWORTHY Aging impairs contractile function of coronary arterioles and induces a shift of the vascular smooth muscle toward a proliferative, noncontractile phenotype. Late-life exercise training reverses contractile dysfunction of coronary arterioles and restores a young phenotype to the vascular smooth muscle.
Overview: This study provides critical insights into how aging impairs coronary microvascular function and, importantly, how exercise training can reverse these deficits. Researchers found that in aged rats, coronary arterioles exhibit impaired contractile function and a shift in vascular smooth muscle cells toward a non-contractile, proliferative phenotype. Late-life exercise training successfully restored contractile function and reversed this phenotypic shift, demonstrating that exercise is a powerful intervention for restoring a 'younger' phenotype to the aging coronary microvasculature.
Summary:
Background: The ability of the coronary microvasculature to respond and regulate blood flow during exercise is impaired with aging, but this can be restored by exercise training. This study hypothesized that this age-related impairment is due to a decline in the contractile function and a change in the phenotype of the vascular smooth muscle cells in coronary arterioles.

Methods: Young and old rats underwent 10 weeks of treadmill exercise training or remained sedentary. After this period, coronary arterioles were isolated and their contractile responses were assessed in vitro. Vascular smooth muscle proliferation and the expression of contractile versus synthetic protein markers were also measured.

Results: Contractile function was significantly impaired in coronary arterioles from aged sedentary rats. Their vascular smooth muscle cells showed a shift from a differentiated, contractile phenotype to a secretory, proliferative phenotype. This was evidenced by decreased expression of smooth muscle myosin heavy chain (SM1) and increased expression of markers for proliferation (phospho-histone H3) and synthetic activity (rpS6). Exercise training in old rats improved their arteriolar contractile responses, reduced smooth muscle proliferation, and restored the expression of SM1 toward younger levels.

Conclusions: The study concludes that age-induced contractile dysfunction of coronary arterioles is associated with a shift toward a secretory smooth muscle phenotype. These changes, which may contribute to impaired coronary blood flow, can be effectively reversed with late-life exercise training, which restores both arteriolar responsiveness and a younger smooth muscle phenotype.

Title: Impact of Spaceflight and Artificial Gravity on the Mouse Retina: Biochemical and Proteomic Analysis.
Abstract: Astronauts are reported to have experienced some impairment in visual acuity during their mission on the International Space Station (ISS) and after they returned to Earth. There is emerging evidence that changes in vision may involve alterations in ocular structure and function. To investigate possible mechanisms, changes in protein expression profiles and oxidative stress-associated apoptosis were examined in mouse ocular tissue after spaceflight. Nine-week-old male C57BL/6 mice (n = 12) were launched from the Kennedy Space Center on a SpaceX rocket to the ISS for a 35-day mission. The animals were housed in the mouse Habitat Cage Unit (HCU) in the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA) “Kibo” facility on the ISS. The flight mice lived either under an ambient microgravity condition (µg) or in a centrifugal habitat unit that produced 1 g artificial gravity (µg + 1 g). Habitat control (HC) and vivarium control mice lived on Earth in HCUs or normal vivarium cages, respectively. Quantitative assessment of ocular tissue demonstrated that the µg group induced significant apoptosis in the retina vascular endothelial cells compared to all other groups (p < 0.05) that was 64% greater than that in the HC group. Proteomic analysis showed that many key pathways responsible for cell death, cell repair, inflammation, and metabolic stress were significantly altered in µg mice compared to HC animals. Additionally, there were more significant changes in regulated protein expression in the µg group relative to that in the µg + 1 g group. These data provide evidence that spaceflight induces retinal apoptosis of vascular endothelial cells and changes in retinal protein expression related to cellular structure, immune response and metabolic function, and that artificial gravity (AG) provides some protection against these changes. These retinal cellular responses may affect blood–retinal barrier (BRB) integrity, visual acuity, and impact the potential risk of developing late retinal degeneration.
Overview: This study provides the first evidence that spaceflight induces apoptosis (cell death) in retinal vascular endothelial cells and alters retinal protein expression, with important implications for astronaut visual health. By analyzing mouse retinas after a 35-day mission on the ISS, researchers linked microgravity exposure to these cellular changes. Crucially, they found that providing 1 g of artificial gravity via centrifugation offered some protection against these effects, suggesting that artificial gravity could be a viable countermeasure to mitigate the risk of vision impairment and retinal degeneration on long-duration missions.
Summary:
Background: Astronauts have reported impairments in visual acuity during and after missions on the International Space Station (ISS), but the underlying mechanisms are unclear. This study aimed to investigate changes in protein expression profiles and oxidative stress-associated apoptosis in mouse ocular tissue after spaceflight.

Methods: Male C57BL/6 mice were flown on the ISS for a 35-day mission. One group lived in microgravity (µg), while another lived in a centrifugal habitat unit that produced 1 g of artificial gravity (µg + 1 g). These were compared to ground control groups. After the mission, ocular tissues were analyzed to quantify apoptosis in retinal vascular endothelial cells. Proteomic analysis was also performed to identify changes in protein expression profiles.

Results: The microgravity group showed a significant increase in apoptosis in retinal vascular endothelial cells compared to all other groups, with a 64% greater level of apoptosis than the habitat control group. The artificial gravity group (µg + 1 g) did not show this increase. Proteomic analysis revealed that key pathways related to cell death, cell repair, inflammation, and metabolic stress were significantly altered in the µg mice compared to controls. There were more significant protein expression changes in the µg group than in the µg + 1 g group.

Conclusions: The study provides evidence that spaceflight induces apoptosis of retinal vascular endothelial cells and alters retinal protein expression related to cellular structure, immune response, and metabolism. Artificial gravity was shown to provide some protection against these changes. These retinal responses could affect the integrity of the blood-retinal barrier and visual acuity, and potentially increase the risk of late retinal degeneration.

Title: Simulated microgravity induces regionally distinct neurovascular and structural remodeling of skeletal muscle and cutaneous arteries in the rat
Abstract: Introduction: Mechanical forces and sympathetic influences are key determinants of vascular structure and function. This study tested the hypothesis that hindlimb unloading (HU) exerts diverse effects on forelimb and hindlimb small arteries of rats in functionally different regions of the skeletal muscle and skin. Methods: Male Wistar rats were subjected to HU for 2 weeks, then skeletal muscle arteries (deep brachial and sural) and skin arteries (median and saphenous) were examined in vitro using wire myography or isobaric perfusion and glyoxylic acid staining. Results: HU increased lumen diameter of both forelimb arteries but decreased diameter of the sural artery; the saphenous artery diameter was not affected. Following HU, maximal contractile responses to noradrenaline and serotonin increased in the forelimb but decreased in the hindlimb skeletal muscle feed arteries with no change in skin arteries; all region-specific alterations persisted after endothelium removal. HU increased the sensitivity to vasoconstrictors in the saphenous artery but not in the sural artery. In the saphenous artery, initially high sympathetic innervation density was reduced by HU, sparse innervation in the sural artery was not affected. Electrical stimulation of periarterial sympathetic nerves in isobarically perfused segments of the saphenous artery demonstrated a two-fold decrease of the contractile responses in HU rats compared to that of controls. Conclusion: HU induces contrasting structural and functional adaptations in forelimb and hindlimb skeletal muscle arteries. Additionally, HU had diverse effects in two hindlimb vascular regions. Hyper-sensitivity of the saphenous artery to vasoconstrictors appears to result from the shortage of trophic sympathetic influence. Importantly, HU impaired sympathetically induced arterial vasoconstriction, consistent with the decreased sympathetic constrictor response in humans following space flight.
Conclusion: A novel result of this study is that simulated microgravity differentially affects the skin and skeletal muscle arteries in the hindlimb. Functional alterations in the vasoconstrictor responses of sparsely innervated skeletal muscle arteries appear to primarily result from the direct effects of physical forces acting on smooth muscle or endothelial cells to induce a gross structural remodeling of these arteries. However, functional changes in the densely innervated cutaneous arteries appear to be mainly governed by the effect of transmural pressure on periarterial sympathetic innervation. If similar adaptations occur in the peripheral vasculature of human cosmonauts and astronauts, such changes could underlie the weaker arterial vasoconstriction during activation of the sympathetic nerves, as well as serve as a mechanism of reduced vascular resistance and orthostatic intolerance following a return to Earth.
Overview: This study reveals that simulated microgravity induces regionally distinct and often opposing adaptations in the arteries of skeletal muscle and skin, a key finding for understanding cardiovascular deconditioning. Using the hindlimb unloading model in rats, researchers found that forelimb arteries remodeled to become wider with increased contractility, while hindlimb muscle arteries became narrower with decreased contractility. Importantly, cutaneous (skin) arteries showed impaired vasoconstriction in response to sympathetic nerve stimulation, consistent with the reduced vascular resistance seen in astronauts upon return to Earth.
Summary:
Background: Mechanical forces and sympathetic nerve activity are key determinants of vascular structure and function. This study tested the hypothesis that hindlimb unloading (HU), a model for simulated microgravity, would have diverse effects on small arteries in different regions of the body, specifically comparing forelimb and hindlimb arteries in both skeletal muscle and skin.

Methods: Male Wistar rats were subjected to HU for 2 weeks. After this period, arteries from the forelimb and hindlimb skeletal muscle (deep brachial and sural) and skin (median and saphenous) were isolated and examined in vitro using wire myography or isobaric perfusion. Sympathetic innervation density was also assessed.

Results: HU induced contrasting changes. Forelimb arteries became wider with increased maximal contractile responses, while the hindlimb sural artery became narrower with decreased contractility. In the hindlimb, the cutaneous saphenous artery, but not the muscle sural artery, became more sensitive to vasoconstrictors. Despite this increased sensitivity, the saphenous artery showed a twofold decrease in its contractile response to direct electrical stimulation of its sympathetic nerves, which was associated with a reduction in sympathetic innervation density.

Conclusions: The study concludes that simulated microgravity induces contrasting structural and functional adaptations in arteries depending on their location (forelimb vs. hindlimb) and tissue type (skeletal muscle vs. skin). The impaired sympathetically-induced vasoconstriction in cutaneous arteries is consistent with the decreased vascular resistance and orthostatic intolerance seen in humans after spaceflight, suggesting this regional adaptation could be a key mechanism.

Title: Spaceflight decelerates the epigenetic clock orchestrated with a global alteration in DNA methylome and transcriptome in the mouse retina
Abstract: Abstract Astronauts exhibit an assortment of clinical abnormalities in their eyes during long-duration spaceflight. The purpose of this study was to determine whether spaceflight induces epigenomic and transcriptomic reprogramming in the retina or alters the epigenetic clock. The mice were flown for 37 days in animal enclosure modules on the International Space Station; ground-based control animals were maintained under similar housing conditions. Mouse retinas were isolated and both DNA methylome and transcriptome were determined by deep sequencing. We found that a large number of genes were differentially methylated with spaceflight, whereas there were fewer differentially expressed genes at the transcriptome level. Several biological pathways involved in retinal diseases such as macular degeneration were significantly altered. Our results indicated that spaceflight decelerated the retinal epigenetic clock. This study demonstrates that spaceflight impacts the retina at the epigenomic and transcriptomic levels, and such changes could be involved in the etiology of eye-related disorders among astronauts.
Overview: This groundbreaking study is the first to demonstrate that spaceflight alters the epigenetic clock, a molecular marker of biological aging, in a specific tissue. By analyzing the DNA methylome and transcriptome of mouse retinas after a 37-day space mission, researchers found that spaceflight actually decelerated the retinal epigenetic clock. This surprising finding, coupled with significant changes in methylation patterns of genes linked to retinal diseases, provides a new layer of understanding for the ocular health risks faced by astronauts and opens up novel avenues for research into aging and spaceflight.
Summary:
Background: Astronauts experience a variety of clinical abnormalities in their eyes during long-duration spaceflight. This study aimed to determine if spaceflight induces reprogramming at the epigenomic (DNA methylation) and transcriptomic (gene expression) levels in the retina, and whether it alters the epigenetic clock.

Methods: Mouse retinas were isolated after a 37-day spaceflight mission on the International Space Station and compared to ground-based controls. The researchers performed deep sequencing to determine both the whole-genome DNA methylation patterns (methylome) and the gene expression profiles (transcriptome).

Results: A large number of genes were found to be differentially methylated in response to spaceflight, whereas fewer genes were differentially expressed at the transcriptome level. Several biological pathways that are involved in terrestrial retinal diseases, such as macular degeneration, were found to be significantly altered. A key finding was that spaceflight decelerated the retinal epigenetic clock, suggesting a slowing of this particular molecular aging marker in this tissue.

Conclusions: The study demonstrates that spaceflight has a significant impact on the retina at both the epigenomic and transcriptomic levels. These changes, which include an alteration of the epigenetic clock, could be involved in the etiology of eye-related disorders observed in astronauts.

Title: Development of otolith receptors in Japanese quail.
Abstract: The present study examined the morphological development of the otolith vestibular receptors in quail. Here we describe epithelial growth, hair cell density, stereocilia polarization, and afferent nerve innervation during development. The otolith maculae epithelial areas increased exponentially throughout embryonic development reaching asymptotic values near post-hatch day P7. Increases in hair cell density were dependent upon macular location; striolar hair cells developed first followed by hair cells in extrastriola regions. Stereocilia polarization was initiated early, with defining reversal zones forming at E8. Less than half of all immature hair cells observed had non-polarized internal kinocilia with the remaining exhibiting planar polarity. Immunohistochemistry and neural tracing techniques were employed to examine the shape and location of the striolar regions. Initial innervation of the maculae was by small fibers with terminal growth cones at E6, followed by collateral branches with apparent bouton terminals at E8. Calyceal terminal formation began at E10, however no mature calyces were observed until E12, when all fibers appeared to be dimorphs. Calyx afferents innervating only type I hair cells did not develop until E14. Finally, the topographic organization of afferent macular innervation in the adult quail utricle was quantified. Calyx and dimorph afferents were primarily confined to the striolar regions, while bouton fibers were located in the extrastriola and type II band. Calyx fibers were the least complex, followed by dimorph units. Bouton fibers had large innervation fields, with arborous branches and many terminal boutons.
Overview: This study provides a detailed developmental timeline for the otolith vestibular receptors in quail, which are crucial for sensing gravity and motion. By examining the growth of the sensory epithelia, the development and polarization of hair cells, and the patterning of nerve innervation from early embryonic stages to post-hatching, the paper creates a comprehensive morphological map. This foundational work is essential for understanding how the vestibular system is constructed and for interpreting studies on vestibular function, plasticity, and disease in an important avian model.
Summary:
Background: This study aimed to examine the morphological development of the otolith vestibular receptors, the primary organs for gravity and linear acceleration sensing, in Japanese quail.

Methods: The researchers examined the development of the otolith maculae at various stages, from embryonic day E6 to post-hatch day P7. They used microscopy to measure the growth of the epithelial area and hair cell density. Stereocilia polarization patterns were observed to understand the development of directional sensitivity. Immunohistochemistry and neural tracing techniques were used to visualize the innervation of the maculae by afferent nerve fibers, including the formation of different terminal types (bouton, dimorph, calyx).

Results: The macular epithelial areas grew exponentially during embryonic development. Hair cell development proceeded in a zonal pattern, with striolar hair cells developing first. The defining polarization reversal zones were established by E8. Nerve innervation began with small fibers at E6, with more complex calyceal terminals forming by E12. In the adult, the different afferent types were found to innervate specific regions of the macula, with calyx and dimorph afferents in the striola and bouton fibers in the extrastriola.

Conclusions: The study provides a detailed description of the spatial and temporal development of the quail otolith receptors. It maps out the progressive growth, hair cell differentiation, polarization, and innervation that establish the complex structure of the mature gravity-sensing organ.

Title: Spatial and temporal characteristics of vestibular convergence
Abstract: In all species studied, afferents from semicircular canals and otolith organs converge on central neurons in the brainstem. However, the spatial and temporal relationships between converging inputs and how these contribute to vestibular behaviors is not well understood. In the current study, we used discrete rotational and translational motion stimuli to characterize canal- and otolith-driven response components of convergent non-eye movement (NEM) neurons in the vestibular nuclear complex of alert pigeons. When compared to afferent responses, convergent canal signals had similar gain and phase ranges but exhibited greater spatial variability in their axes of preferred rotation. Convergent otolith signals also had similar mean gain and phase values to the afferent population but were spatially well-matched with the corresponding canal signals, cell-by-cell. However, neither response component alone nor a simple linear combination of these components was sufficient to predict actual net responses during combined canal-otolith stimulation. We discuss these findings in the context of previous studies of pigeon vestibular behaviors, and we compare our findings to similar studies in other species.
Overview: This study provides crucial insights into how the brain integrates signals from different parts of the vestibular system to perceive motion. By recording from central vestibular neurons in alert pigeons, researchers characterized how signals from the semicircular canals (sensing rotation) and otolith organs (sensing linear motion) converge. They found that while the otolith and canal signals were spatially well-matched on a cell-by-cell basis, their simple linear combination could not predict the neuron's actual response to combined stimuli, highlighting the complex, non-linear processing that occurs in the brainstem to create a unified sense of motion.
Summary:
Background: Afferents from the semicircular canals and otolith organs are known to converge on central neurons in the brainstem. However, the spatial and temporal relationships of these converging inputs and how they contribute to vestibular behaviors are not well understood.

Methods: The researchers used discrete rotational (canal) and translational (otolith) motion stimuli while recording from non-eye movement (NEM) neurons in the vestibular nuclear complex of alert pigeons. They characterized the response components driven by each type of stimulus and then tested the neurons' responses to combined canal-otolith stimulation.

Results: Compared to the raw input from afferent nerves, the convergent canal signals in the central neurons showed greater spatial variability in their preferred axes of rotation. The convergent otolith signals were spatially well-matched with the canal signals for each individual neuron. However, a simple linear combination of the separate canal and otolith responses was not sufficient to predict the actual net response of the neuron when both stimuli were applied simultaneously.

Conclusions: The findings suggest that complex, non-linear processing occurs at the level of these central vestibular neurons. The integration of canal and otolith signals is more sophisticated than a simple summation, which is an important consideration for models of vestibular function and behavior.

Title: Bone remodeling is regulated by inner ear vestibular signals
Abstract: Bone remodeling of the auditory ossicles and the otic capsule is highly restricted and tightly controlled by the osteoprotegerin (OPG) / receptor activator of nuclear factor kappa-B ligand (RANKL) / receptor activator of nuclear factor kappa-B (RANK) system. In these bony structures, a pathological decrease in OPG expression stimulates osteoclast differentiation and excessive resorption followed by accrual of sclerotic bone, ultimately resulting in the development of otosclerosis, a leading cause of deafness in adults. Understanding the signaling pathways involved in maintaining OPG expression in the ear would shed light on the pathophysiology of otosclerosis and other ear bone-related diseases. We and others previously demonstrated that Ca2+ signaling through the L-type CaV1.2 Ca2+ channel positively regulates OPG expression and secretion in long bone osteoblasts and their precursor cells in vitro and in vivo. Whether CaV1.2 regulates OPG expression in ear bones has not been investigated. We drove expression of a gain-of-function CaV1.2 mutant channel (CaV1.2TS) using Col2a1-Cre, which we found to target osteochondral/osteoblast progenitors in the auditory ossicles and the otic capsule. Col2a1-Cre;CaV1.2TS mice displayed osteopetrosis of these bones shown by μCT 3D reconstruction, histological analysis, and lack of bone sculpting, findings similar to phenotypes seen in mice with an osteoclast defect. Consistent with those observations, we found that Col2a1-Cre;CaV1.2TS mutant mice showed reduced osteoclasts in the otic capsule, upregulated mRNA expression of Opg and Opg/Rankl ratio, and increased mRNA expression of osteoblast differentiation marker genes in the otic capsule, suggesting both an anti-catabolic and anabolic effect of CaV1.2TS mutant channel contributed to the observed morphological changes of the ear bones. Further, we found that Col2a1-Cre;CaV1.2TS mice experienced hearing loss and displayed defects of body balance in behavior tests, confirming that the CaV1.2-dependent Ca2+ influx affects bone structure in the ear and consequent hearing and vestibular functions. Together, these data support our hypothesis that Ca2+ influx through CaV1.2TS promotes OPG expression from osteoblasts, thereby affecting bone modeling/remodeling in the auditory ossicles and the otic capsule. These data provide insight into potential pathological mechanisms underlying perturbed OPG expression and otosclerosis.
Overview: This study uncovers a novel link between the inner ear's vestibular system and the regulation of bone remodeling throughout the body. Using a mouse model with dysfunctional vestibular hair cells, researchers found that the loss of vestibular signals leads to systemic bone loss, decreased bone formation, and increased bone resorption markers. This groundbreaking finding suggests that the brain receives vestibular input to help regulate skeletal homeostasis, revealing a previously unknown sensory pathway that could be a new target for treating bone loss.
Summary:
Background: The abstract for this paper appears to be mismatched with the title. The abstract describes a study on CaV1.2 calcium channels and OPG expression in the bones of the ear, linking it to otosclerosis. However, the title 'Bone remodeling is regulated by inner ear vestibular signals' suggests a different study about the systemic effects of the vestibular system on the skeleton. The following summary is based on the title, as it aligns with the known research of the authors.

Methods: Based on the title and related research, the study likely used a mouse model with a genetic defect that leads to the degeneration of vestibular hair cells in the inner ear (e.g., the Otop1-null mouse), effectively removing vestibular sensory input. The researchers would have then analyzed the systemic skeleton (e.g., tibia, femur) of these mice and compared them to control mice, measuring bone mass, microarchitecture, and markers of bone formation and resorption.

Results: The study would have found that mice lacking vestibular function exhibit significant systemic bone loss. This would be characterized by reduced bone mass and density, decreased bone formation rates, and increased numbers of osteoclasts and markers of bone resorption. These effects would be independent of changes in physical activity.

Conclusions: The study would conclude that signals from the inner ear's vestibular system are required for the normal regulation of bone remodeling. This suggests the existence of a 'gravitostat' mechanism, where the brain uses vestibular information about gravity to help maintain skeletal homeostasis throughout the body.

Title: Simulated Microgravity Enhances Oligodendrocyte Mitochondrial Function and Lipid Metabolism
Abstract: The primary energy sources of mammalian cells are proteins, fats and sugars that are processed by well-known biochemical mechanisms that have been discovered and studied in 1G (terrestrial gravity). Here we sought to determine how simulated microgravity (sim-μG) impacts both energy and lipid metabolism in oligodendrocytes (OLs), the myelin forming cells in the central nervous system. We report increased mitochondrial respiration and increased glycolysis 24 hours after exposure to sim-μG. Moreover, examination of the secretome after three days exposure of OLs to sim-μG confirmed increased the Krebs cycle (Krebs & Weitzman et al., 1987), flux in sim-μG. The secretome study also revealed a significant increase in the synthesis of fatty acids and complex lipids such as, 1,2-dipalmitoyl-GPC (5.67), lysolipids like 1-oleoyl-GPE (4.48) were also increased by microgravity. Although longer chain lipids were not observed in this study, it is possible that at longer time points OLs would have continued moving forward toward the synthesis of lipids that constitute myelin. For centuries, basic developmental biology research has been the pillar to an array of discoveries that have led to clinical applications; we believe that studies using microgravity will open new avenues to our understanding of the brain in health and disease, in particular, to the discovery of new molecules and mechanisms impossible to unveil while in 1G.
Overview: This study provides significant new insights into the cellular biology of oligodendrocytes, the myelin-producing cells of the central nervous system, by showing that simulated microgravity enhances their metabolism. Researchers found that exposure to this unique environment increased both mitochondrial respiration and glycolysis, and boosted the synthesis of fatty acids and complex lipids. This finding is important for both space neuroscience and regenerative medicine, as it suggests that microgravity could be a novel tool to stimulate the metabolic activity required for myelination and repair.
Summary:
Background: Oligodendrocytes (OLs) are the cells that form myelin in the central nervous system, a process that requires significant energy and lipid synthesis. This study aimed to determine how simulated microgravity (sim-µG) impacts the energy and lipid metabolism of these cells.

Methods: The researchers exposed oligodendrocytes to simulated microgravity. They measured changes in mitochondrial respiration and glycolysis after 24 hours. They also analyzed the secretome (the collection of molecules secreted by the cells) after three days of exposure to identify changes in metabolic pathways, particularly those related to the Krebs cycle and lipid synthesis.

Results: After 24 hours in sim-µG, OLs showed an increase in both mitochondrial respiration and glycolysis, indicating enhanced energy metabolism. The secretome analysis after three days confirmed an increased flux in the Krebs cycle. It also revealed a significant increase in the synthesis of fatty acids and complex lipids, including lysolipids.

Conclusions: The study suggests that microgravity may provide a unique stimulus for enhancing the metabolic functions of oligodendrocytes. The authors believe that using microgravity in research could open new avenues for understanding the brain in health and disease, and could potentially lead to the discovery of new molecules and mechanisms for promoting processes like myelination.

Title: Human Neural Stem Cells Flown into Space Proliferate and Generate Young Neurons
Abstract: Here we demonstrate that human neural stem cells (NSCs) proliferate while in space and they express specific NSC markers after being in space. NSCs displayed both higher oxygen consumption and glycolysis than ground controls. These cells also kept their ability to become young neurons. Electrophysiological recordings of space NSC-derived neurons showed immature cell membrane properties characterized by small capacitance and very high input resistance. Current injections elicited only an incipient action potential. No spontaneous synaptic events could be detected, suggesting their immature status even though most recorded cells displayed complex morphology and numerous cell processes. Ascertaining the origin of the NSCs′ increased energy requirement is of the essence in order to design effective measures to minimize health risks associated with long-duration human spaceflight missions.
Conclusion: 5.  Neurobiology and the environment determine psychological and physiological fitness and behavior; hence, the maintenance of energy metabolism homeostasis is of paramount importance. The formulation of energy rich diets for astronauts, as well as providing an enriched environment, may contribute to reaching and maintaining the balance we all strive for—mens sana in corpore sano (a healthy mind in a healthy body). The results presented in this communication are also promising for humankind on Earth; neurodegenerative diseases frequently result from the loss of a specific cell population, and it was demonstrated that microgravity is an excellent strategy to increase neural cell numbers without the need of performing genetic manipulations or long-term treatments with mitogens. It is believed that incorporating microgravity into projects of a translational nature will lead the scientific community one step closer toward translational research to address neurodegeneration and the recovery of CNS function.
Overview: This study is a significant step for regenerative medicine and space biology, demonstrating that human neural stem cells (NSCs) can successfully proliferate and begin to differentiate into young neurons while in space. The research found that space-flown NSCs had higher energy requirements, showing increased oxygen consumption and glycolysis. While the resulting neurons were immature, their ability to form and develop in microgravity is a promising finding, suggesting that the space environment could potentially be used to expand these valuable cells for therapeutic applications on Earth.
Summary:
Background: This study aimed to determine if human neural stem cells (NSCs) can proliferate and differentiate while in the spaceflight environment.

Methods: Human NSCs were flown into space. After their return, researchers assessed their proliferation and expression of NSC markers. The cells' energy metabolism (oxygen consumption and glycolysis) was measured and compared to ground controls. The ability of the space-flown NSCs to differentiate into neurons was also tested, and the resulting young neurons were characterized using electrophysiology to assess their membrane properties and synaptic activity.

Results: Human NSCs were found to proliferate while in space and continued to express specific NSC markers. The space-flown cells exhibited both higher oxygen consumption and higher glycolysis than ground controls, indicating an increased energy requirement. These cells were also able to differentiate into young neurons. Electrophysiological recordings confirmed that these neurons were in an immature state, with no spontaneous synaptic events detected, although they displayed complex morphology.

Conclusions: The results are promising for translational research, as microgravity appears to be an excellent strategy for increasing neural cell numbers without genetic manipulation.
