The authors suggest that understanding the increased energy demand of these cells is essential for designing measures to mitigate health risks during long-duration spaceflight. Incorporating microgravity into regenerative medicine projects could bring science one step closer to addressing neurodegeneration.

Title: Delayed Maturation of Oligodendrocyte Progenitors by Microgravity: Implications for Multiple Sclerosis and Space Flight
Abstract: Not found
Overview: This study provides critical insights into the potential neurological risks of spaceflight and offers a new perspective on diseases like multiple sclerosis. The research demonstrates that microgravity delays the maturation of oligodendrocyte progenitors (OPCs), the cells responsible for forming and repairing the myelin sheath around neurons. This finding is highly significant as it suggests a cellular mechanism that could contribute to both the neurological issues experienced by astronauts and the remyelination failure seen in demyelinating diseases on Earth.
Summary:
Background: The abstract for this paper was not found in the provided data. The title suggests the research investigates the effect of microgravity on the development of oligodendrocyte progenitors (OPCs), which mature into myelinating oligodendrocytes. This has implications for both spaceflight, where neurological changes occur, and for diseases like multiple sclerosis (MS), which are characterized by a failure to repair myelin.

Methods: The abstract was not found. The study likely involved culturing OPCs in a simulated microgravity environment (e.g., using a clinostat or rotating wall vessel) and comparing their maturation process to cells grown in normal gravity. The researchers would have assessed the differentiation of OPCs into mature oligodendrocytes, likely using markers for different developmental stages and measuring myelination capacity.

Results: The abstract was not found. The title indicates a key finding: microgravity delays the maturation of OPCs. This means that the cells remain in an immature progenitor state for longer and are less efficient at becoming fully functional, myelin-producing cells.

Conclusions: The conclusion was not found. The study likely concludes that the microgravity-induced delay in OPC maturation could be a contributing factor to the neurological symptoms seen in astronauts. Furthermore, it suggests that the mechanisms governing this delay might be relevant to understanding why remyelination often fails in patients with multiple sclerosis, opening new avenues for research into both conditions.

Title: Space Microgravity Alters Neural Stem Cell Division: Implications for Brain Cancer Research on Earth and in Space
Abstract: Considering the imminence of long-term space travel, it is necessary to investigate the impact of space microgravity (SPC-µG) in order to determine if this environment has consequences on the astronauts’ health, in particular, neural and cognitive functions. Neural stem cells (NSCs) are the basis for the regeneration of the central nervous system (CNS) cell populations and learning how weightlessness impacts NSCs in health and disease provides a critical tool for the potential mitigation of specific mechanisms leading to neurological disorders. In previous studies, we found that exposure to SPC-µG resulted in enhanced proliferation, a shortened cell cycle, and a larger cell diameter of NSCs compared to control cells. Here, we report the frequent occurrence of abnormal cell division (ACD) including incomplete cell division (ICD), where cytokinesis is not successfully completed, and multi-daughter cell division (MDCD) of NSCs following SPC-µG as well as secretome exposure compared to ground control (1G) NSCs. These findings provide new insights into the potential health implications of space travel and have far-reaching implications for understanding the mechanisms leading to the deleterious effects of long-term space travel as well as potential carcinogenic susceptibility. Knowledge of these mechanisms could help to develop preventive or corrective measures for successful long-term SPC-µG exposure.
Overview: This study uncovers a concerning effect of microgravity on neural stem cells, with potential implications for both astronaut health and cancer research. Researchers found that after exposure to space microgravity, human neural stem cells (NSCs) frequently underwent abnormal cell divisions, either failing to complete cytokinesis or dividing into multiple daughter cells. This finding is significant as it provides new insights into the potential neurological risks of long-term space travel and suggests that microgravity could be a tool for studying mechanisms related to genomic instability and carcinogenesis.
Summary:
Background: As long-term space travel becomes more feasible, it is necessary to understand how microgravity impacts neural and cognitive functions. Neural stem cells (NSCs) are crucial for CNS regeneration. Previous studies showed that space microgravity (SPC-µG) enhances NSC proliferation.

Methods: The study examined the cell division process of human NSCs following exposure to actual space microgravity as well as to the secretome (conditioned media) from space-flown cells. The researchers looked for the occurrence of abnormal cell division (ACD) and compared the frequency to that of ground control (1G) NSCs.

Results: A frequent occurrence of abnormal cell division was observed in NSCs following exposure to SPC-µG and their secretome. These abnormalities included incomplete cell division (ICD), where the two daughter cells fail to separate, and multi-daughter cell division (MDCD), where a cell divides into more than two cells. These phenomena were not seen as frequently in the ground control cells.

Conclusions: The findings provide new insights into the potential health implications of space travel, particularly regarding neurological function and potential carcinogenic susceptibility. The authors suggest that knowledge of these mechanisms could help in the development of preventive or corrective measures for long-term space missions.

Title: Oligodendrocyte Progenitors Display Enhanced Proliferation and Autophagy after Space Flight
Abstract: Intracranial hypertension (ICP) and visual impairment intracranial pressure (VIIP) are some of the consequences of long-term space missions. Here we examined the behavior of oligodendrocyte progenitors (OLPs) after space flight using time-lapse microscopy. We show that most OLPs divided more than ground control (GC) counterparts did. Nonetheless, a subpopulation of OLPs flown to space presented a significant increase in autophagic cell death. Examination of the proteomic profile of the secretome of space flown OLPs (SPC-OLPs) revealed that the stress protein heat shock protein-90 beta “HSP-90β” was the 5th most enriched (6.8 times) and the secreted protein acidic and rich in cysteine “SPARC” was the 7th most enriched (5.2 times), with respect to ground control cells. SPARC induces endoplasmic reticulum stress, which leads to autophagy. Given the roles and importance of these two proteins in mammalian cells’ metabolism, their upregulation may hold the key to modulating cell proliferation and autophagy, in order to mitigate ICP and VIIP during and after space missions.
Overview: This study reveals a dual effect of spaceflight on oligodendrocyte progenitors (OLPs), the cells that produce myelin in the brain, with important implications for astronaut health. Researchers found that while spaceflight enhances the proliferation of these cells, it also triggers a significant increase in autophagic cell death. Proteomic analysis linked this to the upregulation of stress proteins like HSP-90β and SPARC, the latter of which is known to induce autophagy. This is a critical finding for understanding the mechanisms behind intracranial pressure and visual impairment in space, pointing to key proteins for potential countermeasures.
Summary:
Background: Long-term space missions can lead to health issues like intracranial hypertension (ICP) and visual impairment intracranial pressure (VIIP). This study examined the behavior of oligodendrocyte progenitors (OLPs), the myelin-forming cells of the central nervous system, after a spaceflight mission.

Methods: The researchers used time-lapse microscopy to observe the division and survival of OLPs after they were flown in space. They also analyzed the proteomic profile of the secretome (secreted proteins) from the space-flown OLPs (SPC-OLPs) and compared it to ground control cells.

Results: Most of the space-flown OLPs divided more than their ground control counterparts, indicating enhanced proliferation. However, a subpopulation of the SPC-OLPs also showed a significant increase in autophagic cell death. The proteomic analysis revealed that the stress protein HSP-90β and the secreted protein SPARC were highly enriched in the secretome of SPC-OLPs. SPARC is known to induce endoplasmic reticulum stress, which leads to autophagy.

Conclusions: The upregulation of HSP-90β and SPARC may be key to modulating the observed increase in both cell proliferation and autophagy in OLPs after spaceflight. The authors suggest that understanding the roles of these two proteins could be crucial for developing ways to mitigate conditions like ICP and VIIP during and after space missions.

Title: Metabolomics profile of the secretome of space-flown oligodendrocytes.
Abstract: Intracranial hypertension (ICP) and visual impairment intracranial pressure (VIIP) are some of the sequels of long-term space missions. Here we sought to determine how space microgravity (µG) impacts the metabolomics profile of oligodendrocyte progenitors (OLPs), the myelin-forming cells in the central nervous system. We report increased glutamate and energy metabolism while the OLPs were in space for 26 days. We also show that after space flight, OLPs (SPC OLPs) display significantly increased mitochondrial respiration and glycolysis. These data are in agreement with our previous work using simulated microgravity. In addition, our global metabolomics approach allowed for the discovery of endogenous metabolites secreted by OLPs while in space that are significantly modulated by microgravity. Our results provide, for the first time, relevant information about the energetic state of OLPs while in space and after space flight. The functional and molecular relevance of these specific pathways are promising targets for therapeutic intervention for humans in long-term space missions to the moon, Mars and beyond.
Overview: This study provides a detailed metabolic snapshot of oligodendrocyte progenitors (OLPs) in space, offering crucial insights into the neurological challenges of long-term missions, such as intracranial hypertension. By analyzing the secretome of OLPs flown on the ISS, researchers found that microgravity leads to increased glutamate and energy metabolism. This heightened energetic state, confirmed by post-flight analysis of mitochondrial respiration and glycolysis, reveals specific metabolic pathways that are altered by spaceflight and could serve as promising targets for therapeutic interventions to protect astronaut brain health.
Summary:
Background: Long-term space missions are associated with health issues like intracranial hypertension (ICP) and visual impairment (VIIP). This study aimed to determine how space microgravity (µG) impacts the metabolic profile of oligodendrocyte progenitors (OLPs), the myelin-forming cells of the central nervous system.

Methods: The researchers analyzed the metabolomic profile of the secretome (molecules secreted into the culture medium) from OLPs that were flown in space for 26 days. After the spaceflight, the cells' mitochondrial respiration and glycolysis rates were measured and compared to ground controls.

Results: The analysis of the in-flight secretome revealed that microgravity caused an increase in glutamate and energy metabolism. Post-flight analysis confirmed that the space-flown OLPs displayed significantly increased mitochondrial respiration and glycolysis, consistent with previous work using simulated microgravity. This global metabolomics approach identified endogenous metabolites and pathways that are significantly modulated by space microgravity.

Conclusions: The study provides, for the first time, relevant information about the energetic state of OLPs both during and after spaceflight. The specific metabolic pathways that are activated by microgravity are identified as promising targets for developing therapeutic interventions to protect human health on long-term space missions.

Title: Metabolomic profiling of the secretome from human neural stem cells flown into space.
Abstract: The change in gravitational force has a significant effect on biological tissues and the entire organism. As with any alteration in the environment, microgravity (µG) produces modifications in the system inducing adaptation to the new condition. In this study, we analyzed the effect of µG on neural stem cells (NSCs) following a space flight to the International Space Station (ISS). After 3 days in space, analysis of the metabolome in culture medium revealed increased glycolysis with augmented pyruvate and glycerate levels, and activated catabolism of branched-chain amino acids (BCAA) and glutamine. NSCs flown into space (SPC-NSCs) also showed increased synthesis of NADH and formation of polyamine spermidine when compared to ground controls (GC-NSCs). Overall, the space environment appears to increase energy demands in response to the µG setting.
Overview: This study provides a unique metabolic profile of human neural stem cells (NSCs) during spaceflight, revealing that the microgravity environment places increased energy demands on these critical cells. By analyzing the culture medium of NSCs flown on the ISS, researchers found evidence of increased glycolysis, activated catabolism of key amino acids, and enhanced synthesis of NADH. This is an important finding for understanding the fundamental cellular response to space travel, as it suggests that the adaptation to weightlessness requires a significant metabolic shift in these progenitor cells.
Summary:
Background: The change in gravitational force has a significant effect on biological systems, inducing adaptations to the new environment. This study aimed to analyze the metabolic effect of microgravity (µG) on human neural stem cells (NSCs) following a 3-day spaceflight to the International Space Station (ISS).

Methods: The researchers analyzed the metabolome of the culture medium (the secretome) in which human NSCs were grown during a 3-day spaceflight. This allowed them to identify the metabolites that were consumed or secreted by the cells while they were in space, and these were compared to ground controls.

Results: The analysis revealed several key metabolic changes in the space-flown NSCs (SPC-NSCs). There was evidence of increased glycolysis, with augmented levels of pyruvate and glycerate. The cells also showed activated catabolism of branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs) and glutamine. Furthermore, there was increased synthesis of NADH and the polyamine spermidine in the SPC-NSCs compared to ground controls.

Conclusions: The overall finding is that the space environment appears to increase the energy demands of neural stem cells as they adapt to the microgravity setting. The specific metabolic shifts identified provide insights into the cellular response to spaceflight.

Title: Strategies, research priorities, and challenges for the exploration of space beyond low-Earth orbit
Abstract: Space exploration objectives will soon move from low Earth orbit to distant destinations like Moon and Mars. The present work provides an up-to-date roadmap that identifies critical research gaps related to human behavior and performance in altered gravity and space. The roadmap summarizes (1) key neurobehavioral challenges associated with spaceflight, (2) the need to consider sex as a biological variable, (3) the use of integrative omics technologies to elucidate mechanisms underlying changes in the brain and behavior, and (4) the importance of understanding the neural representation of gravity throughout the brain and its multisensory processing. We then highlight the need for a variety of target-specific countermeasures, and a personalized administration schedule as two critical strategies for mitigating potentially adverse effects of spaceflight on the central nervous system and performance. We conclude with a summary of key priorities for the roadmaps of current and future space programs and stress the importance of new collaborative strategies across agencies and researchers for fostering an integrative cross- and transdisciplinary approach from cells, molecules to neural circuits and cognitive performance. Finally, we highlight that space research in neurocognitive science goes beyond monitoring and mitigating risks in astronauts but could also have significant benefits for the population on Earth.
Overview: This paper serves as a vital roadmap for future human space exploration beyond low-Earth orbit, identifying key research gaps in neurobehavioral health. It summarizes the challenges of altered gravity on human performance, stresses the importance of studying sex differences, and advocates for using integrative 'omics' and personalized countermeasures. It's a must-read for space agencies and researchers, as it outlines a transdisciplinary strategy for mitigating the adverse effects of spaceflight on the central nervous system and ensuring mission success.
Summary:
Background: As space exploration plans move from low Earth orbit to distant destinations like the Moon and Mars, it is critical to identify and address research gaps related to human behavior and performance in the altered gravity and unique stress environments of space.

Methods: This is a roadmap and perspective article. It summarizes key neurobehavioral challenges associated with spaceflight, discusses the need to consider sex as a biological variable, promotes the use of integrative omics technologies to understand mechanisms, and emphasizes the importance of understanding the brain's multisensory processing of gravity.

Results: The paper highlights several key research priorities. It identifies the need for a variety of target-specific countermeasures and the development of personalized administration schedules to mitigate the potentially adverse effects of spaceflight on the central nervous system and cognitive performance. It stresses the importance of a collaborative, transdisciplinary approach that integrates research from the molecular level to overall performance.

Conclusions: The authors conclude by summarizing key priorities for the roadmaps of future space programs. They emphasize that new collaborative strategies across agencies and researchers are necessary to foster an integrative research approach. They also highlight that space neurocognitive science not only helps to mitigate risks for astronauts but could also have significant health benefits for the population on Earth.

Title: Spaceflight Induces Specific Alterations in the Proteomes of Arabidopsis
Abstract: Abstract Life in spaceflight demonstrates remarkable acclimation processes within the specialized habitats of vehicles subjected to the myriad of unique environmental issues associated with orbital trajectories. To examine the response processes that occur in plants in space, leaves and roots from Arabidopsis (Arabidopsis thaliana) seedlings from three GFP reporter lines that were grown from seed for 12 days on the International Space Station and preserved on orbit in RNAlater were returned to Earth and analyzed by using iTRAQ broad-scale proteomics procedures. Using stringent criteria, we identified over 1500 proteins, which included 1167 leaf proteins and 1150 root proteins we were able to accurately quantify. Quantification revealed 256 leaf proteins and 358 root proteins that showed statistically significant differential abundance in the spaceflight samples compared to ground controls, with few proteins differentially regulated in common between leaves and roots. This indicates that there are measurable proteomics responses to spaceflight and that the responses are organ-specific. These proteomics data were compared with transcriptome data from similar spaceflight samples, showing that there is a positive but limited relationship between transcriptome and proteome regulation of the overall spaceflight responses of plants. These results are discussed in terms of emergence understanding of plant responses to spaceflight particularly with regard to cell wall remodeling, as well as in the context of deriving multiple omics data sets from a single on-orbit preservation and operations approach. Key Words: Space biology—Proteomics—Gene expression—ISS. Astrobiology 15, 32–56.
Overview: This study provides a detailed molecular snapshot of how different plant organs respond to spaceflight, making it a valuable resource for space biology. By conducting a broad-scale proteomic analysis of Arabidopsis seedlings grown on the ISS, researchers found that leaves and roots show distinct and largely separate protein abundance changes. This organ-specific response, which has only a limited correlation with transcriptome data, highlights the complexity of plant adaptation to space and emphasizes the importance of studying specific tissues to understand processes like cell wall remodeling.
Summary:
Background: To understand how plants acclimate to the unique environment of space, this study aimed to characterize the proteomic responses in different plant organs.

Methods: Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings from three different GFP reporter lines were grown from seed for 12 days on the International Space Station (ISS). The leaves and roots were preserved on-orbit in RNAlater. Upon return to Earth, the researchers used iTRAQ broad-scale proteomics procedures to identify and quantify proteins in the spaceflight samples and compare them to ground controls. The proteomic data were also compared with transcriptome data from similar spaceflight samples.

Results: The analysis accurately quantified over 1100 proteins in both leaves and roots. It revealed that 256 leaf proteins and 358 root proteins showed statistically significant differential abundance in the spaceflight samples. Very few of these differentially regulated proteins were common between leaves and roots, indicating a highly organ-specific response. The comparison with transcriptome data showed a positive but limited relationship between changes at the RNA and protein levels.

Conclusions: The study concludes that there are measurable proteomic responses to spaceflight and that these responses are organ-specific. The findings contribute to the emerging understanding of plant responses to spaceflight, particularly in the context of cell wall remodeling, and demonstrate the utility of on-orbit preservation for multi-omics analysis.

Title: The effect of spaceflight on the gravity-sensing auxin gradient of roots: GFP reporter gene microscopy on orbit.
Abstract: Our primary aim was to determine whether gravity has a direct role in establishing the auxin-mediated gravity-sensing system in primary roots. Major plant architectures have long been thought to be guided by gravity, including the directional growth of the primary root via auxin gradients that are then disturbed when roots deviate from the vertical as a gravity sensor. However, experiments on the International Space Station (ISS) now allow physical clarity with regard to any assumptions regarding the role of gravity in establishing fundamental root auxin distributions. We examined the spaceflight green fluorescent protein (GFP)-reporter gene expression in roots of transgenic lines of Arabidopsis thaliana: pDR5r::GFP, pTAA1::TAA1–GFP, pSCR::SCR–GFP to monitor auxin and pARR5::GFP to monitor cytokinin. Plants on the ISS were imaged live with the Light Microscopy Module (LMM), and compared with control plants imaged on the ground. Preserved spaceflight and ground control plants were examined post flight with confocal microscopy. Plants on orbit, growing in the absence of any physical reference to the terrestrial gravity vector, displayed typically “vertical” distribution of auxin in the primary root. This confirms that the establishment of the auxin-gradient system, the primary guide for gravity signaling in the root, is gravity independent. The cytokinin distribution in the root tip differs between spaceflight and the ground controls, suggesting spaceflight-induced features of root growth may be cytokinin related. The distribution of auxin in the gravity-sensing portion of the root is not dependent on gravity. Spaceflight appears benign to auxin and its role in the development of the primary root tip, whereas spaceflight may influence cytokinin-associated processes.
Overview: This study provides a definitive answer to a fundamental question in plant biology by demonstrating that the establishment of the auxin gradient in the root tip—the core of the gravity-sensing system—is independent of gravity itself. Using live microscopy of reporter-gene plants on the International Space Station, researchers showed that this critical developmental pattern forms normally in the absence of a gravity vector. This is a crucial read as it confirms a long-held assumption and allows scientists to focus on how gravity acts to perturb this pre-established system, rather than create it.
Summary:
Background: The directional growth of plant roots has long been thought to be guided by gravity, which acts on an auxin gradient established in the root tip. However, it was an unproven assumption whether gravity itself was required to establish this auxin-gradient system in the first place.

Methods: The researchers used transgenic lines of Arabidopsis thaliana with Green Fluorescent Protein (GFP) reporter genes to monitor the distribution of auxin (pDR5r::GFP, pTAA1::TAA1–GFP) and cytokinin (pARR5::GFP), as well as a key developmental marker (pSCR::SCR–GFP). Plants were grown on the International Space Station (ISS) and imaged live with the Light Microscopy Module (LMM). The images were compared with those from ground control plants, and preserved samples were analyzed post-flight with confocal microscopy.

Results: Plants growing on orbit, in the absence of a directional gravity vector, displayed a normal, vertically-oriented distribution of auxin in the primary root tip, similar to what is seen on Earth. This confirms that the establishment of the auxin-gradient system is gravity-independent. In contrast, the distribution of the cytokinin reporter was different between spaceflight and ground controls, suggesting that some aspects of spaceflight-induced growth changes may be cytokinin-related.

Conclusions: The study concludes that the distribution of auxin in the gravity-sensing portion of the root is not dependent on gravity for its establishment. Spaceflight appears to be benign to the initial development of the auxin system in the root tip, solidifying our understanding of how gravitropism works.

Title: Skewing in Arabidopsis roots involves disparate environmental signaling pathways.
Abstract: BackgroundSkewing root patterns provide key insights into root growth strategies and mechanisms that produce root architectures. Roots exhibit skewing and waving when grown on a tilted, impenetrable surface. The genetics guiding these morphologies have been examined, revealing that some Arabidopsis ecotypes skew and wave (e.g. WS), while others skew insignificantly but still wave (e.g. Col-0). The underlying molecular mechanisms of skewing and waving remain unclear. In this study, transcriptome data were derived from two Arabidopsis ecotypes, WS and Col-0, under three tilted growth conditions in order to identify candidate genes involved in skewing. ResultsThis work identifies a number of genes that are likely involved in skewing, using growth conditions that differentially affect skewing and waving. Comparing the gene expression profiles of WS and Col-0 in different tilted growth conditions identified 11 candidate genes as potentially involved in the control of skewing. These 11 genes are involved in several different cellular processes, including sugar transport, salt signaling, cell wall organization, and hormone signaling. ConclusionsThis study identified 11 genes whose change in expression level is associated with root skewing behavior. These genes are involved in signaling and perception, rather than the physical restructuring of root. Future work is needed to elucidate the potential role of these candidate genes during root skewing. Electronic supplementary materialThe online version of this article (doi:10.1186/s12870-017-0975-9) contains supplementary material, which is available to authorized users.
Conclusion: This work investigated the transcriptional differences between skewing and non-skewing roots. Comparisons within WS revealed genes that responded to the angle of growth (Agp) during the process of skewing. These genes were cross referenced with transcripts differing between the WS and Col-0 genotypes to refine the list of genes that are most probably be involved in root skewing. A majority of the highly probable skew gene candidates (HPSGC) are directly associated with environmental sensing (e.g. salt, sugar, hormones, darkness), upstream of physical growth differences (e.g. cell wall remodeling, cell division, cell elongation). Thus, pathways that respond to disparate signals from the root local environment may drive the root behavior of skewing. However, it is also possible that some of the HPSGC are responses to the altered phenotype, rather than the basis of the phenotype. In order to separate these two hypotheses, future studies could investigate the HPSGC to find the specific pathways and molecular mechanisms contributing to root skewing.
Overview: This study provides a valuable genetic starting point for dissecting the molecular mechanisms behind root skewing, a complex growth behavior in plants. By comparing the transcriptomes of two Arabidopsis ecotypes with different skewing tendencies under various tilted growth conditions, the researchers identified 11 candidate genes potentially involved in this process. Importantly, these genes are linked to environmental sensing and signaling pathways (salt, sugar, hormones) rather than structural components, suggesting that skewing is an integrative response to multiple local cues.
Summary:
Background: The skewing and waving patterns of roots grown on tilted, impenetrable surfaces offer insights into root growth strategies. While the genetics guiding these behaviors are known to vary between different Arabidopsis ecotypes (e.g., WS skews, Col-0 does not), the underlying molecular mechanisms remain unclear. This study aimed to identify candidate genes for skewing by analyzing gene expression.

Methods: The researchers grew two Arabidopsis ecotypes, WS (which skews) and Col-0 (which does not), under three different tilted growth conditions designed to differentially affect skewing and waving. They then performed a transcriptome analysis (microarray) to compare the gene expression profiles between the two ecotypes and across the different conditions.

Results: The comparison of gene expression profiles identified 11 candidate genes whose expression levels were associated with the root skewing behavior. These 11 genes were found to be involved in a variety of cellular processes, including sugar transport, salt signaling, cell wall organization, and hormone signaling.

Conclusions: The study identified 11 genes likely involved in root skewing. The fact that a majority of these candidates are associated with environmental sensing and signaling, rather than the physical machinery of root growth, suggests that skewing is a complex behavior driven by the integration of disparate signals from the root's local environment. Future work is needed to confirm the specific roles of these candidate genes.

Title: Data for characterization of SALK_084889, a T-DNA insertion line of Arabidopsis thaliana
Abstract: In this article we report the identification of T-DNA (transfer DNA) insertion sites within two different gene regions in the genome of an Arabidopsis mutant line, SALK_084889. The T-DNA positions are in the 3′ UTR (untranslated region) of DREB2A (Dehydration-responsive element-binding protein 2A) (AT5G05410) and promoter of LOX1 (Lipoxygenase 1) (AT1G55020) as determined by DNA-PCR and sanger sequencing. The expression levels of DREB2A and LOX1 were also analyzed using quantitative realtime PCR (qPCR) in SALK_084889 and wild type Arabidopsis (Col, Columbia). Further, the comparison of drought and heat tolerance between Col and SALK_084889 were conducted by stress treatments. The present data indicate that in SALK_084889, the expression of DREB2A is not downregulated under normal growth conditions but can be affected only in roots under drought treatment, while LOX1 is significantly downregulated in both roots and shoots under all tested conditions. These data are original and have not been published elsewhere.
Overview: This data-in-brief article provides a detailed characterization of the Arabidopsis T-DNA insertion line SALK_084889, which is a valuable resource for plant stress-response researchers. The authors precisely identify the T-DNA insertion sites in the DREB2A and LOX1 genes and quantify the resulting changes in gene expression. Their findings clarify that this specific line is a significant LOX1 knockdown mutant but has only a minor, condition-specific effect on DREB2A, providing crucial information for the correct interpretation of any experiments using this publicly available mutant line.
Summary:
Background: This article reports on the molecular characterization of a specific T-DNA insertion mutant line of Arabidopsis, SALK_084889, to clarify its genetic nature and effects on gene expression.

Methods: The researchers used DNA-PCR and Sanger sequencing to precisely determine the locations of the T-DNA insertions within the Arabidopsis genome for the SALK_084889 line. They then used quantitative real-time PCR (qPCR) to analyze the expression levels of the two affected genes, DREB2A (a drought-responsive transcription factor) and LOX1 (a lipoxygenase), in the mutant line compared to the wild type (Col-0). Drought and heat tolerance were also compared between the lines.

Results: The T-DNA was found to have inserted into two different gene regions: the 3' untranslated region (UTR) of the DREB2A gene and the promoter of the LOX1 gene. The expression analysis revealed that LOX1 was significantly downregulated in both roots and shoots under all tested conditions. In contrast, the expression of DREB2A was not downregulated under normal conditions and was only affected in the roots during a drought treatment.

Conclusions: The data indicate that the SALK_084889 line is a strong knockdown mutant for the LOX1 gene. Its effect on the DREB2A gene is much more subtle and condition-dependent. This detailed characterization provides important information for any researcher planning to use this specific mutant line in their experiments.

Title: Genetic dissection of the Arabidopsis spaceflight transcriptome: Are some responses dispensable for the physiological adaptation of plants to spaceflight?
Abstract: Experimentation on the International Space Station has reached the stage where repeated and nuanced transcriptome studies are beginning to illuminate the structural and metabolic differences between plants grown in space compared to plants on the Earth. Genes that are important in establishing the spaceflight responses are being identified, their roles in spaceflight physiological adaptation are increasingly understood, and the fact that different genotypes adapt differently is recognized. However, the basic question of whether these spaceflight responses are actually required for survival has yet to be posed, and the fundamental notion that spaceflight responses may be non-adaptive has yet to be explored. Therefore the experiments presented here were designed to ask if portions of the plant spaceflight response can be genetically removed without causing loss of spaceflight survival and without causing increased stress responses. The CARA experiment compared the spaceflight transcriptome responses in the root tips of two Arabidopsis ecotypes, Col-0 and WS, as well as that of a PhyD mutant of Col-0. When grown with the ambient light of the ISS, phyD plants displayed a significantly reduced spaceflight transcriptome response compared to Col-0, suggesting that altering the activity of a single gene can actually improve spaceflight adaptation by reducing the transcriptome cost of physiological adaptation. The WS genotype showed an even simpler spaceflight transcriptome response in the ambient light of the ISS, more broadly indicating that the plant genotype can be manipulated to reduce the cost of spaceflight adaptation, as measured by transcriptional response. These differential genotypic responses suggest that genetic manipulation could further reduce, or perhaps eliminate the metabolic cost of spaceflight adaptation. When plants were germinated and then left in the dark on the ISS, the WS genotype actually mounted a larger transcriptome response than Col-0, suggesting that the in-space light environment affects physiological adaptation, which implies that manipulating the local habitat can also substantially impact the metabolic cost of spaceflight adaptation.
Conclusion: The primary conclusion of this work is that much of the plant response to spaceflight is potentially non-adaptive in that at least most of the gene expression responses could be genetically eliminated without overtly compromising growth in space. This suggests that responses to truly novel environments may include responses from signals that are inappropriately activated or misinterpreted, and further suggests that these inappropriate responses can be genetically eliminated without adverse consequences. For spaceflight in particular, these data suggest that genetic manipulation can produce varieties that are better adapted to growth in spaceflight through elimination of unnecessary responses. A secondary conclusion of this work is that there is no fundamental spaceflight response that characterizes plant physiological adaptation to spaceflight. Rather, the adaptive response is dependent upon the genotype of the plant and the specific environment within which it grows. The response also appears highly organ specific, as roots and leaves share few spaceflight differential genes in common [38, 47]. And yet, it remains possible and even likely that classes of differentially expressed genes will continue to be shared amongst cell types, genotypes and environments in space. However there is no overt indication that specific genes will be differentially expressed in all spaceflight plants. These conclusions lie in sharp contrast to evolutionarily defined and well characterized terrestrial stress responses. Heat shock, cold shock, salt, pathogen attack and other stresses show commonality of differential expression across cell types and local environments. HSPs are HSPs in all plant cells. Since no such commonality exists in spaceflight responses, it appears that at least large portions of the spaceflight responses in plants are not necessary, and therefore can be eliminated without negative impact on plant life in spaceflight and opening the possibility of selecting plant genotypes optimized for spaceflight growth. The differential expression of categories of genes, rather than individual genes, exhibited in the overall plant spaceflight response could be interpreted as support for the notion that certain categories of responses are either necessary for spaceflight physiological adaptation, or a common consequence of interpreting this novel environment. A common theme that appears to remain consistent among plant spaceflight transcriptomes is that of cell wall remodeling. Genes encoding proteins associated with cell wall remodeling have characterized the spaceflight response among several experiments and genotypes [23, 38, 47, 48, 51, 52, 56, 57, 65]. Cell wall remodeling genes are represented in the differentially expressed genes are richly represented in this experiment as well (Fig 6, Supporting S2 and S3 Tables). Thus cell wall remodeling appears to be, for the most part, a requirement or an unavoidable consequence of spaceflight physiological adaptation. Yet the differential gene expression that characterizes that response may be highly cell, genotype and environment specific, and indeed may not actually be required for successful adaptation. Future experiments can be directed to establishing the minimal responses to spaceflight by further mutational and environmental manipulations, and can thereby contribute to systems engineering of spaceflight habitats. Plant growth in actual life support functions within space exploration is an important technical engineering challenge. Growing plants on petri plates allows what is likely the most benign growth system possible in spaceflight absent artificial gravity. Water management is not necessary, as the Phytagel provides water to the roots without potential flooding that can be seen in larger scale plant production systems on orbit or within exploration vehicles. Light and air management is quite similar to situations in terrestrial laboratories. It is quite possible that more stress responses will be seen in larger plant growth units on orbit, where water, nutrient and air management become more of an issue than for plants grown on plates. Engineering solutions to those issues can draw upon these plants-on-plates to better understand achievable stress reduction goals.
Overview: This study offers a paradigm-shifting perspective on plant adaptation to spaceflight, suggesting that many of the observed gene expression changes may be non-adaptive and genetically dispensable. By comparing the transcriptomes of two Arabidopsis ecotypes and a phyD mutant on the ISS, researchers found that the phyD mutant had a significantly reduced transcriptional response to spaceflight without any apparent loss of survival. This groundbreaking finding implies that plant responses to novel environments are not always necessary and that genetic manipulation could be used to create varieties that are better adapted to space by eliminating these unnecessary metabolic costs.
Summary:
Background: While it is known that plants alter their gene expression to adapt to spaceflight, it has not been questioned whether all of these responses are actually required for survival. This study was designed to ask if parts of the plant spaceflight response could be genetically removed without causing increased stress or loss of viability.

Methods: The researchers compared the spaceflight transcriptome responses in the root tips of three different Arabidopsis genotypes grown on the International Space Station (ISS): two wild ecotypes (Col-0 and WS) and a phyD mutant of Col-0. The plants were grown in both the ambient light of the ISS and in complete darkness.

Results: In ambient ISS light, the phyD mutant displayed a significantly reduced spaceflight transcriptome response compared to its Col-0 wild type. The WS ecotype showed an even simpler transcriptional response. These results indicate that the 'cost' of spaceflight adaptation, as measured by transcriptional changes, can be reduced by altering a single gene or by using a different genetic background. In darkness, the WS genotype mounted a larger transcriptome response than Col-0, showing that the light environment also impacts the adaptive response.

Conclusions: The primary conclusion is that much of the plant's transcriptional response to spaceflight may be non-adaptive, as it can be genetically eliminated without compromising growth in space. This suggests that genetic manipulation could produce plant varieties that are better adapted for growth in spaceflight by removing unnecessary responses. A secondary conclusion is that there is no single, fundamental spaceflight response; instead, it is highly dependent on the plant's genotype and its specific growth environment.

Title: Phenotypic characterization of an Arabidopsis T- DNA insertion line SALK_063500
Abstract: In this article we report the identification of a homozygous lethal T-DNA (transfer DNA) line within the coding region of the At1G05290 gene in the genome of Arabidopsis thaliana (Arabidopsis) line, SALK_063500. The T-DNA insertion is found within exon one of the AT1G05290 gene, however a homozygous T-DNA allele is unattainable. In the heterozygous T-DNA allele the expression levels of AT1G05290 were compared to wild type Arabidopsis (Col-0, Columbia). Further analyses revealed an aberrant silique phenotype found in the heterozygous SALK_063500 plants that is attributed to the reduced rate of pollen tube germination. These data are original and have not been published elsewhere.
Overview: This data-in-brief article provides a critical characterization of the Arabidopsis T-DNA line SALK_063500, identifying the gene AT1G05290 as essential for plant reproduction. The researchers found that it is impossible to obtain a plant that is homozygous for the T-DNA insertion, indicating that the gene is lethal when fully knocked out. Importantly, they linked the heterozygous state to a defect in pollen tube germination, which results in an aberrant silique phenotype. This information is crucial for any researcher working with this gene or mutant line.
Summary:
Background: This article reports on the phenotypic and genetic characterization of a specific T-DNA insertion mutant line of Arabidopsis, SALK_063500, to determine the function of the affected gene.

Methods: The researchers identified the location of the T-DNA insertion within the coding region of the AT1G05290 gene. They attempted to generate homozygous mutant plants but were unable to do so. They then compared the gene expression levels of AT1G05290 in heterozygous plants to the wild type (Col-0). The phenotype of the heterozygous plants was analyzed, with a focus on silique (seed pod) morphology and pollen function.

Results: The study found that a homozygous T-DNA insertion in the AT1G05290 gene is lethal. Heterozygous plants were viable but displayed an aberrant silique phenotype. Further analysis revealed that this was caused by a reduced rate of pollen tube germination, indicating a defect in male gametophyte function.

Conclusions: The data indicate that the gene AT1G05290 is essential for the viability of Arabidopsis, likely playing a crucial role in pollen function and fertilization. The characterization of this homozygous lethal line provides important information for the plant biology community.

Title: Utilization of single-image normalized difference vegetation index (SI-NDVI) for early plant stress detection
Abstract: Premise of the StudyAn imaging system was refined to monitor the health of vegetation grown in controlled conditions using spectral reflectance patterns. To measure plant health, the single‐image normalized difference vegetation index (SI‐NDVI) compares leaf reflectance in visible and near‐infrared light spectrums. Methods and ResultsThe SI‐NDVI imaging system was characterized to assess plant responses to stress before visual detection during controlled stress assays. Images were analyzed using Fiji image processing software and Microsoft Excel to create qualitative false color images and quantitative graphs to detect plant stress. ConclusionsStress was detected in Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings within 15 min of salinity application using SI‐NDVI analysis, before stress was visible. Stress was also observed during ammonium nitrate treatment of Eruca sativa plants before visual detection. Early detection of plant stress is possible using SI‐NDVI imaging, which is both simpler to use and more cost efficient than traditional dual‐image NDVI or hyper‐spectral imaging.
Conclusion: Compared to traditional NDVI or hyper‐spectral imaging approaches, the dollar cost of implementing an SI‐NDVI imaging system is low because SI‐NDVI requires only one camera and can rely on completely free, open source software for analysis. In addition, the implementation barriers within a laboratory setting or greenhouse facilities are essentially nonexistent. To optimize SI‐NDVI imaging to be similar to the historical NDVI applications, precise application of light in the blue and NIR spectrums can be supplied using controlled lighting (Fig. 2). In our study, this was accomplished through the use of programmable LED lighting. Alternatively, NDVI cameras have been developed to function in natural lighting, such as the smart NDVI camera developed by Dworak and colleagues (Dworak et al., 2013). This study demonstrated that SI‐NDVI imaging allows for detection of plant stress before it is apparent to the human eye, in controlled conditions using two of the many potential stresses that may be of interest in the laboratory or greenhouse. This work has demonstrated that the SI‐NDVI imaging system is capable of enabling detection of stress in Arabidopsis seedlings within 15 min of exposure to salt on agar plates (Figs. 4, 6) and in young arugula plants on soil within 6 h of exposure to high concentrations of ammonium nitrate. When cultivating crops in controlled conditions, it is especially desirable to detect stress early to improve the overall success rate of cultivation. SI‐NDVI imaging has clear applications in the development of indoor farming practices, which are increasingly relied upon to provide fresh food to geographical areas not conducive to crop cultivation, such as in urban cities or areas of extreme temperature. Additionally, SI‐NDVI imaging could potentially be used as a high‐throughput screening technique for identification of mutant phenotypes in controlled laboratory plant studies. Hence, the implementation of SI‐NDVI will likely improve the success of controlled greenhouse or laboratory growing efforts, and should be tested further. This work has characterized an SI‐NDVI response curve corresponding to salt‐stressed agar‐grown Arabidopsis seedlings and ammonium nitrate–stressed soil‐grown arugula plants. Future research should work toward characterizing SI‐NDVI phenotypes for additional plant stressors, species, and growth mediums. Furthermore, future work should address practical concerns associated with deploying the SI‐NDVI method in real‐world controlled crop cultivation efforts.
Overview: This paper presents a simplified and cost-effective imaging system for the early detection of plant stress, which is highly valuable for controlled environment agriculture and laboratory research. The authors refine the single-image normalized difference vegetation index (SI-NDVI) method, which uses a single modified camera to compare visible and near-infrared light reflectance. They successfully demonstrate that this system can detect stress in Arabidopsis and arugula seedlings from salinity and high nutrient levels long before any visual symptoms appear, offering a powerful tool for proactive plant health monitoring.
Summary:
Background: Monitoring plant health in controlled environments often requires early detection of stress. The normalized difference vegetation index (NDVI), which measures differences in leaf reflectance, is a common tool for this. This study aimed to refine a simpler, more cost-effective version called the single-image NDVI (SI-NDVI).

Methods: An SI-NDVI imaging system was developed and characterized. The system was then used to monitor plant responses during controlled stress assays. Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings were subjected to salinity stress, and Eruca sativa (arugula) plants were treated with high concentrations of ammonium nitrate. Images were captured and analyzed using Fiji software to create false-color images and quantitative graphs to track the stress response over time.

Results: The SI-NDVI imaging system was able to detect stress in the Arabidopsis seedlings within just 15 minutes of salt application, well before any stress was visually apparent. Similarly, stress was observed in the arugula plants within 6 hours of ammonium nitrate treatment, again before it was visible to the naked eye.

Conclusions: The study concludes that early detection of plant stress is possible using SI-NDVI imaging. This method is noted to be both simpler to use and more cost-efficient than traditional dual-image NDVI or more complex hyperspectral imaging systems, making it a practical tool for improving the success of controlled crop cultivation.

Title: Comparing RNA-Seq and microarray gene expression data in two zones of the Arabidopsis root apex relevant to spaceflight.
Abstract: Premise of the StudyThe root apex is an important region involved in environmental sensing, but comprises a very small part of the root. Obtaining root apex transcriptomes is therefore challenging when the samples are limited. The feasibility of using tiny root sections for transcriptome analysis was examined, comparing RNA sequencing (RNA‐Seq) to microarrays in characterizing genes that are relevant to spaceflight. Methods Arabidopsis thaliana Columbia ecotype (Col‐0) roots were sectioned into Zone 1 (0.5 mm; root cap and meristematic zone) and Zone 2 (1.5 mm; transition, elongation, and growth‐terminating zone). Differential gene expression in each was compared. ResultsBoth microarrays and RNA‐Seq proved applicable to the small samples. A total of 4180 genes were differentially expressed (with fold changes of 2 or greater) between Zone 1 and Zone 2. In addition, 771 unique genes and 19 novel transcriptionally active regions were identified by RNA‐Seq that were not detected in microarrays. However, microarrays detected spaceflight‐relevant genes that were missed in RNA‐Seq. DiscussionSingle root tip subsections can be used for transcriptome analysis using either RNA‐Seq or microarrays. Both RNA‐Seq and microarrays provided novel information. These data suggest that techniques for dealing with small, rare samples from spaceflight can be further enhanced, and that RNA‐Seq may miss some spaceflight‐relevant changes in gene expression.
Overview: This study is a valuable methodological guide for plant researchers working with small or limited samples, such as those from spaceflight experiments. It directly compares the performance of RNA sequencing (RNA-Seq) and microarrays for analyzing the transcriptomes of tiny, specific zones of the Arabidopsis root apex. The paper demonstrates that both techniques are feasible for such small samples, but they provide different and complementary information; RNA-Seq identified novel genes, while microarrays were better at detecting some known spaceflight-relevant genes, highlighting important considerations for experimental design.
Summary:
Background: The root apex is a critical region for environmental sensing, but its small size makes it challenging to obtain enough material for transcriptome analysis, especially from rare samples like those from spaceflight. This study aimed to examine the feasibility of using tiny root sections for this purpose and to compare the results from two major transcriptome technologies, RNA sequencing (RNA-Seq) and microarrays.

Methods: Arabidopsis thaliana roots were sectioned into two small zones: Zone 1 (0.5 mm, containing the root cap and meristem) and Zone 2 (1.5 mm, the elongation zone). RNA was extracted from these tiny samples, and both microarray and RNA-Seq analyses were performed to identify differentially expressed genes between the two zones.

Results: Both techniques proved to be applicable to the small samples. A total of 4,180 genes were found to be differentially expressed between Zone 1 and Zone 2. RNA-Seq provided novel information by identifying 771 unique genes and 19 new transcriptionally active regions that were not detected by the microarrays. However, the microarrays were able to detect some known spaceflight-relevant genes that were missed in the RNA-Seq data.

Conclusions: The study concludes that single root tip subsections can be successfully used for transcriptome analysis with either RNA-Seq or microarrays. Importantly, it highlights that both technologies can provide novel and sometimes non-overlapping information. The finding that RNA-Seq may miss some spaceflight-relevant changes in gene expression is a key consideration for researchers designing experiments with limited and valuable samples.

Title: Spaceflight-induced alternative splicing during seedling development in Arabidopsis thaliana.
Abstract: Plants grown in spaceflight experience novel environmental signals, including those associated with microgravity and ionizing radiation. Spaceflight triggers a response involving transcriptional re-programming and altered cell morphology, though many aspects of this response remain uncharacterized. We analyzed the spaceflight-induced transcriptome with a focus on genes that undergo alternative splicing to examine differential splicing associated with spaceflight—an unstudied characteristic of the molecular response to spaceflight exposure. RNA sequence data obtained during the APEX03 spaceflight experiment that was collected from two Arabidopsis thaliana ecotypes at two seedling stages grown onboard the International Space Station, or as ground controls at Kennedy Space Center, were re-examined to detect alternative splicing differences induced by spaceflight. Presence/absence variation analysis was used to identify putative expression-level differences in alternatively spliced isoforms between spaceflight and ground controls and was followed by analysis of significant differential alternative splicing. This study provides the first evidence of a role for alternative splicing in the molecular processes of physiological adaptation to the spaceflight environment.
Overview: This study is the first to explore the role of alternative splicing in plant adaptation to spaceflight, a previously unexamined layer of gene regulation. By re-analyzing RNA-seq data from Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings grown on the ISS, researchers identified significant differential alternative splicing induced by the space environment. This is a crucial read for space biologists, as it reveals a new and complex molecular mechanism that plants use to respond to the novel stresses of space, expanding our understanding beyond simple changes in gene expression levels.
Summary:
Background: Plants grown in the novel environment of spaceflight exhibit transcriptional re-programming. However, the role of alternative splicing—a process where a single gene can produce multiple protein isoforms—in this adaptation process had not been previously studied.

Methods: The researchers re-examined RNA sequence data from the APEX03 spaceflight experiment. This experiment involved two different ecotypes of Arabidopsis thaliana grown for two different durations on the International Space Station. A presence/absence variation analysis was used to identify putative expression-level differences in alternatively spliced isoforms between the spaceflight and ground control samples, followed by a statistical analysis of differential alternative splicing.

Results: The analysis revealed that the spaceflight environment induced significant differences in the patterns of alternative splicing in the Arabidopsis seedlings when compared to the ground controls. This indicates that spaceflight not only changes which genes are expressed but also how the transcripts from those genes are processed.

Conclusions: This study provides the first evidence that alternative splicing plays a role in the molecular processes that underpin a plant's physiological adaptation to the spaceflight environment. This finding adds a new layer of regulatory complexity to our understanding of how plants respond to space.

Title: The Plant Health Monitoring System of the EDEN ISS Space Greenhouse in Antarctica during the 2018 experiment phase
Abstract: The EDEN ISS greenhouse is a space-analog test facility near the German Neumayer III station in Antarctica. The facility is part of the project of the same name and was designed and built starting from March 2015 and eventually deployed in Antarctica in January 2018. The nominal operation of the greenhouse started on February 7th and continued until the 20th of November. The purpose of the facility is to enable multidisciplinary research on topics related to future plant cultivation on human space exploration missions. Research on food quality and safety, plant health monitoring, microbiology, system validation, human factors and horticultural sciences was conducted. Part of the latter is the determination of the biomass production of the different crops. The data on this topic is presented in this paper. During the first season 26 different crops were grown on the 12.5 m2 cultivation area of the greenhouse. A large number of crops were grown continuously throughout the 9 months of operation, but there were also crops that were only grown a few times for test purposes. The focus of this season was on growing lettuce, leafy greens and fresh vegetables. In total more than 268 kg of edible biomass was produced by the EDEN ISS greenhouse facility in 2018. Most of the harvest was cucumbers (67 kg), lettuces (56 kg), leafy greens (49 kg), and tomatoes (50 kg) complemented with smaller amounts of herbs (12 kg), radish (8 kg), and kohlrabi (19 kg). The environmental set points for the crops were 330–600 μmol/(m2*s) LED light, 21°C, ∼65% relative humidity, 1000 ppm and the photoperiod was 17 h per day. The overall yearly productivity of the EDEN ISS greenhouse in 2018 was 27.4 kg/m2, which is equal to 0.075 kg/(m2*d). This paper shows in detail the data on edible and inedible biomass production of each crop grown in the EDEN ISS greenhouse in Antarctica during the 2018 season.
Overview: This paper provides a detailed account of the first operational season of the EDEN ISS greenhouse in Antarctica, a crucial analog for future space-based plant cultivation. It presents the biomass production data for 26 different crops grown in this closed-loop system, demonstrating its capability to produce significant amounts of fresh food (over 268 kg in 9 months). This is a vital resource for researchers and engineers developing bioregenerative life support systems, as it provides a real-world baseline for crop yields and system performance in an extreme, isolated environment.
Summary:
Background: The EDEN ISS greenhouse is a space-analog test facility in Antarctica designed for research on plant cultivation for future human space missions. This paper details the horticultural sciences aspect of the first season, focusing on biomass production.

Methods: Over a 9-month period in 2018, 26 different crop varieties were grown in the 12.5 m² cultivation area of the greenhouse. The crops, primarily lettuce, leafy greens, and fresh vegetables, were grown under controlled environmental conditions (LED light, temperature, humidity, CO2). Edible and inedible biomass was harvested and weighed to determine productivity.

Results: The facility produced a total of over 268 kg of edible biomass. The majority of the harvest consisted of cucumbers (67 kg), lettuce (56 kg), leafy greens (49 kg), and tomatoes (50 kg). The overall yearly productivity was 27.4 kg/m², equivalent to 0.075 kg/(m²*d). The paper provides detailed data on the biomass production for each crop grown.

Conclusions: The data from the first operational season of the EDEN ISS greenhouse demonstrate its effectiveness as a space-analog food production system. The successful cultivation and harvest of a variety of crops provide a valuable dataset for planning and designing bioregenerative life support systems for future long-duration space missions.

Title: Root skewing-associated genes impact the spaceflight response of Arabidopsis thaliana.
Abstract: The observation that plant roots skew in microgravity recently refuted the long-held conviction that skewing was a gravity-dependent phenomenon. Further, spaceflight root skewing suggests that specific root morphologies and cell wall remodeling systems may be important aspects of spaceflight physiological adaptation. However, connections between skewing, cell wall modification and spaceflight physiology are currently based on inferences rather than direct tests. Therefore, the Advanced Plant Experiments-03-2 (APEX-03-2) spaceflight study was designed to elucidate the contribution of two skewing- and cell wall-associated genes in Arabidopsis to root behavior and gene expression patterns in spaceflight, to assess whether interruptions of different skewing pathways affect the overall spaceflight-associated process. SPIRAL1 is a skewing-related protein implicated in directional cell expansion, and functions by regulating cortical microtubule dynamics. SKU5 is skewing-related glycosylphosphatidylinositol-anchored protein of the plasma membrane and cell wall implicated in stress response signaling. These two genes function in different cellular pathways that affect skewing on the Earth, and enable a test of the relevance of skewing pathways to spaceflight physiological adaptation. In this study, both sku5 and spr1 mutants showed different skewing behavior and markedly different patterns of gene expression in the spaceflight environment. The spr1 mutant showed fewer differentially expressed genes than its Col-0 wild-type, whereas sku5 showed considerably more than its WS wild-type. Developmental age played a substantial role in spaceflight acclimation in all genotypes, but particularly in sku5 plants, where spaceflight 4d seedlings had almost 10-times as many highly differentially expressed genes as the 8d seedlings. These differences demonstrated that the two skewing pathways represented by SKU5 and SPR1 have unique and opposite contributions to physiological adaptation to spaceflight. The spr1 response is less intense than wild type, suggesting that the loss of SPR1 positively impacts spaceflight adaptation. Conversely, the intensity of the sku5 responses suggests that the loss of SKU5 initiates a much more complex, deeper and more stress related response to spaceflight. This suggests that proper SKU5 function is important to spaceflight adaptation.
Conclusion: The physiological adaptation of sku5 to spaceflight is characterized by powerful stress responses, as well as the strong induction of LEAs and other genes associated with seed development. In contrast to sku5, spr1 differentially expressed fewer genes than Col-0 to physiologically adapt to spaceflight. This observation suggests that the spr1 mutation imbued an enhanced ability for rapid spaceflight acclimation while sku5 required an extended spaceflight response to accomplish acclimation, even to the point of initiating classic deep stress responses. These observations further suggest that the functional distinctions between sku5 and spr1 inform distinct aspects of the spaceflight response in plants, in particular the responses of young seedlings. The dramatic responses of sku5 suggest that lipid raft nanodomains of the plasma membrane and their associated GPI-APs play important roles in spaceflight physiological adaptation. The fact that sku5 and spr1 show markedly different gene expression patterns in spaceflight suggests that the two skewing pathways highlighted by SKU5 and SPR1 differentially affect the mechanisms used by plants to physiologically acclimate to spaceflight. Since spr1 and sku5 root lengths are not altered by spaceflight, the effects of these mutations lie not in the process of growth, but in the processes that direct morphology and structure, likely tying together the large number of cell wall remodeling genes observed as differentially expressed in spaceflight. The data from APEX-03-2 therefore provide an initial functional dissection of the spaceflight response in roots, one that allows an integration of pathways associated with root directionality, morphology and physiological responses to spaceflight.
Overview: This study provides a fascinating genetic dissection of the plant spaceflight response by examining how mutations affecting root skewing impact adaptation to microgravity. Researchers found that two different skewing-related mutants, spr1 and sku5, showed unique and opposite transcriptomic responses in space. The spr1 mutant had a less intense response than its wild-type, suggesting an improved adaptation, while sku5 had a much more severe stress response. This is a significant finding because it functionally links specific cellular pathways (microtubule dynamics vs. cell wall signaling) to different aspects of spaceflight acclimation.
Summary:
Background: Plant roots have been observed to skew in microgravity, suggesting that root morphology and cell wall remodeling are important aspects of spaceflight adaptation. This study was designed to test this connection by examining the spaceflight response of Arabidopsis mutants with known defects in root skewing pathways on Earth.

Methods: Two Arabidopsis mutants, sku5 and spiral1 (spr1), along with their respective wild-type controls, were grown on the International Space Station. The spr1 mutation affects microtubule dynamics, while sku5 affects a protein linked to the plasma membrane and cell wall. Root behavior and gene expression patterns (transcriptomics) were analyzed for seedlings at 4 and 8 days of growth.

Results: The spr1 mutant showed fewer differentially expressed genes in spaceflight compared to its wild-type, suggesting a less intense transcriptional response. In contrast, the sku5 mutant showed considerably more differentially expressed genes than its wild-type, indicating a stronger stress response, particularly in younger (4-day-old) seedlings. These differences demonstrate that the two mutations have unique and opposing effects on the plant's physiological adaptation to spaceflight.

Conclusions: The study concludes that the two skewing pathways represented by SKU5 and SPR1 have distinct contributions to spaceflight adaptation. The less intense response of the spr1 mutant suggests that the loss of its function may be beneficial for acclimation. Conversely, the intense response of the sku5 mutant suggests that proper SKU5 function is important for spaceflight adaptation. This work provides an initial functional dissection of the plant root's response to spaceflight.

Title: Articular cartilage and sternal fibrocartilage respond differently to extended microgravity.
Abstract: The effects of spaceflight on cartilaginous structure are largely unknown. To address this deficiency, articular cartilage (AC) and sternal cartilage (SC) from mice exposed to 30 days of microgravity on the BION-M1 craft were investigated for pathological changes. The flight AC showed some evidence of degradation at the tissue level with loss of proteoglycan staining and a reduction in mRNA expression of mechano-responsive and structural cartilage matrix proteins compared to non-flight controls. These data suggest that degradative changes are underway in the AC extracellular matrix exposed to microgravity. In contrast, there was no evidence of cartilage breakdown in SC flight samples and the gene expression profile was distinct from that of AC with a reduction in metalloproteinase gene transcription. Since the two cartilages respond differently to microgravity we propose that each is tuned to the biomechanical environments in which they are normally maintained. That is, the differences between magnitude of normal terrestrial loading and the unloading of microgravity dictates the tissue response. Weight-bearing articular cartilage, but not minimally loaded sternal fibrocartilage, is negatively affected by the unloading of microgravity. We speculate that the maintenance of physiological loading on AC during spaceflight will minimize AC damage.
Overview: This study provides a novel and important comparison of how different types of cartilage respond to the unloading environment of spaceflight. By examining both articular cartilage (AC) from weight-bearing joints and sternal fibrocartilage (SC) from the minimally-loaded sternum of mice after a 30-day mission, researchers found that only the weight-bearing cartilage showed signs of degradation. This finding suggests that the negative effects of microgravity on cartilage are primarily dictated by the degree of unloading from the tissue's normal terrestrial state, a crucial insight for developing countermeasures for astronauts.
Summary:
Background: The effects of spaceflight on cartilaginous structures are largely unknown. This study aimed to investigate whether microgravity exposure would cause pathological changes in two different types of cartilage: articular cartilage (AC) from a weight-bearing joint, and sternal cartilage (SC), which is minimally loaded.

Methods: Articular cartilage and sternal cartilage were collected from mice after a 30-day microgravity exposure on the BION-M1 mission. The tissues were investigated for pathological changes using histology (to assess proteoglycan staining) and for changes in gene expression (mRNA) of key cartilage matrix proteins and metalloproteinases.

Results: The flight articular cartilage showed evidence of degradation, including a loss of proteoglycan staining and a reduction in the mRNA expression of mechano-responsive and structural matrix proteins compared to non-flight controls. In stark contrast, the sternal cartilage from the flight samples showed no evidence of breakdown. The gene expression profile in the SC was also distinct from that of the AC, with a reduction in the transcription of metalloproteinase genes.

Conclusions: The two types of cartilage responded differently to microgravity. The authors propose that this difference is because each cartilage type is tuned to its normal biomechanical environment on Earth. The weight-bearing articular cartilage was negatively affected by the unloading of microgravity, while the minimally loaded sternal fibrocartilage was not. This suggests that maintaining physiological loading on AC during spaceflight could minimize damage.

Title: Host-microbe interactions in microgravity: assessment and implications.
Abstract: Spaceflight imposes several unique stresses on biological life that together can have a profound impact on the homeostasis between eukaryotes and their associated microbes. One such stressor, microgravity, has been shown to alter host-microbe interactions at the genetic and physiological levels. Recent sequencing of the microbiomes associated with plants and animals have shown that these interactions are essential for maintaining host health through the regulation of several metabolic and immune responses. Disruptions to various environmental parameters or community characteristics may impact the resiliency of the microbiome, thus potentially driving host-microbe associations towards disease. In this review, we discuss our current understanding of host-microbe interactions in microgravity and assess the impact of this unique environmental stress on the normal physiological and genetic responses of both pathogenic and mutualistic associations. As humans move beyond our biosphere and undergo longer duration space flights, it will be essential to more fully understand microbial fitness in microgravity conditions in order to maintain a healthy homeostasis between humans, plants and their respective microbiomes.
Overview: This review is essential for understanding the health risks of long-duration spaceflight, as it synthesizes our current knowledge of how microgravity alters the critical relationship between hosts and their microbiomes. It discusses how spaceflight can impact both pathogenic and mutualistic interactions at genetic and physiological levels. The paper is valuable because it highlights the importance of maintaining a healthy host-microbe homeostasis for the success of future missions beyond our biosphere, as disruptions can drive associations toward disease.
Summary:
Background: Spaceflight imposes unique stresses, particularly microgravity, which can have a profound impact on the balance between eukaryotic organisms and their associated microbes. As these microbiomes are essential for host health, understanding how they are disrupted by spaceflight is critical.

Methods: This is a review article. The authors discuss the current understanding of host-microbe interactions in microgravity by summarizing genetic and physiological studies on both pathogenic (disease-causing) and mutualistic (beneficial) associations.

Results: The review consolidates findings showing that microgravity can alter gene expression and physiology in both hosts and their microbes. These disruptions can impact the resiliency of the microbiome and potentially shift host-microbe associations toward a disease state, affecting the host's metabolic and immune responses.

Conclusions: The abstract concludes that as humans embark on longer-duration spaceflights, a more complete understanding of microbial fitness in microgravity is essential. This knowledge is necessary to develop strategies to maintain a healthy homeostasis between humans, their food crops, and their respective microbiomes.

Title: Environmental cues and symbiont microbe-associated molecular patterns function in concert to drive the daily remodelling of the crypt-cell brush border of the Euprymna scolopes light organ
Abstract: Summary Recent research has shown that the microbiota affects the biology of associated host epithelial tissues, including their circadian rhythms, although few data are available on how such influences shape the microarchitecture of the brush border. The squid-vibrio system exhibits two modifications of the brush border that supports the symbionts: effacement and repolarization. Together these occur on a daily rhythm in adult animals, at the dawn expulsion of symbionts into the environment, and symbiont colonization of the juvenile host induces an increase in microvillar density. Here we sought to define how these processes are related and the roles of both symbiont colonization and environmental cues. Ultrastructural analyses showed that the juvenile-organ brush borders also efface concomitantly with daily dawn-cued expulsion of symbionts. Manipulation of the environmental light cue and juvenile symbiotic state demonstrated that this behaviour requires the light cue, but not colonization. In contrast, symbionts were required for the observed increase in microvillar density that accompanies post dawn brush-border repolarization; this increase was induced solely by host exposure to phosphorylated lipid A of symbiont cells. These data demonstrate that a partnering of environmental and symbiont cues shapes the brush border and that microbe-associated molecular patterns play a role in the regulation of brush-border microarchitecture.
Overview: This study provides a fascinating look at how environmental cues and symbiotic bacteria work in concert to drive the daily remodeling of host tissues. Using the squid-vibrio light organ model, researchers show that a daily, dawn-cued effacement (shedding) of the brush border is controlled by light, but the subsequent repolarization and increase in microvillar density requires a specific molecule from the symbiont bacteria (lipid A).
